**Brain Tumors** are abnormal cell growths in the brain, which can be benign or malignant. Types:

  • Primary brain tumors (originate in the brain)
  • Metastatic brain tumors (spread from other body parts)
  • Common types: Gliomas, Meningiomas, Pituitary tumors
Symptoms:
  • Headaches (worse in the morning)
  • Seizures or convulsions
  • Vision, hearing, or speech difficulties
  • Cognitive or personality changes
Treatment:
  • Surgery to remove the tumor
  • Radiation therapy to target tumor cells
  • Chemotherapy and targeted drug therapies
  • Supportive care to manage symptoms
References:
  1. American Cancer Society: Brain Tumors
  2. Mayo Clinic: Brain Tumors

Brain Tumours in Children: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Brain tumours are the most common solid tumors in children. Learn about their causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Brain Tumours in Children** can be benign or malignant, affecting brain function and development. Causes:

  • Genetic conditions (e.g., Li-Fraumeni syndrome)
  • Radiation exposure
  • Inherited gene mutations
  • Unknown causes in many cases
Symptoms:
  • Frequent headaches, especially in the morning
  • Nausea or vomiting
  • Balance and coordination issues
  • Changes in behavior or academic performance
Treatment:
  • Surgery to remove the tumor
  • Chemotherapy tailored for children
  • Radiation therapy with caution to minimize side effects
  • Rehabilitation for physical and cognitive recovery
References:
  1. American Cancer Society: Childhood Brain Tumors
  2. NHS: Brain Tumours in Children

Brain Tumours in Teenagers & Young Adults: Symptoms & Care

Brain tumours in teenagers and young adults require specialized care. Understand their symptoms, risks, and treatment options.

**Brain Tumours** in teenagers and young adults can disrupt education, social life, and overall health. Causes:

  • Genetic predispositions
  • Previous radiation therapy
  • Environmental exposures (rare)
  • Family history of brain tumors
Symptoms:
  • Persistent headaches and vision problems
  • Difficulty with balance and coordination
  • Seizures
  • Fatigue and memory issues
Treatment:
  • Surgical intervention when possible
  • Radiation and chemotherapy with age-appropriate protocols
  • Counseling and support for emotional well-being
References:
  1. Cancer Research UK: Brain Tumours in Young People
  2. NHS: Brain Tumours

Breast Cancer in Women: Signs, Causes & Treatment

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Learn about risk factors, early signs, and treatment options.

**Breast Cancer in Women** occurs when malignant cells form in the breast tissue. Causes & Risk Factors:

  • Family history and genetic mutations (BRCA1/BRCA2)
  • Hormonal influences (estrogen exposure)
  • Lifestyle factors (obesity, alcohol use)
  • Age and reproductive history
Symptoms:
  • Lump or thickening in the breast or armpit
  • Changes in breast shape or size
  • Nipple discharge (especially bloody)
  • Skin dimpling or redness
Treatment:
  • Surgery (lumpectomy or mastectomy)
  • Chemotherapy, radiation, and hormone therapy
  • Targeted therapies for specific cancer types
References:
  1. American Cancer Society: Breast Cancer
  2. NHS: Breast Cancer

Breast Cancer in Men: Causes, Symptoms & Care

Though rare, men can develop breast cancer. Learn about its causes, early signs, and available treatment options.

**Breast Cancer in Men** is uncommon but often diagnosed late due to lack of awareness. Causes:

  • Hormonal imbalances (elevated estrogen)
  • Family history and BRCA mutations
  • Liver disease and obesity
  • Radiation exposure
Symptoms:
  • Lump in the breast area
  • Nipple retraction or discharge
  • Swelling or redness around the breast
  • Sores or scaling of nipple skin
Treatment:
  • Surgery (mastectomy)
  • Radiation and chemotherapy
  • Hormone therapy (tamoxifen)
References:
  1. American Cancer Society: Male Breast Cancer
  2. NHS: Breast Cancer in Men

Bronchiectasis: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Bronchiectasis is a chronic lung condition that causes persistent coughing and mucus buildup. Explore causes, symptoms, and treatments.

**Bronchiectasis** involves permanent widening of the airways, leading to mucus accumulation and frequent infections. Causes:

  • Previous lung infections (e.g., pneumonia, tuberculosis)
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Immune system disorders
  • Chronic aspiration or inhalation injuries
Symptoms:
  • Chronic productive cough
  • Breathlessness and wheezing
  • Frequent lung infections
  • Fatigue and weight loss
Management:
  • Airway clearance techniques (physiotherapy)
  • Antibiotics for infections
  • Bronchodilators and inhaled corticosteroids
  • Vaccinations to prevent infections
References:
  1. NHS: Bronchiectasis
  2. Mayo Clinic: Bronchiectasis

Bronchitis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Bronchitis is the inflammation of the bronchial tubes, leading to coughing and mucus production. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Bronchitis** can be acute or chronic, often resulting from infections or irritants. Causes:

  • Viral infections (common cause of acute bronchitis)
  • Smoking and air pollution
  • Exposure to dust, fumes, or chemicals
  • Chronic lung diseases (e.g., COPD)
Symptoms:
  • Persistent cough with mucus
  • Chest discomfort
  • Shortness of breath
  • Low-grade fever and fatigue
Treatment:
  • Rest and fluid intake for viral cases
  • Inhalers or bronchodilators for chronic bronchitis
  • Antibiotics (only if a bacterial infection is present)
  • Avoiding smoke and pollutants
References:
  1. NHS: Bronchitis
  2. CDC: Bronchitis Overview

Bulimia Nervosa: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by binge eating followed by purging. Understand its causes, symptoms, and treatment methods.

**Bulimia Nervosa** involves cycles of overeating followed by compensatory behaviors like vomiting or excessive exercise. Causes:

  • Psychological factors (anxiety, depression, low self-esteem)
  • Societal pressure for thinness
  • Genetic predisposition
  • Trauma or significant life stressors
Symptoms:
  • Frequent episodes of binge eating
  • Self-induced vomiting or misuse of laxatives
  • Swollen cheeks and dental erosion
  • Electrolyte imbalances and fatigue
Treatment:
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
  • Medication (e.g., antidepressants)
  • Nutritional counseling
  • Support groups and family therapy
References:
  1. NHS: Bulimia Nervosa
  2. NEDA: Bulimia Information

Bunion: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A bunion is a bony bump that forms on the joint at the base of the big toe. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Bunion** (hallux valgus) is a deformity that causes the big toe to lean towards the other toes, creating a painful bump. Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition
  • Wearing tight or high-heeled shoes
  • Foot injuries
  • Arthritis (especially rheumatoid arthritis)
Symptoms:
  • Visible bump on the side of the big toe
  • Pain and swelling around the joint
  • Restricted toe movement
  • Corn or callus development
Treatment:
  • Changing to comfortable footwear
  • Pain relievers and anti-inflammatory medications
  • Orthotics or bunion pads
  • Surgery (bunionectomy) for severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Bunions
  2. AAOS: Bunion Information

Carcinoid Syndrome & Tumours: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Carcinoid tumours are slow-growing neuroendocrine tumours that can cause carcinoid syndrome. Learn about causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Carcinoid Tumours** are rare, slow-growing tumours that usually develop in the gastrointestinal tract or lungs. When they release hormones into the bloodstream, they cause **Carcinoid Syndrome**. Causes:

  • Genetic factors (e.g., MEN1 syndrome)
  • Family history of neuroendocrine tumours
  • Smoking (linked to lung carcinoid tumours)
Symptoms:
  • Flushing of the skin (especially face and neck)
  • Diarrhea and abdominal cramping
  • Wheezing and breathing difficulties
  • Rapid heartbeat (tachycardia)
Treatment:
  • Surgical removal of the tumour
  • Medications to control hormone production (e.g., somatostatin analogs)
  • Targeted therapies and chemotherapy
  • Liver-directed therapies for metastases
References:
  1. American Cancer Society: Carcinoid Tumours
  2. Cancer Research UK: Carcinoid Tumours

Cardiovascular Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Prevention

Cardiovascular disease (CVD) refers to a range of heart and blood vessel disorders. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and preventive measures.

**Cardiovascular Disease (CVD)** encompasses conditions like coronary artery disease, heart failure, and stroke. Causes:

  • High blood pressure (hypertension)
  • High cholesterol levels
  • Smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
  • Poor diet and physical inactivity
  • Diabetes and obesity
Symptoms:
  • Chest pain (angina)
  • Shortness of breath
  • Dizziness or fainting
  • Swelling in the legs, ankles, or feet
Prevention & Treatment:
  • Lifestyle changes (healthy diet, regular exercise, quitting smoking)
  • Medications to control blood pressure and cholesterol
  • Surgical interventions (e.g., stent placement, bypass surgery)
  • Regular medical check-ups and risk assessments
References:
  1. WHO: Cardiovascular Diseases
  2. American Heart Association: Cardiovascular Health

Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve in the wrist. Discover its causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS)** occurs when the median nerve is compressed as it passes through the wrist. Causes:

  • Repetitive hand movements (e.g., typing, assembly work)
  • Pregnancy (fluid retention can increase pressure)
  • Rheumatoid arthritis and diabetes
  • Wrist injuries or fractures
Symptoms:
  • Numbness and tingling in the fingers (especially thumb, index, and middle fingers)
  • Weak grip strength
  • Pain radiating up the arm
  • Difficulty with fine motor tasks
Treatment:
  • Wrist splints to relieve pressure
  • Anti-inflammatory medications
  • Steroid injections to reduce swelling
  • Surgery (carpal tunnel release) in severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
  2. AAOS: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

Catarrh: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Catarrh refers to the buildup of mucus in the nose or throat, often linked to infections or allergies. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatments.

**Catarrh** is an excessive buildup of mucus in the airways, typically caused by infections or allergies. Causes:

  • Common cold or flu
  • Sinus infections (sinusitis)
  • Allergic reactions (e.g., hay fever)
  • Environmental irritants (smoke, pollution)
Symptoms:
  • Nasal congestion and runny nose
  • Postnasal drip and throat clearing
  • Earache and hearing difficulties
  • Reduced sense of smell and taste
Management:
  • Saline nasal sprays and decongestants
  • Allergy medications (antihistamines)
  • Steam inhalation for relief
  • Avoiding known triggers and irritants
References:
  1. NHS: Catarrh
  2. Healthline: Catarrh Overview

Cellulitis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection causing redness, swelling, and pain. Find out about causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Cellulitis** is a bacterial infection of the skin and underlying tissues, commonly caused by *Streptococcus* or *Staphylococcus* bacteria. Causes:

  • Breaks in the skin (cuts, insect bites, surgical wounds)
  • Weakened immune system
  • Skin conditions (eczema, athlete's foot)
  • Chronic swelling (lymphedema)
Symptoms:
  • Red, swollen, and painful skin
  • Warmth in the affected area
  • Fever and chills
  • Blisters or skin dimpling in severe cases
Treatment:
  • Oral or intravenous antibiotics
  • Pain relievers and anti-inflammatory medications
  • Elevation of the affected limb to reduce swelling
  • Hospitalization for severe infections
References:
  1. NHS: Cellulitis
  2. CDC: Cellulitis Information

Cerebral Palsy: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Cerebral palsy is a group of disorders affecting movement, muscle tone, and posture. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and management options.

**Cerebral Palsy (CP)** is caused by abnormal brain development or damage during birth or early childhood, affecting motor skills. Causes:

  • Premature birth
  • Lack of oxygen during birth
  • Brain infections like meningitis
  • Head injuries in early childhood
Symptoms:
  • Muscle stiffness or floppiness
  • Poor coordination and balance
  • Delayed developmental milestones
  • Difficulty with speech and swallowing
Management:
  • Physical, occupational, and speech therapies
  • Medications for muscle spasticity
  • Surgical interventions for mobility improvement
  • Assistive devices like wheelchairs and braces
References:
  1. CDC: Cerebral Palsy
  2. NHS: Cerebral Palsy

Cervical Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Cervical cancer develops in the cells of the cervix, often caused by HPV. Discover its causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Cervical Cancer** begins in the cervix and is primarily linked to persistent infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types. Causes:

  • HPV infection (most common cause)
  • Smoking and weakened immune system
  • Long-term use of oral contraceptives
  • Multiple sexual partners increasing HPV risk
Symptoms:
  • Abnormal vaginal bleeding (after intercourse or between periods)
  • Pelvic pain or discomfort during intercourse
  • Unusual vaginal discharge
  • Painful urination in advanced stages
Treatment:
  • Surgical removal of cancerous tissues
  • Radiation therapy and chemotherapy
  • Targeted therapy for advanced cases
  • HPV vaccination for prevention
References:
  1. American Cancer Society: Cervical Cancer
  2. NHS: Cervical Cancer

Cervical Spondylosis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Cervical spondylosis is age-related wear and tear of the neck's spinal discs. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatments.

**Cervical Spondylosis** involves degenerative changes in the cervical spine due to aging. Causes:

  • Age-related wear of spinal discs
  • Previous neck injuries
  • Occupations with repetitive neck motions
  • Genetic predisposition
Symptoms:
  • Neck pain and stiffness
  • Headaches originating from the neck
  • Numbness or weakness in arms and hands
  • Loss of balance and coordination
Treatment:
  • Pain relievers and anti-inflammatory medications
  • Physical therapy to improve mobility
  • Neck braces for short-term relief
  • Surgery in severe cases with nerve compression
References:
  1. NHS: Cervical Spondylosis
  2. Healthline: Cervical Spondylosis

Chest & Rib Injury: Causes, Symptoms & Care

Chest and rib injuries often result from trauma, causing pain and breathing difficulties. Learn about causes, symptoms, and first aid measures.

**Chest and Rib Injuries** include fractures, bruises, or muscle strains affecting breathing and mobility. Causes:

  • Falls or direct blows to the chest
  • Car accidents
  • Severe coughing or sudden twisting movements
  • Contact sports injuries
Symptoms:
  • Pain that worsens with movement or deep breathing
  • Swelling and tenderness over the affected area
  • Difficulty breathing in severe cases
  • Bruising around the injury site
Care & Treatment:
  • Pain management with medications
  • Cold compresses to reduce swelling
  • Breathing exercises to prevent lung infections
  • Hospital care for severe injuries (e.g., punctured lungs)
References:
  1. NHS: Chest and Rib Injury
  2. CDC: Injury Prevention

Chest Infection: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Chest infections like bronchitis and pneumonia cause coughing and breathing difficulties. Learn about causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Chest Infections** involve inflammation of the lungs or airways, often caused by bacteria or viruses. Causes:

  • Viral infections (e.g., cold or flu)
  • Bacterial infections (e.g., pneumonia)
  • Weakened immune system
  • Smoking and lung conditions (COPD)
Symptoms:
  • Persistent cough with phlegm
  • Fever and chills
  • Chest pain when breathing or coughing
  • Shortness of breath and fatigue
Treatment:
  • Rest and increased fluid intake
  • Antibiotics for bacterial infections
  • Inhalers for breathing relief
  • Hospitalization for severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Chest Infection
  2. CDC: Pneumonia Information

Chickenpox: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Chickenpox is a contagious viral infection causing an itchy rash and flu-like symptoms. Learn about causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Chickenpox** is caused by the varicella-zoster virus, spreading through respiratory droplets and direct contact. Causes:

  • Exposure to an infected person's cough, sneeze, or rash
  • Lack of varicella vaccination
Symptoms:
  • Itchy red rash turning into fluid-filled blisters
  • Fever and fatigue
  • Loss of appetite
  • Headache and general discomfort
Treatment:
  • Calamine lotion for itch relief
  • Antihistamines to reduce itching
  • Acetaminophen for fever (avoid aspirin)
  • Antiviral medication for high-risk individuals
References:
  1. NHS: Chickenpox
  2. CDC: Chickenpox Information

Chilblains: Causes, Symptoms & Prevention

Chilblains are small, itchy swellings on the skin caused by cold exposure. Learn about causes, symptoms, and preventive measures.

**Chilblains** occur due to abnormal reaction of small blood vessels to cold temperatures. Causes:

  • Sudden warming of cold skin
  • Poor circulation and damp environments
  • Tight footwear and clothing
  • Underlying conditions like Raynaud's disease
Symptoms:
  • Red, swollen, and itchy patches on skin
  • Burning or tingling sensations
  • Skin ulcers in severe cases
  • Blistering and inflammation
Prevention & Treatment:
  • Keep body warm, especially hands and feet
  • Avoid sudden temperature changes
  • Use soothing creams and corticosteroids
  • Consult a doctor if ulcers or infections occur
References:
  1. NHS: Chilblains
  2. Healthline: Chilblains

Chlamydia: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Chlamydia is a common sexually transmitted infection often without symptoms. Learn about causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Chlamydia** is caused by the bacteria *Chlamydia trachomatis* and spreads through unprotected sexual contact. Causes:

  • Unprotected vaginal, anal, or oral sex
  • Sharing sex toys without proper cleaning
  • Mother-to-child transmission during childbirth
Symptoms:
  • Painful urination and genital discharge
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Pain during intercourse (in females)
  • Testicular pain and swelling (in males)
  • Most cases may be asymptomatic
Treatment & Prevention:
  • Antibiotic course (usually doxycycline or azithromycin)
  • Avoid sexual activity until treatment completion
  • Regular STI screenings for sexually active individuals
  • Consistent use of condoms and safe sex practices
References:
  1. NHS: Chlamydia
  2. CDC: Chlamydia Information

Chronic Fatigue Syndrome: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) is a complex disorder causing persistent, debilitating fatigue. Learn about its possible triggers, symptoms, and management strategies.

**Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)**, also known as myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME), is characterized by prolonged, severe fatigue that does not improve with rest. Causes:

  • The exact cause is unknown, but infections, stress, and immune dysfunction may trigger it.
  • Possible hormonal imbalances and genetic factors.
Symptoms:
  • Persistent fatigue lasting over six months.
  • Difficulty concentrating and memory problems.
  • Sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and muscle pain.
  • Unrefreshing sleep and post-exertional malaise.
Management:
  • Graded exercise therapy and pacing of activities.
  • Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) to manage symptoms.
  • Medications for pain and sleep disturbances.
  • Lifestyle adjustments and stress management techniques.
References:
  1. NHS: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
  2. CDC: ME/CFS

Chronic Kidney Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is the gradual loss of kidney function over time. Discover its causes, key symptoms, and available treatment options.

**Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)** is a progressive condition where the kidneys lose their ability to filter waste and excess fluids from the blood. Causes:

  • Diabetes and high blood pressure are the leading causes.
  • Glomerulonephritis and other chronic kidney infections.
  • Inherited conditions such as polycystic kidney disease.
Symptoms:
  • Fatigue, weakness, and loss of appetite.
  • Swelling in the legs, ankles, or feet.
  • Changes in urination patterns and fluid retention.
  • Nausea and difficulty concentrating.
Treatment:
  • Medications to manage blood pressure and blood sugar levels.
  • Dietary changes and lifestyle modifications.
  • Dialysis or kidney transplant for advanced stages.
References:
  1. NHS: Chronic Kidney Disease
  2. National Kidney Foundation

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) is a slow-growing blood cancer affecting lymphocytes. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatment approaches.

**Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL)** is a type of cancer that originates in the blood and bone marrow, characterized by the overproduction of abnormal lymphocytes. Causes:

  • The exact cause is unclear, though genetic mutations are involved.
  • Exposure to certain chemicals or radiation may increase the risk.
Symptoms:
  • Painless swelling of lymph nodes.
  • Fatigue and weakness.
  • Frequent infections.
  • Unintended weight loss and night sweats.
Treatment:
  • Watchful waiting in early, asymptomatic stages.
  • Chemotherapy and targeted therapy for progressing cases.
  • Immunotherapy and occasionally stem cell transplant.
References:
  1. American Cancer Society: CLL
  2. NHS: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

COPD is a progressive lung disease that makes breathing difficult. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)** is characterized by long-term respiratory symptoms and airflow limitation. Causes:

  • Long-term exposure to cigarette smoke and air pollutants
  • Genetic factors, such as alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
  • Chronic bronchitis and emphysema
Symptoms:
  • Shortness of breath, especially during physical activity
  • Chronic cough and sputum production
  • Wheezing and chest tightness
  • Frequent respiratory infections
Treatment:
  • Smoking cessation and avoidance of pollutants
  • Bronchodilators and inhaled corticosteroids
  • Oxygen therapy and pulmonary rehabilitation
  • Medications to manage symptoms
References:
  1. NHS: COPD
  2. CDC: COPD

Chronic Pain: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Chronic pain persists for months or years, impacting daily life. Understand its causes, symptoms, and management strategies.

**Chronic Pain** can result from various conditions and injuries, affecting both physical and emotional well-being. Causes:

  • Injuries, inflammation, or nerve damage
  • Conditions such as arthritis, fibromyalgia, and back pain
  • Psychological factors and stress
Symptoms:
  • Persistent pain in one or more areas of the body
  • Mood changes and sleep disturbances
  • Reduced mobility and activity limitations
Management:
  • Medications, including pain relievers and anti-inflammatories
  • Physical therapy and exercise
  • Cognitive behavioral therapy and mindfulness techniques
  • Alternative treatments such as acupuncture
References:
  1. NHS: Chronic Pain
  2. American Chronic Pain Association

Chronic Pancreatitis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Chronic pancreatitis is long-term inflammation of the pancreas, often causing abdominal pain and digestive issues. Learn about its causes and management.

**Chronic Pancreatitis** is characterized by persistent inflammation of the pancreas leading to scarring and impaired function. Causes:

  • Long-term alcohol abuse
  • Genetic predisposition and autoimmune conditions
  • Obstruction of the pancreatic duct
Symptoms:
  • Severe, recurring abdominal pain
  • Weight loss and malnutrition
  • Digestive problems and oily, foul-smelling stools
Treatment:
  • Pain management and dietary modifications
  • Pancreatic enzyme supplements
  • Endoscopic or surgical interventions when necessary
References:
  1. NHS: Chronic Pancreatitis
  2. Mayo Clinic: Chronic Pancreatitis

Cirrhosis: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Cirrhosis is the scarring of the liver due to long-term damage. Learn about its causes, key symptoms, and management options.

**Cirrhosis** involves the gradual replacement of healthy liver tissue with scar tissue, leading to impaired liver function. Causes:

  • Chronic alcohol abuse
  • Hepatitis B and C infections
  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
Symptoms:
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  • Swelling in the legs and abdomen
  • Easy bruising and bleeding
Management:
  • Lifestyle changes such as abstaining from alcohol
  • Medications to manage complications
  • Regular monitoring and supportive care
  • Liver transplant in advanced cases
References:
  1. NHS: Cirrhosis
  2. American Liver Foundation

Clavicle (Collar Bone) Fracture: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A clavicle fracture is a break in the collar bone, often resulting from trauma. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Clavicle Fracture** refers to a break or crack in the collar bone, typically caused by falls, sports injuries, or accidents. Causes:

  • Falls onto an outstretched arm or directly onto the shoulder
  • Sports injuries or accidents
  • Direct trauma to the clavicle
Symptoms:
  • Pain and tenderness around the collar bone
  • Swelling and bruising
  • Limited movement of the arm
  • Visible deformity or bump at the fracture site
Treatment:
  • Immobilization with a sling or figure-of-eight bandage
  • Pain relief and anti-inflammatory medications
  • Physical therapy for rehabilitation
  • Surgery in cases of severe displacement or complications
References:
  1. NHS: Clavicle Fracture
  2. AAOS: Clavicle Fractures

Clostridium difficile: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Clostridium difficile is a bacterium that causes severe diarrhea and colitis, often linked to antibiotic use.

**Clostridium difficile (C. diff)** is a bacterium responsible for significant intestinal infections. Causes:

  • Prolonged use of antibiotics disrupting normal gut flora
  • Hospital-acquired infections
  • Advanced age and weakened immune systems
Symptoms:
  • Severe, watery diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain and cramping
  • Fever and nausea
  • In severe cases, colitis and dehydration
Diagnosis:
  • Stool tests for toxins A and B
  • Enzyme immunoassay (EIA) and PCR tests
Treatment:
  • Discontinuing the inciting antibiotic when possible
  • Using targeted antibiotics such as metronidazole or vancomycin
  • Fecal microbiota transplantation in recurrent cases
Prevention:
  • Proper hand hygiene and infection control in healthcare settings
  • Judicious use of antibiotics
References:
  1. NHS: Clostridium difficile
  2. CDC: C. difficile

Coeliac Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Coeliac disease is an autoimmune condition triggered by gluten that damages the small intestine.

**Coeliac Disease** is an immune-mediated disorder in which ingestion of gluten leads to inflammation and damage to the small intestine. Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 markers
  • Autoimmune reaction to gluten found in wheat, barley, and rye
Symptoms:
  • Diarrhea, abdominal pain, and bloating
  • Weight loss and malabsorption of nutrients
  • Fatigue and anemia
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis (a blistering skin rash)
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests for anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies
  • Small intestine biopsy for confirmation
Treatment:
  • Adopting a strict gluten-free diet
  • Nutritional supplementation if needed
  • Regular monitoring with a healthcare professional
References:
  1. NHS: Coeliac Disease
  2. Coeliac UK

Cold Sore: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Cold sores are painful blisters around the mouth caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV-1).

**Cold Sores** are caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) and can be triggered by stress, illness, or sun exposure. Causes:

  • Infection with HSV-1
  • Triggers such as stress, fever, or UV exposure
  • Weakened immune system
Symptoms:
  • Tingling or burning sensation around the lips
  • Formation of small, fluid-filled blisters
  • Pain and discomfort during outbreaks
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination by a healthcare provider
  • Viral culture or PCR test in uncertain cases
Treatment:
  • Topical antiviral creams and oral antiviral medications (e.g., acyclovir)
  • Pain relievers and cold compresses for symptom relief
  • Avoidance of known triggers
Prevention:
  • Managing stress and protecting lips from sun exposure
  • Avoiding direct contact during active outbreaks
References:
  1. NHS: Cold Sores
  2. CDC: Herpes Simplex Virus

Coma: Causes, Symptoms & Management

A coma is a prolonged state of unconsciousness resulting from severe brain injury or illness.

**Coma** is a deep state of prolonged unconsciousness often resulting from traumatic brain injury, stroke, or metabolic disturbances. Causes:

  • Severe traumatic brain injury
  • Stroke or brain infections
  • Metabolic imbalances and drug overdose
Symptoms:
  • Lack of response to external stimuli
  • Absence of purposeful movement
  • Unresponsiveness to pain or sound
  • Low or no eye-opening response
Diagnosis:
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) assessment
  • Neuroimaging (CT, MRI) to identify brain injuries
  • Electroencephalogram (EEG) to assess brain activity
Management:
  • Intensive care and supportive treatment
  • Treatment of the underlying cause
  • Continuous monitoring in a hospital setting
References:
  1. NHS: Coma
  2. Mayo Clinic: Coma

Common Cold: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, causing sneezing, coughing, and a runny nose.

**Common Cold** is primarily caused by rhinoviruses and other respiratory viruses. Causes:

  • Viral infections, primarily rhinovirus
  • Transmission via respiratory droplets
  • Close contact with infected individuals
Symptoms:
  • Runny or stuffy nose
  • Sore throat and cough
  • Sneezing and mild fever
  • Mild headache and body aches
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation based on symptoms
Treatment:
  • Rest and increased fluid intake
  • Over-the-counter decongestants and pain relievers
  • Home remedies such as warm teas and humidifiers
Prevention:
  • Frequent handwashing and avoiding close contact with infected individuals
  • Maintaining a healthy lifestyle to support the immune system
References:
  1. NHS: Common Cold
  2. CDC: Rhinovirus & Common Cold

Concussion: Causes, Symptoms & Management

A concussion is a mild traumatic brain injury usually resulting from a blow to the head. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and recovery strategies.

**Concussion** is a type of traumatic brain injury that temporarily affects brain function. It can occur from sports injuries, falls, or accidents. Causes:

  • Direct impact to the head
  • Falls or collisions during sports
  • Motor vehicle accidents
Symptoms:
  • Headache and dizziness
  • Nausea and blurred vision
  • Confusion and memory loss
  • Balance problems
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and neurological examination
  • Imaging tests (CT or MRI) if severe
Treatment:
  • Rest and gradual return to activities
  • Pain relievers and monitoring of symptoms
  • Follow-up with healthcare providers
Prevention:
  • Using protective gear during sports
  • Implementing safety measures at home and work
References:
  1. NHS: Concussion
  2. CDC: Concussion Basics

Congenital Heart Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Congenital heart disease refers to structural heart defects present at birth. Understand its causes, common symptoms, and treatment options.

**Congenital Heart Disease (CHD)** includes a range of heart defects that develop during fetal life. Causes:

  • Genetic factors and family history
  • Maternal infections or exposure to toxins during pregnancy
  • Unknown developmental factors
Symptoms:
  • Rapid breathing and fatigue in infants
  • Cyanosis (blue-tinted skin)
  • Heart murmurs
  • Poor growth and feeding difficulties
Diagnosis:
  • Echocardiogram and chest X-ray
  • Electrocardiogram (ECG) and cardiac MRI
Treatment:
  • Medications to manage symptoms
  • Interventional procedures or surgery to repair defects
  • Long-term monitoring and care
Prevention:
  • Proper prenatal care and avoiding harmful substances during pregnancy
  • Genetic counseling for at-risk families
References:
  1. NHS: Congenital Heart Disease
  2. American Heart Association: Congenital Heart Defects

Conjunctivitis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Conjunctivitis, commonly known as pink eye, is an inflammation of the eye’s conjunctiva. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Conjunctivitis** is an inflammation or infection of the conjunctiva, the transparent membrane covering the white part of the eye. Causes:

  • Viral or bacterial infections
  • Allergic reactions
  • Irritants such as smoke or chemicals
Symptoms:
  • Redness and irritation in one or both eyes
  • Itching, burning, or gritty sensation
  • Watery or sticky discharge
  • Sensitivity to light
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination by an eye specialist
  • Swab tests in cases of suspected bacterial infection
Treatment:
  • Antibiotic eye drops for bacterial conjunctivitis
  • Antihistamines or artificial tears for allergic cases
  • Cold compresses to soothe irritation
Prevention:
  • Frequent handwashing and avoiding touching the eyes
  • Avoiding close contact with infected individuals
References:
  1. NHS: Conjunctivitis
  2. CDC: Conjunctivitis

Constipation: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Constipation is a common digestive problem characterized by infrequent or difficult bowel movements. Learn about its causes and how to manage it.

**Constipation** occurs when bowel movements become less frequent and stools become hard to pass. Causes:

  • Low fiber diet and inadequate fluid intake
  • Lack of physical activity
  • Certain medications and medical conditions
Symptoms:
  • Infrequent bowel movements
  • Straining during defecation
  • Bloating and abdominal discomfort
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and medical history
  • Abdominal exam and, if needed, imaging tests
Treatment:
  • Increasing dietary fiber and fluid intake
  • Regular physical activity
  • Over-the-counter laxatives when necessary
Prevention:
  • Maintaining a balanced diet with sufficient fiber
  • Staying hydrated and active
References:
  1. NHS: Constipation
  2. Mayo Clinic: Constipation

Coronary Heart Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Coronary heart disease occurs when the coronary arteries narrow or become blocked, leading to heart problems. Learn about its causes and treatment options.

**Coronary Heart Disease (CHD)** is characterized by the buildup of plaque in the coronary arteries, reducing blood flow to the heart. Causes:

  • Atherosclerosis due to high cholesterol and blood pressure
  • Smoking and sedentary lifestyle
  • Diabetes and obesity
Symptoms:
  • Chest pain or discomfort (angina)
  • Shortness of breath and fatigue
  • Heart palpitations and irregular heartbeat
  • Risk of heart attack
Diagnosis:
  • Electrocardiogram (ECG) and stress testing
  • Coronary angiography and blood tests
Treatment:
  • Lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise, smoking cessation)
  • Medications to lower cholesterol and blood pressure
  • Surgical interventions such as angioplasty or bypass surgery
Prevention:
  • Regular exercise and a heart-healthy diet
  • Managing stress and regular health screenings
References:
  1. NHS: Coronary Heart Disease
  2. American Heart Association: Coronary Heart Disease

Coronavirus (COVID-19): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

COVID-19 is a viral respiratory illness caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Learn about its transmission, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Coronavirus (COVID-19)** is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which spreads primarily through respiratory droplets and contact with contaminated surfaces. Causes:

  • Transmission through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks
  • Contact with contaminated surfaces and subsequent touching of the face
Symptoms:
  • Fever, cough, and shortness of breath
  • Loss of taste or smell, fatigue, and body aches
  • Sore throat and congestion
Diagnosis:
  • PCR and rapid antigen tests
  • Clinical evaluation based on symptoms
Treatment:
  • Supportive care including rest and hydration
  • Antiviral medications and oxygen therapy for severe cases
  • Vaccination to prevent infection
Prevention:
  • Wearing masks and social distancing
  • Hand hygiene and vaccination
References:
  1. NHS: Coronavirus (COVID-19)
  2. CDC: COVID-19

Coronavirus (COVID-19): Longer-term Effects (Long COVID) – Causes, Symptoms & Management

Long COVID refers to persistent symptoms experienced weeks or months after the initial COVID-19 infection. Explore its common manifestations and management strategies.

**Long COVID** describes a range of symptoms that continue or develop after the acute phase of COVID-19 has resolved. Causes:

  • Post-viral inflammatory responses
  • Immune system dysregulation following infection
Symptoms:
  • Chronic fatigue, brain fog, and shortness of breath
  • Joint pain, chest pain, and muscle aches
  • Difficulty concentrating and sleep disturbances
Diagnosis:
  • Medical history review and symptom evaluation
  • Ruling out other conditions with blood tests and imaging if necessary
Management:
  • Multidisciplinary rehabilitation programs
  • Symptom-targeted treatments including pain management and respiratory therapy
  • Ongoing monitoring and supportive care
Prevention:
  • COVID-19 vaccination and booster doses
  • Early treatment during the acute phase of infection
References:
  1. NHS: Long COVID
  2. CDC: Long-term Effects of COVID-19

Costochondritis: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Costochondritis is an inflammation of the cartilage connecting a rib to the sternum, causing chest pain. Learn about its causes and treatment options.

**Costochondritis** is characterized by inflammation of the costal cartilage, leading to chest wall pain. Causes:

  • Repetitive physical strain or overuse
  • Chest trauma or injury
  • Viral infections or inflammatory conditions
Symptoms:
  • Sharp or aching chest pain, often worsened by movement or deep breathing
  • Tenderness when pressing on the affected area
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and physical examination
  • Exclusion of cardiac causes through diagnostic tests
Treatment:
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Rest and application of heat or cold packs
  • Physical therapy and stretching exercises
Prevention:
  • Avoiding repetitive chest strain and injury
  • Proper warm-up before physical activity
References:
  1. NHS: Costochondritis
  2. Mayo Clinic: Costochondritis

Cough: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A cough is a reflex to clear the airways. It may be acute or chronic and can have multiple causes. Learn more about its management.

**Cough** is a common reflex action that helps clear mucus and irritants from the respiratory tract. Causes:

  • Respiratory infections (e.g., common cold, influenza, pneumonia)
  • Allergies and asthma
  • Exposure to irritants such as smoke or pollution
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
Symptoms:
  • Dry or productive cough
  • Chest discomfort and throat irritation
  • Sputum production in some cases
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and medical history
  • Chest X-ray or spirometry if chronic
Treatment:
  • Cough suppressants or expectorants depending on the type
  • Hydration and rest
  • Addressing underlying causes such as infections or allergies
Prevention:
  • Hand hygiene and avoiding irritants
  • Managing allergies and asthma effectively
References:
  1. NHS: Cough
  2. CDC: Flu Symptoms & Cough

Crohn’s Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting the gastrointestinal tract. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatment strategies.

**Crohn’s Disease** is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, leading to a variety of symptoms. Causes:

  • Exact cause unknown – believed to be a combination of genetic, environmental, and immune factors
  • Immune system attacks healthy gut tissue, causing chronic inflammation
Symptoms:
  • Abdominal pain and cramping
  • Diarrhea and sometimes bloody stools
  • Weight loss and fatigue
  • Fever and reduced appetite
Diagnosis:
  • Colonoscopy and endoscopy with biopsy
  • Imaging tests such as CT or MRI scans
  • Blood tests and stool studies
Treatment:
  • Anti-inflammatory medications and immunosuppressants
  • Biologic therapies targeting specific inflammatory pathways
  • Nutritional support and sometimes surgery for complications
Management:
  • Lifestyle modifications and dietary adjustments
  • Regular monitoring and follow-up with healthcare providers
References:
  1. NHS: Crohn’s Disease
  2. Crohn’s & Colitis Foundation

Croup: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Croup is a common respiratory condition in children characterized by a barking cough and noisy breathing.

**Croup** is an inflammation of the upper airway (larynx and trachea), primarily affecting young children. It is usually caused by viral infections. Causes:

  • Viral infections, especially parainfluenza viruses
  • Exposure to respiratory viruses in crowded settings
Symptoms:
  • Barking, seal-like cough
  • Hoarseness and noisy breathing (stridor)
  • Fever and, in severe cases, difficulty breathing
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation based on symptoms
  • Occasionally, a neck X-ray to assess airway narrowing
Treatment:
  • Humidified air or steam therapy
  • Corticosteroids to reduce airway inflammation
  • Nebulized epinephrine for severe cases
Prevention:
  • Good hand hygiene and avoiding exposure to sick individuals
  • Vaccination against influenza to reduce respiratory infections
References:
  1. NHS: Croup
  2. CDC: Croup

Cystic Fibrosis: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system, leading to persistent infections and nutritional challenges.

**Cystic Fibrosis (CF)** is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, resulting in thick, sticky mucus that obstructs the lungs and impairs digestion. Causes:

  • Inherited mutations in the CFTR gene
  • Abnormal chloride and sodium transport across cell membranes
Symptoms:
  • Chronic lung infections and persistent cough
  • Difficulty breathing and wheezing
  • Poor growth and malabsorption leading to nutritional deficiencies
  • Digestive problems and frequent greasy, bulky stools
Diagnosis:
  • Newborn screening and sweat chloride tests
  • Genetic testing for CFTR mutations
Treatment:
  • Airway clearance techniques and inhaled medications
  • Pancreatic enzyme supplements and nutritional support
  • Antibiotics to manage lung infections
  • CFTR modulators in eligible patients
Management:
  • Regular monitoring with a multidisciplinary healthcare team
  • Advanced therapies, including lung transplant in severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Cystic Fibrosis
  2. Cystic Fibrosis Foundation

Cystitis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Cystitis is an inflammation of the bladder, most often caused by a bacterial infection, resulting in discomfort and urinary symptoms.

**Cystitis** is an inflammation of the bladder, commonly resulting from a bacterial infection, particularly by E. coli. Causes:

  • Bacterial infection, most often E. coli
  • Sexual activity and poor personal hygiene
  • Certain irritants or medications
Symptoms:
  • Frequent and urgent need to urinate
  • Burning sensation during urination
  • Cloudy or strong-smelling urine
  • Lower abdominal pain or pressure
Diagnosis:
  • Urine analysis and culture
  • Clinical evaluation of symptoms
Treatment:
  • Antibiotics to clear the infection
  • Increased fluid intake and pain relievers
  • Preventative measures for recurrent infections
Prevention:
  • Proper personal hygiene and urinating after sexual intercourse
  • Staying well-hydrated
References:
  1. NHS: Urinary Tract Infection (Cystitis)
  2. CDC: Urinary Tract Infections

Deafblindness: Causes, Challenges & Support

Deafblindness is a dual sensory impairment affecting both hearing and vision, presenting unique communication challenges.

**Deafblindness** is a condition characterized by a combined loss of hearing and vision. It can be present from birth (congenital) or acquired later in life. Causes:

  • Genetic conditions or congenital disabilities
  • Acquired conditions such as infections, injuries, or age-related degeneration
Challenges & Symptoms:
  • Difficulty in communication and accessing visual and auditory information
  • Social isolation and challenges in mobility
  • Impaired sensory processing leading to cognitive overload
Diagnosis & Support:
  • Comprehensive assessments by audiologists, ophthalmologists, and specialized educators
  • Multidisciplinary evaluations to tailor communication and mobility strategies
Management & Support:
  • Assistive technologies such as hearing aids, Braille devices, and tactile communication tools
  • Specialized education programs and support networks
  • Counseling and social services to promote independence and integration
References:
  1. NIDCD: Deaf-Blindness
  2. WHO: Visual and Hearing Impairment

Deep Vein Thrombosis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is the formation of blood clots in deep veins—often in the legs—which can lead to serious complications if left untreated.

**Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)** is a condition where blood clots form in the deep veins, typically in the legs. If a clot dislodges, it can travel to the lungs causing a pulmonary embolism. Causes:

  • Prolonged immobility (e.g., long flights, bed rest)
  • Recent surgery or injury
  • Medical conditions that increase blood clotting risk (e.g., certain cancers, genetic clotting disorders)
Symptoms:
  • Swelling, pain, and tenderness in the affected leg
  • Red or discolored skin and warmth in the area
Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound imaging
  • D-dimer blood tests
  • Venography in complex cases
Treatment:
  • Anticoagulant medications to prevent clot enlargement
  • Compression stockings and increased mobility
  • Surgical or catheter-based interventions for severe cases
Prevention:
  • Regular movement and hydration during long periods of inactivity
  • Prophylactic anticoagulation for high-risk individuals
References:
  1. NHS: Deep Vein Thrombosis
  2. CDC: DVT

Degenerative Cervical Myelopathy: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) is a progressive condition caused by age-related changes in the cervical spine that compress the spinal cord.

**Degenerative Cervical Myelopathy (DCM)** is a condition where degenerative changes in the cervical spine—such as disc degeneration, osteoarthritis, and ligament thickening—lead to compression of the spinal cord. Causes:

  • Age-related wear and tear of spinal discs and joints
  • Osteoarthritis and spinal stenosis
  • Herniated discs pressing on the spinal cord
Symptoms:
  • Numbness, weakness, and loss of coordination in the arms and legs
  • Neck pain and stiffness
  • Difficulty with fine motor skills and balance
Diagnosis:
  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine
  • Neurological examination and clinical assessment
  • X-rays or CT scans as supplementary tests
Treatment:
  • Physical therapy and medications for pain relief
  • Surgical decompression in advanced cases
  • Rehabilitation programs to improve function and mobility
Management:
  • Regular monitoring and lifestyle adjustments
  • Adaptive strategies to manage daily activities
References:
  1. NHS: Degenerative Cervical Myelopathy
  2. Spine Health: Degenerative Cervical Myelopathy

Dehydration: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Dehydration occurs when the body loses more fluids than it takes in, leading to impaired bodily functions. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatment.

**Dehydration** is a condition in which the body does not have enough fluids to function optimally. Causes:

  • Insufficient fluid intake
  • Excessive sweating, vomiting, or diarrhea
  • High environmental temperatures and strenuous physical activity
Symptoms:
  • Thirst and dry mouth
  • Dizziness, fatigue, and decreased urine output
  • Confusion and rapid heartbeat in severe cases
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Blood tests to assess electrolyte levels and kidney function
Treatment:
  • Rehydration with oral fluids or IV fluids in severe cases
  • Addressing the underlying cause (e.g., treating diarrhea or heat exposure)
Prevention:
  • Regular fluid intake, especially during hot weather or physical exertion
  • Monitoring for early signs of dehydration
References:
  1. NHS: Dehydration
  2. CDC: Hydration and Nutrition

Delirium: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Delirium is an acute, fluctuating confusional state marked by inattention and disorganized thinking. Learn about its triggers and care.

**Delirium** is an acute disturbance in mental abilities that results in confused thinking and reduced awareness of the environment. Causes:

  • Infections such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections
  • Medications or drug withdrawal
  • Metabolic imbalances and electrolyte disturbances
  • Trauma, surgery, or severe illness
Symptoms:
  • Sudden confusion and disorientation
  • Difficulty focusing and maintaining attention
  • Fluctuating levels of consciousness
  • Agitation or lethargy
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and cognitive testing
  • Laboratory tests to identify underlying causes
  • Neuroimaging if needed
Treatment:
  • Treating the underlying cause
  • Supportive care and ensuring a safe environment
  • Medications to manage agitation if necessary
References:
  1. NHS: Delirium
  2. CDC: Delirium

Dementia: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Dementia is a progressive decline in cognitive function affecting memory, thinking, and behavior. Explore its causes and management strategies.

**Dementia** is an umbrella term for conditions characterized by a decline in memory and other cognitive abilities, with Alzheimer’s disease being the most common form. Causes:

  • Alzheimer’s disease and other neurodegenerative disorders
  • Cerebrovascular disease
  • Genetic and environmental factors
Symptoms:
  • Memory loss and confusion
  • Difficulty performing familiar tasks
  • Impaired reasoning and language skills
  • Behavioral and mood changes
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and cognitive assessments
  • Neuroimaging (MRI or CT scans)
  • Blood tests to exclude other causes
Treatment & Management:
  • Medications to manage symptoms (e.g., cholinesterase inhibitors)
  • Cognitive therapies and structured routines
  • Support and education for caregivers
References:
  1. NHS: Dementia
  2. Alzheimer's Association

Dental Abscess: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A dental abscess is a painful infection at the root of a tooth or in the gum, often requiring prompt dental care.

**Dental Abscess** is a localized collection of pus caused by a bacterial infection in or around a tooth. Causes:

  • Untreated dental decay and cavities
  • Gum disease (periodontitis)
  • Injury or trauma to the tooth
Symptoms:
  • Severe toothache and sensitivity
  • Swelling of the gums and face
  • Fever and a bad taste in the mouth
Diagnosis:
  • Dental examination and X-rays
  • Evaluation of the affected area by a dentist
Treatment:
  • Drainage of the abscess and root canal treatment
  • Antibiotics to clear the infection
  • Pain management with analgesics
References:
  1. NHS: Dental Abscess
  2. American Dental Association: Dental Abscess

Depression: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Depression is a mood disorder characterized by persistent sadness and a loss of interest in life. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Depression** is a common but serious mental health disorder that affects how you feel, think, and handle daily activities. Causes:

  • Genetic, biological, environmental, and psychological factors
  • Imbalances in brain neurotransmitters
  • Chronic stress and traumatic life events
Symptoms:
  • Persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and irritability
  • Loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities
  • Changes in sleep, appetite, and energy levels
  • Difficulty concentrating and making decisions
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and psychiatric assessment
  • Screening tools such as the PHQ-9 questionnaire
Treatment:
  • Psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive-behavioral therapy)
  • Antidepressant medications
  • Lifestyle changes and support groups
References:
  1. NHS: Depression
  2. Mayo Clinic: Depression

Dermatitis Herpetiformis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely itchy skin condition closely linked to gluten sensitivity and celiac disease.

**Dermatitis Herpetiformis** is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by clusters of small, itchy, red bumps and blisters, typically on the elbows, knees, buttocks, and back. Causes:

  • Gluten sensitivity and celiac disease
  • Genetic predisposition
Symptoms:
  • Intense itching and burning sensation
  • Clusters of red bumps and blisters
  • Crusting and scaling of the affected skin
Diagnosis:
  • Skin biopsy with direct immunofluorescence
  • Blood tests for gluten-related antibodies
Treatment:
  • Adoption of a strict gluten-free diet
  • Medications such as dapsone to reduce symptoms
  • Topical treatments for skin care
References:
  1. NHS: Celiac Disease (linked to dermatitis herpetiformis)
  2. Celiac Disease Foundation

Diabetic Retinopathy: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes that damages the blood vessels of the retina, potentially leading to vision loss.

**Diabetic Retinopathy** is a diabetes-related eye disease caused by damage to the retinal blood vessels due to chronic high blood sugar. Causes:

  • Long-term high blood glucose levels
  • Hypertension and other cardiovascular risk factors
Symptoms:
  • Blurred vision and floaters
  • Dark spots or areas of vision loss
  • Gradual loss of vision in advanced stages
Diagnosis:
  • Dilated eye examinations and retinal imaging
  • Fluorescein angiography and optical coherence tomography (OCT)
Treatment:
  • Laser therapy and intravitreal injections
  • Strict blood sugar and blood pressure control
  • Vitrectomy in severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Diabetic Retinopathy
  2. American Academy of Ophthalmology: Diabetic Retinopathy

Diarrhoea: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Diarrhoea is characterized by frequent loose or watery stools and can result from infections, food intolerances, or other digestive disorders.

**Diarrhoea** is a common condition marked by frequent, watery bowel movements. It can be acute or chronic, depending on the underlying cause. Causes:

  • Viral or bacterial infections (e.g., norovirus, E. coli)
  • Food poisoning and food intolerances
  • Inflammatory bowel diseases and malabsorption syndromes
Symptoms:
  • Loose or watery stools
  • Abdominal cramps and urgency
  • Dehydration and electrolyte imbalances
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Stool tests and, if necessary, blood tests
Treatment:
  • Rehydration with fluids and electrolytes
  • Over-the-counter anti-diarrhoeal medications (when appropriate)
  • Treatment of underlying infections or conditions
Prevention:
  • Proper hand hygiene and safe food practices
  • Staying well-hydrated and avoiding contaminated water
References:
  1. NHS: Diarrhoea
  2. CDC: Diarrhoeal Diseases

Discoid Eczema: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Also known as nummular eczema, discoid eczema is a chronic skin condition characterized by coin-shaped, itchy, and inflamed patches.

**Discoid Eczema** (nummular eczema) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that presents as round, red, itchy patches which may ooze or become scaly. Causes:

  • Unknown, though often linked to dry skin and environmental triggers
  • Allergic reactions or irritants may contribute
Symptoms:
  • Circular, coin-shaped lesions on the skin
  • Itching, redness, and sometimes oozing or crusting
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation by a dermatologist
  • Skin biopsy in uncertain cases
Treatment:
  • Topical corticosteroids and moisturizers
  • Avoidance of known irritants and triggers
  • Antihistamines to reduce itching
Prevention:
  • Regular moisturizing and gentle skin care routines
  • Avoiding harsh chemicals and extreme temperatures
References:
  1. NHS: Nummular (Discoid) Eczema
  2. British Association of Dermatologists

Diverticular Disease & Diverticulitis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Diverticular disease involves small pouches in the colon wall, which can become inflamed or infected (diverticulitis), causing abdominal pain and digestive issues.

**Diverticular Disease** is the formation of small pouches (diverticula) in the colon wall. When these pouches become inflamed or infected, the condition is known as **diverticulitis**. Causes:

  • Low-fiber diet and poor bowel habits
  • Increased pressure within the colon, especially with aging
Symptoms:
  • Mild abdominal discomfort or cramping (diverticular disease)
  • Severe abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits during diverticulitis
  • Bloating and digestive disturbances
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Imaging tests such as CT scan or colonoscopy
Treatment:
  • High-fiber diet and lifestyle modifications for mild cases
  • Antibiotics and pain management for diverticulitis
  • Surgery in severe or recurrent cases
Prevention:
  • Increasing dietary fiber and staying hydrated
  • Regular physical activity to maintain bowel health
References:
  1. NHS: Diverticular Disease
  2. Against Colorectal Cancer

Dizziness (Lightheadedness): Causes, Symptoms & Management

Dizziness, often experienced as lightheadedness or imbalance, can stem from various underlying conditions. Learn more about its causes and management.

**Dizziness (Lightheadedness)** is a common symptom that may be caused by issues ranging from dehydration to inner ear disturbances. Causes:

  • Dehydration or low blood pressure
  • Inner ear problems (e.g., benign paroxysmal positional vertigo)
  • Side effects from medications
  • Anxiety or stress
Symptoms:
  • A sensation of unsteadiness or lightheadedness
  • Feeling faint or off-balance
  • Nausea and sometimes blurred vision
Diagnosis:
  • Medical history and physical examination
  • Blood pressure and balance tests
  • Additional investigations (e.g., hearing tests or imaging) when needed
Treatment:
  • Addressing the underlying cause (hydration, medication review, etc.)
  • Rest and gradual positional changes
  • Vestibular rehabilitation for inner ear issues
Prevention:
  • Staying well-hydrated and avoiding rapid position changes
  • Managing stress and following medical advice
References:
  1. NHS: Dizziness
  2. Mayo Clinic: Dizziness

Down’s Syndrome: Overview, Characteristics & Support

Down’s syndrome is a genetic condition caused by an extra copy of chromosome 21, leading to developmental differences. Learn about its characteristics and available support.

**Down’s Syndrome** is a genetic disorder that occurs when an individual has an extra copy of chromosome 21, affecting physical and intellectual development. Causes:

  • Non-disjunction during cell division resulting in trisomy 21
Characteristics:
  • Distinct facial features and developmental delays
  • Varying degrees of intellectual disability
  • Potential for congenital heart defects and other health concerns
Diagnosis:
  • Prenatal screening and diagnostic tests (e.g., amniocentesis)
  • Postnatal clinical evaluation
Management & Support:
  • Early intervention programs and specialized education
  • Regular health monitoring and therapies
  • Family and community support services
Prevention:
  • Genetic counseling for prospective parents
References:
  1. NHS: Down’s Syndrome
  2. Global Down Syndrome Foundation

Dry Mouth: Causes, Symptoms & Relief

Dry mouth, or xerostomia, occurs when salivary glands don’t produce enough saliva. Discover its causes, symptoms, and ways to find relief.

**Dry Mouth (Xerostomia)** is a condition characterized by a lack of sufficient saliva, which can lead to discomfort and oral health issues. Causes:

  • Side effects of medications and dehydration
  • Underlying medical conditions such as diabetes or Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Radiation therapy to the head and neck
Symptoms:
  • A sticky, dry feeling in the mouth
  • Difficulty swallowing, speaking, or tasting
  • Increased risk of dental cavities and gum disease
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Examination of oral health
Treatment:
  • Increasing fluid intake and using saliva substitutes
  • Adjusting medications if possible
  • Maintaining good oral hygiene
Prevention:
  • Staying well-hydrated and managing underlying conditions
  • Regular dental check-ups
References:
  1. NHS: Dry Mouth
  2. Mayo Clinic: Dry Mouth

Dysphagia (Swallowing Problems): Causes, Symptoms & Management

Dysphagia is a swallowing disorder that can result from neurological, muscular, or structural issues. Discover its causes and management strategies.

**Dysphagia** refers to difficulty swallowing, which may be due to problems in the mouth, throat, or esophagus. Causes:

  • Neurological disorders (e.g., stroke, Parkinson’s disease)
  • Structural abnormalities or obstructions
  • Muscle disorders or injuries
Symptoms:
  • Pain or difficulty when swallowing
  • Coughing or choking during meals
  • Unintended weight loss and dehydration
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and swallowing studies
  • Imaging tests such as a barium swallow or endoscopy
Treatment:
  • Dietary modifications and swallowing therapy
  • Medications or surgery if an obstruction is present
Prevention:
  • Early management of neurological or structural issues
  • Prompt treatment of infections and injuries affecting the throat
References:
  1. NHS: Dysphagia
  2. Mayo Clinic: Dysphagia

Dystonia: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Dystonia is a neurological movement disorder characterized by involuntary muscle contractions that lead to twisting and abnormal postures.

**Dystonia** is a movement disorder in which involuntary muscle contractions cause repetitive or twisting movements and abnormal postures. Causes:

  • Often idiopathic, though it can be secondary to medications or brain injury
  • Genetic predisposition in some cases
Symptoms:
  • Involuntary muscle contractions leading to twisting movements
  • Abnormal postures and muscle pain
  • Difficulty performing coordinated movements
Diagnosis:
  • Neurological examination and clinical history
  • Additional tests such as EMG or genetic testing as needed
Treatment:
  • Medications such as anticholinergics and muscle relaxants
  • Botulinum toxin injections to reduce muscle contractions
  • Physical and occupational therapy
  • Deep brain stimulation for refractory cases
Management:
  • Ongoing care with a neurologist and rehabilitation specialists
References:
  1. NHS: Dystonia
  2. Mayo Clinic: Dystonia

Earache: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Earache is a common condition that often results from ear infections or other underlying issues.

**Earache** is typically a result of inflammation or infection within the ear. Causes:

  • Middle ear infections (otitis media)
  • Outer ear infections (otitis externa)
  • Earwax impaction
  • Trauma or injury to the ear
  • Sinus infections or changes in altitude
Symptoms:
  • Sharp or dull ear pain
  • Hearing difficulties
  • Fluid drainage in case of infection
  • Fever and general malaise (if infection is present)
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination with an otoscope
  • Review of medical history and symptoms
Treatment:
  • Pain relief with over-the-counter analgesics
  • Warm compresses and rest
  • Antibiotics for bacterial infections
  • Professional ear cleaning for wax impaction
Prevention:
  • Maintain good ear hygiene
  • Avoid inserting objects (like cotton swabs) into the ear
  • Protect ears from water and extreme temperatures
References:
  1. NHS: Ear Infections
  2. Mayo Clinic: Ear Pain

Early Miscarriage: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Early miscarriage, occurring in the first trimester, is a common complication often due to chromosomal abnormalities.

**Early Miscarriage** refers to the loss of a pregnancy during the first 12 weeks. It is most commonly due to chromosomal abnormalities, though other factors may contribute. Causes:

  • Chromosomal abnormalities in the embryo
  • Hormonal imbalances
  • Maternal health issues or infections
Symptoms:
  • Vaginal bleeding and cramping
  • Passage of tissue or clots
  • Abdominal pain of varying intensity
Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound examinations
  • Blood tests to assess hCG levels
  • Clinical evaluation by a healthcare provider
Management:
  • Expectant management for natural resolution
  • Medical management if necessary (e.g., with misoprostol)
  • Surgical intervention for incomplete miscarriage
  • Counseling and emotional support
Prevention:
  • Regular prenatal care and monitoring
  • Managing chronic health conditions prior to conception
References:
  1. NHS: Miscarriage
  2. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists

Earwax Build-Up: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Earwax build-up can cause discomfort and hearing difficulties if not managed properly.

**Earwax Build-Up** occurs when excessive cerumen accumulates in the ear canal, potentially leading to blockage and discomfort. Causes:

  • Overproduction of earwax
  • Improper cleaning methods (e.g., cotton swabs pushing wax deeper)
  • Natural anatomical variations
Symptoms:
  • Sensation of fullness or blockage in the ear
  • Decreased hearing or ear pain
  • Tinnitus (ringing in the ear)
Diagnosis:
  • Visual examination with an otoscope
  • Assessment of hearing if blockage is suspected
Treatment:
  • Ear drops to soften the wax
  • Ear irrigation or manual removal by a healthcare professional
Prevention:
  • Avoid using cotton swabs deep in the ear
  • Maintain proper ear hygiene
References:
  1. NHS: Earwax
  2. Mayo Clinic: Earwax Blockage

Ebola Virus Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Ebola virus disease is a severe and often fatal hemorrhagic fever caused by the Ebola virus.

**Ebola Virus Disease (EVD)** is a life-threatening illness caused by the Ebola virus, transmitted through direct contact with infected bodily fluids. Causes:

  • Infection with the Ebola virus
  • Transmission via contact with blood or bodily fluids of infected individuals or animals
Symptoms:
  • Fever, severe headache, and muscle pain
  • Vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain
  • Bleeding and bruising in later stages
Diagnosis:
  • Laboratory tests such as PCR and ELISA
  • Clinical evaluation based on exposure history and symptoms
Treatment:
  • Supportive care with fluids and electrolyte management
  • Experimental antiviral therapies and immunotherapies
  • Strict isolation and infection control measures
Prevention:
  • Vaccination and use of personal protective equipment (PPE)
  • Adherence to strict infection control protocols
References:
  1. WHO: Ebola Virus Disease
  2. CDC: Ebola Virus Disease

Ectopic Pregnancy: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, most commonly in a fallopian tube, posing serious health risks.

**Ectopic Pregnancy** is a condition where the fertilized egg implants outside the uterine cavity—most often in a fallopian tube—leading to potential life-threatening complications. Causes:

  • Damage or blockage in the fallopian tubes (due to infections, surgery, or previous ectopic pregnancies)
  • Risk factors such as smoking and advanced maternal age
Symptoms:
  • Severe abdominal or pelvic pain
  • Vaginal bleeding or spotting
  • Dizziness or fainting due to internal bleeding
Diagnosis:
  • Transvaginal ultrasound to determine the location of the pregnancy
  • Blood tests to measure hCG levels
  • Clinical evaluation by a healthcare provider
Treatment:
  • Medical management with methotrexate for early, unruptured cases
  • Surgical intervention (laparoscopy or laparotomy) for ruptured or advanced cases
Prevention:
  • Early prenatal care and prompt evaluation of risk factors
  • Managing conditions that may affect fallopian tube health
References:
  1. NHS: Ectopic Pregnancy
  2. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists

Elbow (Radial Head or Neck) Fracture: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Elbow fractures involving the radial head or neck commonly result from trauma, such as falls or sports injuries.

**Elbow (Radial Head or Neck) Fracture** is a break or crack in the bone around the elbow, often caused by a direct impact or fall. Causes:

  • Direct trauma from falls or collisions
  • Sports-related injuries
  • Accidents resulting in impact to the elbow
Symptoms:
  • Severe pain and swelling around the elbow
  • Bruising and limited range of motion
  • Deformity or tenderness at the fracture site
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination and patient history
  • X-rays and possibly CT scans for detailed assessment
Treatment:
  • Immobilization with a cast or splint
  • Surgical intervention for displaced or complex fractures
  • Physical therapy for rehabilitation
Prevention:
  • Using protective gear during high-risk activities
  • Implementing safety measures in sports and daily activities
References:
  1. NHS: Broken Bones
  2. AAOS: Elbow Fractures

Edwards’ Syndrome: Causes, Characteristics & Management

Edwards’ syndrome, or trisomy 18, is a severe genetic disorder caused by an extra copy of chromosome 18, leading to profound developmental challenges.

**Edwards’ Syndrome (Trisomy 18)** is a genetic condition resulting from an extra chromosome 18. It causes multiple congenital abnormalities and is associated with a high rate of infant mortality. Causes:

  • Non-disjunction during cell division leading to trisomy 18
  • Advanced maternal age may increase the risk
Characteristics:
  • Severe developmental delays and congenital heart defects
  • Distinctive facial features and growth retardation
  • High risk of complications in multiple organ systems
Diagnosis:
  • Prenatal screening (ultrasound, maternal blood tests)
  • Karyotyping or chromosomal microarray analysis
Management:
  • Supportive and palliative care
  • Early intervention programs and specialized support for families
  • Multidisciplinary care approach
References:
  1. NHS: Edwards’ Syndrome
  2. Global Down Syndrome & Trisomy Support Organizations

Endometriosis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Endometriosis is a chronic condition where tissue similar to the uterine lining grows outside the uterus, often causing severe pain and fertility issues.

**Endometriosis** is a disorder in which tissue resembling the endometrium grows outside the uterus, leading to inflammation, pain, and scarring. Causes:

  • Retrograde menstruation and genetic predisposition
  • Immune system dysfunction and hormonal imbalances
Symptoms:
  • Severe pelvic pain, especially during menstruation
  • Pain during intercourse and bowel movements
  • Infertility and heavy menstrual bleeding
Diagnosis:
  • Pelvic examination and ultrasound imaging
  • Laparoscopy for definitive diagnosis
Treatment:
  • Pain management with NSAIDs and hormonal therapies
  • Surgical removal of endometrial lesions in severe cases
  • Lifestyle modifications and supportive therapies
References:
  1. NHS: Endometriosis
  2. Endometriosis Foundation of America

Epilepsy: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures. Learn about its causes, symptoms, and available treatment options.

**Epilepsy** is a chronic brain disorder marked by recurrent, unprovoked seizures due to abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition and brain malformations
  • Head injuries, infections, or strokes
  • Sometimes, the cause remains unknown
Symptoms:
  • Recurrent seizures (varying in type and intensity)
  • Loss of consciousness or altered awareness
  • Confusion and temporary memory loss following a seizure
Diagnosis:
  • Electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring
  • Brain imaging (MRI or CT scans)
  • Neurological examination and medical history review
Treatment:
  • Antiepileptic medications tailored to the seizure type
  • Lifestyle adjustments and, in some cases, surgical interventions
  • Supportive care and seizure management education
References:
  1. NHS: Epilepsy
  2. Epilepsy Foundation

Erectile Dysfunction: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Erectile dysfunction (impotence) is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for sexual performance.

**Erectile Dysfunction (ED)** is a common condition affecting men, characterized by difficulty in achieving or sustaining an erection. Causes:

  • Vascular and neurological conditions, including atherosclerosis and diabetes
  • Psychological factors such as stress and anxiety
  • Medications and lifestyle factors (e.g., smoking, obesity)
Symptoms:
  • Inability to achieve or maintain an erection
  • Reduced sexual desire
  • Emotional distress and relationship difficulties
Diagnosis:
  • Medical history and physical examination
  • Blood tests to assess hormone levels and cardiovascular risk
Treatment:
  • Medications such as phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil)
  • Psychological counseling and lifestyle modifications
  • In some cases, vacuum devices or surgical interventions
References:
  1. NHS: Erectile Dysfunction
  2. American Urological Association

Escherichia coli (E. coli) O157: Causes, Symptoms & Prevention

E. coli O157 is a harmful strain of the bacterium Escherichia coli that can cause severe foodborne illness.

**Escherichia coli (E. coli) O157** is a pathogenic strain of E. coli bacteria known for causing serious gastrointestinal illness, including bloody diarrhea and, in severe cases, hemolytic uremic syndrome. Causes:

  • Consumption of contaminated food or water
  • Contact with infected animals or person-to-person transmission
Symptoms:
  • Severe stomach cramps and abdominal pain
  • Bloody diarrhea and vomiting
  • Fever and dehydration
Diagnosis:
  • Stool culture and laboratory tests to identify the bacterial strain
Treatment:
  • Supportive care with hydration and electrolyte management
  • Avoidance of antibiotics which may worsen complications
Prevention:
  • Proper food handling, cooking, and hygiene practices
  • Avoiding unpasteurized dairy products and undercooked meats
References:
  1. NHS: Foodborne Illnesses
  2. CDC: E. coli Information

Ewing Sarcoma: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Ewing sarcoma is a rare cancer that primarily affects bones or soft tissues, typically in adolescents and young adults.

**Ewing Sarcoma** is an aggressive malignant tumor that most often arises in the long bones, pelvis, or soft tissues. It is driven by specific genetic mutations, most notably chromosomal translocations involving the EWS gene. Causes:

  • Genetic mutations and chromosomal translocations (e.g., EWS-FLI1 fusion)
  • The exact environmental or lifestyle triggers remain unclear
Symptoms:
  • Localized pain and swelling at the tumor site
  • Fever and general malaise
  • Risk of pathological fractures in affected bones
Diagnosis:
  • Imaging studies (X-rays, MRI, CT scans) to identify lesions
  • Biopsy for histopathological and genetic analysis
Treatment:
  • Combination chemotherapy, surgery, and in some cases radiation therapy
  • Multidisciplinary management to improve long-term survival
References:
  1. American Cancer Society: Ewing Sarcoma
  2. NHS: Cancer Information

Eye Cancer: Types, Symptoms & Treatment

Eye cancer refers to malignancies that develop in various parts of the eye, with ocular melanoma being the most common in adults.

**Eye Cancer** encompasses a range of cancers affecting different parts of the eye. Ocular melanoma is the most common form in adults, while retinoblastoma is more common in children. Causes:

  • Genetic mutations and predispositions
  • Risk factors such as light eye color and UV exposure
Symptoms:
  • Visual disturbances like blurry vision or floaters
  • Pain, redness, or a visible mass in the eye
  • Loss of peripheral vision in advanced cases
Diagnosis:
  • Comprehensive eye examination and imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI)
  • Biopsy for histopathological confirmation when needed
Treatment:
  • Laser therapy, radiation, or surgical removal of the tumor
  • Targeted and immunotherapies in selected cases
References:
  1. American Academy of Ophthalmology: Eye Cancer
  2. NHS: Eye Cancer

Eating Disorders: Types, Causes & Treatment

Eating disorders are serious mental health conditions characterized by disordered eating behaviors and an unhealthy preoccupation with food and body image.

**Eating Disorders** include conditions such as anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, and binge eating disorder. These disorders affect both physical and psychological health. Causes:

  • Complex interplay of genetic, psychological, and environmental factors
  • Societal pressure and distorted body image
Symptoms:
  • Extreme preoccupation with body weight and shape
  • Irregular eating patterns and severe weight changes
  • Emotional distress, anxiety, and depression
  • Physical complications such as electrolyte imbalances
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and psychological assessments
  • Medical tests to monitor physical health
Treatment:
  • Psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive-behavioral therapy)
  • Nutritional counseling and medical supervision
  • Support groups and sometimes medications for associated conditions
References:
  1. NHS: Eating Disorders
  2. National Eating Disorders Association

Farting: Causes, Implications & Management

Farting, or flatulence, is the natural expulsion of gas from the digestive system. Learn about its causes and when to seek advice.

**Farting (Flatulence)** is the release of gas from the digestive tract via the rectum. While a normal bodily function, excessive flatulence can sometimes indicate digestive issues. Causes:

  • Swallowed air and the breakdown of undigested food
  • Consumption of high-fiber foods and carbonated drinks
  • Food intolerances or digestive disorders
Symptoms:
  • Audible gas release and potential odor
  • Bloating or mild abdominal discomfort
Diagnosis:
  • Typically based on clinical history and dietary review
  • Further tests if associated with other gastrointestinal symptoms
Treatment & Management:
  • Dietary modifications to reduce gas-producing foods
  • Over‑the‑counter remedies such as simethicone
  • Consulting a healthcare provider for persistent discomfort
Prevention:
  • Eat slowly and chew food thoroughly to reduce swallowed air
  • Avoid excessive intake of carbonated beverages
References:
