  1. NHS: Indigestion and Gas
  2. Mayo Clinic: Flatulence

Febrile Seizures: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Febrile seizures are convulsions triggered by a rapid rise in temperature in young children. Discover common causes and management strategies.

**Febrile Seizures** occur in young children (typically between 6 months and 5 years) when a high fever triggers brief convulsions. Causes:

  • High fever from viral or bacterial infections
  • Rapid spikes in body temperature
Symptoms:
  • Convulsions, muscle twitching, and brief loss of consciousness
  • Irritability and temporary confusion
Diagnosis:
  • Based on clinical history and observation of the seizure episode
  • Additional tests to rule out other conditions if necessary
Treatment:
  • Supportive care and management of the fever (e.g., antipyretics)
  • Close monitoring and follow-up with a pediatrician
Prevention:
  • Prompt fever management and keeping the child hydrated
  • Vaccinations to reduce infection risk
References:
  1. NHS: Febrile Seizures
  2. Mayo Clinic: Febrile Seizures

Globus: Causes & Management of the Throat Sensation

Globus is the sensation of a lump in the throat with no physical obstruction. Understand its causes and effective management.

**Globus Sensation** is the persistent feeling that something is stuck in the throat despite no physical blockage being present. It is often related to reflux or stress. Causes:

  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
  • Stress and anxiety causing muscle tension
  • Postnasal drip and minor throat inflammation
Symptoms:
  • Persistent lump-like sensation in the throat
  • No true difficulty swallowing
  • Occasional throat clearing
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Endoscopic examinations if other causes are suspected
Treatment & Management:
  • Managing reflux with dietary changes and medications
  • Stress reduction techniques and counseling
  • Voice therapy to relax throat muscles
References:
  1. NHS: Globus Sensation
  2. Mayo Clinic: Globus Sensation

Fever in Adults: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Fever in adults is a common sign of infection or inflammation. Learn about its causes, when to seek help, and management strategies.

**Fever in Adults** is defined as an elevated body temperature, often reflecting an underlying infection or inflammatory process. Causes:

  • Bacterial, viral, or fungal infections
  • Inflammatory or autoimmune conditions
  • Heat-related illnesses or medication side effects
Symptoms:
  • Raised body temperature with chills
  • Muscle aches, headache, and fatigue
  • Sometimes sweating and dehydration
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and temperature measurement
  • Laboratory tests and imaging as needed to identify the cause
Treatment:
  • Antipyretics (e.g., acetaminophen or ibuprofen)
  • Management of the underlying condition
  • Hydration and rest
Prevention:
  • Good hygiene and vaccination to prevent infections
  • Timely management of chronic conditions
References:
  1. NHS: Fever in Adults
  2. Mayo Clinic: Fever

Fever in Children: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Fever is a common response in children to infections. Learn about its causes, when to seek medical help, and appropriate management.

**Fever in Children** is an elevated body temperature that often signals an underlying infection. It is one of the most frequent reasons for pediatric consultations. Causes:

  • Viral infections such as colds and influenza
  • Bacterial infections like ear or throat infections
  • Other inflammatory or immune conditions
Symptoms:
  • High temperature with shivering and irritability
  • Lethargy, poor appetite, and sometimes vomiting
Diagnosis:
  • Temperature measurement and clinical assessment
  • Additional tests if symptoms persist or worsen
Treatment:
  • Antipyretics (e.g., acetaminophen or ibuprofen) as advised
  • Ensuring adequate fluid intake and rest
  • Monitoring for signs of serious illness
Prevention:
  • Maintaining good hygiene and vaccination as per guidelines
  • Prompt medical attention for concerning symptoms
References:
  1. NHS: Fever in Children
  2. CDC: Fever in Children

Fibroids: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Fibroids are non-cancerous growths in the uterus that may cause heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain.

**Fibroids** are benign tumors that develop within the muscular wall of the uterus. Causes:

  • Hormonal imbalances (especially estrogen)
  • Genetic factors
  • Family history of fibroids
Symptoms:
  • Heavy menstrual bleeding and prolonged periods
  • Pain or pressure in the pelvic area
  • Frequent urination and back pain
Diagnosis:
  • Pelvic ultrasound or MRI
  • Clinical examination and medical history
Treatment:
  • Medication to regulate hormones
  • Surgical options (myomectomy or hysterectomy) for severe cases
  • Minimally invasive procedures such as uterine artery embolization
Prevention:
  • Maintaining a balanced diet and regular exercise
  • Regular medical check-ups
References:
  1. NHS: Uterine Fibroids
  2. ACOG: Uterine Fibroids

Fibromyalgia: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Fibromyalgia is a chronic disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain and fatigue.

**Fibromyalgia** is a long-term condition marked by widespread pain, fatigue, and tenderness in the muscles and soft tissues. Causes:

  • Abnormal pain processing in the central nervous system
  • Genetic predisposition
  • Stress and physical trauma
Symptoms:
  • Widespread muscle pain and stiffness
  • Fatigue and sleep disturbances
  • Cognitive difficulties ("fibro fog")
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Exclusion of other similar conditions
Treatment:
  • Medications such as pain relievers, antidepressants, or anticonvulsants
  • Physical therapy and exercise programs
  • Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
Management:
  • Lifestyle modifications and stress reduction techniques
  • Regular exercise and proper sleep hygiene
References:
  1. NHS: Fibromyalgia
  2. Mayo Clinic: Fibromyalgia

Flu: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

The flu is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses, leading to fever, cough, and body aches.

**Flu (Influenza)** is a viral infection that attacks the respiratory system, spreading easily from person to person. Causes:

  • Infection with influenza viruses
  • Transmission via respiratory droplets
Symptoms:
  • High fever, chills, and body aches
  • Cough, sore throat, and congestion
  • Fatigue and headache
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and rapid influenza diagnostic tests (RIDTs)
Treatment:
  • Rest, fluids, and over-the-counter medications
  • Antiviral drugs for severe cases
Prevention:
  • Annual flu vaccination and proper hygiene practices
  • Avoiding close contact with infected individuals
References:
  1. NHS: Flu
  2. CDC: Influenza

Foetal Alcohol Syndrome: Causes, Effects & Prevention

Foetal alcohol syndrome is a condition resulting from alcohol exposure during pregnancy, leading to lifelong developmental issues.

**Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS)** is a serious condition in which alcohol consumption during pregnancy affects the developing fetus, leading to physical, behavioral, and cognitive abnormalities. Causes:

  • Maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy
  • Lack of awareness or support regarding alcohol’s risks
Effects:
  • Growth deficiencies and facial abnormalities
  • Cognitive impairments and behavioral issues
  • Organ malformations and lifelong health challenges
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and developmental assessments
  • Review of maternal alcohol exposure history
Treatment & Prevention:
  • No cure exists; focus is on supportive therapies and educational interventions
  • Prevention through abstinence from alcohol during pregnancy and public health education
References:
  1. NHS: Foetal Alcohol Syndrome
  2. CDC: FASD

Food Allergy: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Food allergies occur when the immune system overreacts to specific foods, potentially causing severe allergic reactions.

**Food Allergy** is an adverse immune response triggered by specific proteins in foods. Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition and environmental factors
  • Immune system hypersensitivity to certain food proteins
Symptoms:
  • Hives, swelling, and difficulty breathing
  • Gastrointestinal discomfort and, in severe cases, anaphylaxis
Diagnosis:
  • Allergy testing (skin prick tests or blood tests)
  • Detailed dietary and symptom history
Treatment:
  • Avoidance of known allergens and emergency epinephrine for severe reactions
  • Antihistamines and corticosteroids to manage mild symptoms
Prevention:
  • Early exposure under medical supervision and proper food labeling
References:
  1. NHS: Food Allergy
  2. Food Allergy Research & Education (FARE)

Food Poisoning: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Food poisoning is an illness caused by consuming contaminated food or beverages, leading to gastrointestinal distress.

**Food Poisoning** is a condition resulting from ingesting harmful bacteria, viruses, or toxins present in contaminated food. Causes:

  • Consumption of contaminated or undercooked food
  • Poor food handling and storage practices
Symptoms:
  • Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain and cramps
  • Fever and dehydration in severe cases
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Stool tests to identify pathogens if necessary
Treatment:
  • Rehydration with fluids and electrolytes
  • Over-the-counter medications for symptom relief
  • Antibiotics in severe bacterial cases (under medical guidance)
Prevention:
  • Safe food handling, proper cooking, and storage
  • Regular handwashing and sanitation
References:
  1. NHS: Food Poisoning
  2. CDC: Foodborne Germs

Fragility Fracture of the Hip: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Fragility fractures of the hip are common in older adults, typically resulting from minimal trauma due to weakened bones.

**Fragility Fracture of the Hip** often occurs in individuals with osteoporosis when even a minor fall can lead to a break in the hip. Causes:

  • Osteoporosis and age-related bone loss
  • Falls or minor trauma
  • Weakening of the bone structure over time
Symptoms:
  • Severe hip pain and tenderness
  • Difficulty or inability to bear weight on the affected side
  • Swelling and bruising around the hip area
Diagnosis:
  • X-rays or CT scans to visualize the fracture
  • Bone density tests to assess osteoporosis
Treatment:
  • Surgical repair (e.g., hip replacement or fixation) for displaced fractures
  • Pain management and rehabilitation therapy
  • Osteoporosis treatment to prevent future fractures
Prevention:
  • Fall prevention strategies and home safety modifications
  • Regular weight-bearing exercise and adequate calcium/vitamin D intake
References:
  1. NHS: Hip Fracture
  2. Mayo Clinic: Hip Fracture

Frozen Shoulder: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Frozen shoulder, or adhesive capsulitis, is a condition causing stiffness and pain in the shoulder joint that limits movement.

**Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis)** is a condition characterized by progressive stiffness and pain in the shoulder, often developing over months. Causes:

  • Inflammation and thickening of the shoulder capsule
  • Injury, surgery, or prolonged immobilization
  • Underlying health conditions such as diabetes
Symptoms:
  • Pain and stiffness in the shoulder
  • Limited range of motion
  • Difficulty performing daily activities
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination and range-of-motion tests
  • Imaging (X-ray or MRI) to rule out other causes
Treatment:
  • Physical therapy and stretching exercises
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs)
  • Corticosteroid injections and, in rare cases, surgery
Prevention:
  • Early mobilization after shoulder injury or surgery
  • Regular stretching and maintaining shoulder flexibility
References:
  1. NHS: Frozen Shoulder
  2. Mayo Clinic: Frozen Shoulder

Functional Neurological Disorder (FND): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

FND is a condition where patients experience neurological symptoms without a clear structural cause, often linked to stress or trauma.

**Functional Neurological Disorder (FND)** is characterized by neurological symptoms—such as weakness, movement disorders, or sensory disturbances—that are not explained by structural neurological disease. Causes:

  • Complex interactions of psychological factors and stress
  • Abnormalities in brain function rather than structural damage
Symptoms:
  • Weakness, tremors, or abnormal movements
  • Sensory changes, including numbness or pain
  • Seizure-like episodes without epileptic activity
Diagnosis:
  • Detailed clinical evaluation and neurological examination
  • Exclusion of other neurological disorders through imaging and tests
Treatment:
  • Multidisciplinary approach including psychotherapy and physiotherapy
  • Stress management and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
Management:
  • Ongoing support and rehabilitation to improve quality of life
References:
  1. NHS: Functional Neurological Disorder
  2. FND Hope

Fungal Nail Infection: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Fungal nail infection (onychomycosis) is a common condition causing thick, discolored, and brittle nails.

**Fungal Nail Infection (Onychomycosis)** is an infection of the nail caused by fungi, leading to thickened, discolored, and crumbly nails. Causes:

  • Exposure to fungi in moist environments (e.g., communal showers)
  • Weak immune system or chronic conditions like diabetes
Symptoms:
  • Thickened, yellow, or white nails
  • Brittle and crumbly nail edges
  • Discomfort or pain when pressure is applied
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and nail clipping analysis
  • Nail culture or microscopy for fungal elements
Treatment:
  • Topical antifungal agents or oral antifungal medications
  • Maintaining proper nail hygiene and dryness
Prevention:
  • Avoiding prolonged exposure to moist environments
  • Wearing breathable footwear and maintaining good foot hygiene
References:
  1. NHS: Fungal Nail Infection
  2. American Academy of Dermatology

Gallbladder Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Gallbladder cancer is a rare malignancy affecting the gallbladder, often associated with gallstones and chronic inflammation.

**Gallbladder Cancer** develops in the gallbladder and is frequently linked to long-standing inflammation due to gallstones. Causes:

  • Chronic inflammation from gallstones
  • Genetic predispositions and environmental factors
Symptoms:
  • Abdominal pain and jaundice
  • Nausea, vomiting, and unexplained weight loss
  • Fever in advanced cases
Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound, CT, or MRI imaging
  • Biopsy for histopathological confirmation
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection for early-stage disease
  • Chemotherapy and radiation for advanced stages
  • Palliative care for symptom management
Prevention:
  • Maintain a healthy weight and balanced diet
  • Schedule regular check-ups to monitor gallbladder health
  • Manage gallstones or related conditions early
References:
  1. NHS: Gallbladder Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society: Gallbladder Cancer

Gallstones: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Gallstones are hardened deposits in the gallbladder that can cause severe abdominal pain and digestive issues.

**Gallstones** form when substances in bile crystallize in the gallbladder. Causes:

  • Excess cholesterol or bilirubin in bile
  • Obesity and rapid weight loss
  • Genetic predisposition
Symptoms:
  • Sudden, intense abdominal pain
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Jaundice in severe cases
Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound imaging of the gallbladder
  • Blood tests to assess liver function
Treatment:
  • Medication to dissolve small stones
  • Surgical removal of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy) for recurrent or severe cases
Prevention:
  • Maintain a healthy, balanced diet low in fats
  • Avoid rapid weight loss and manage obesity
  • Regular check-ups to monitor gallbladder health
References:
  1. NHS: Gallstones
  2. Mayo Clinic: Gallstones

Ganglion Cyst: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Ganglion cysts are non-cancerous, fluid-filled lumps that commonly develop on the wrist or hand.

**Ganglion Cyst** is a benign, fluid-filled sac that typically arises near joints or tendons, most often on the wrist. Causes:

  • Joint or tendon irritation
  • Degenerative changes or trauma
Symptoms:
  • Painless or mildly painful lump near a joint
  • Potential restriction in joint movement
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination and ultrasound imaging
Treatment:
  • Observation as many cysts resolve on their own
  • Needle aspiration or surgical removal if painful or persistent
Prevention:
  • Use proper ergonomic practices to reduce joint strain
  • Avoid repetitive motions that may irritate joints
References:
  1. NHS: Ganglion Cyst
  2. AAOS: Ganglion Cysts

Gastroenteritis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Gastroenteritis is an inflammation of the stomach and intestines, commonly caused by viral, bacterial, or parasitic infections.

**Gastroenteritis** is often referred to as the "stomach flu" and results in diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Causes:

  • Viral infections (e.g., norovirus, rotavirus)
  • Bacterial infections (e.g., E. coli, Salmonella)
  • Parasitic infections
Symptoms:
  • Diarrhea and vomiting
  • Abdominal cramps and fever
  • Dehydration and fatigue
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Stool tests if necessary
Treatment:
  • Rehydration with fluids and electrolytes
  • Over-the-counter medications for symptom relief
  • Antibiotics only if a bacterial cause is confirmed
Prevention:
  • Practice good hand hygiene
  • Ensure safe food and water consumption
  • Vaccination for rotavirus (for children) where applicable
References:
  1. NHS: Gastroenteritis
  2. CDC: Gastroenteritis

Gastro-oesophageal Reflux Disease (GORD): Causes, Symptoms & Management

GORD, commonly known as acid reflux, occurs when stomach acid flows back into the oesophagus, causing discomfort.

**Gastro-oesophageal Reflux Disease (GORD)** is a condition where the lower oesophageal sphincter fails to close properly, allowing acid to reflux into the oesophagus. Causes:

  • Weak or dysfunctional lower oesophageal sphincter
  • Obesity, pregnancy, and consumption of trigger foods (e.g., spicy or fatty foods)
Symptoms:
  • Heartburn and regurgitation
  • Chest pain and difficulty swallowing
  • Chronic cough and throat irritation
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Endoscopy, pH monitoring, or barium swallow tests
Treatment:
  • Lifestyle modifications such as weight loss and dietary changes
  • Medications (antacids, H2 blockers, or proton pump inhibitors)
  • Surgery in severe or refractory cases
Prevention:
  • Avoid trigger foods and large meals
  • Maintain a healthy weight
  • Avoid lying down immediately after eating
References:
  1. NHS: GORD
  2. Mayo Clinic: GERD

Genital Herpes: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Genital herpes is a common STI caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV), leading to painful sores in the genital area.

**Genital Herpes** is primarily caused by HSV-2 (and sometimes HSV-1) transmitted through sexual contact. Causes:

  • Direct contact with infected skin or active lesions
  • Transmission through sexual intercourse
Symptoms:
  • Painful blisters or ulcers in the genital area
  • Itching, burning, and flu-like symptoms during initial outbreak
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and swab testing (PCR or viral culture)
Treatment:
  • Antiviral medications (e.g., acyclovir) to reduce outbreak severity
  • Pain management and supportive care
Prevention:
  • Use protection during sexual activities
  • Regular STD screenings
  • Avoid sexual contact during outbreaks
References:
  1. NHS: Genital Herpes
  2. CDC: Genital Herpes

Genital Symptoms: Overview & When to Seek Help

Genital symptoms, including pain, discharge, or lesions, can indicate a range of conditions. Learn what these symptoms may signify.

**Genital Symptoms** can include itching, pain, abnormal discharge, or lesions in the genital area. These signs may indicate infections, inflammation, or other conditions. Causes:

  • Sexually transmitted infections (e.g., herpes, chlamydia)
  • Dermatological conditions and allergic reactions
  • Trauma or irritants
Common Symptoms:
  • Redness, swelling, or itching in the genital region
  • Abnormal discharge or sores
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and detailed patient history
  • Laboratory tests including swabs and blood tests
Treatment:
  • Targeted therapies depending on the underlying cause
  • Medications (antibiotics, antivirals, antifungals) as required
Prevention:
  • Practice safe sexual behaviors and use protection
  • Maintain proper personal hygiene
  • Schedule regular check-ups and screenings
References:
  1. NHS: STIs and Genital Infections
  2. CDC: Sexually Transmitted Diseases

Genital Warts: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Genital warts are benign growths caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) that can affect the genital area. Learn about their management.

**Genital Warts** are caused by certain strains of HPV, typically types 6 and 11, and manifest as small, skin-colored or gray growths on the genital region. Causes:

  • Infection with HPV, usually transmitted through sexual contact
Symptoms:
  • Painless, fleshy growths or bumps in the genital area
  • Itching or discomfort in some cases
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination by a healthcare provider
  • Acetic acid application and, if needed, biopsy
Treatment:
  • Topical medications, cryotherapy, or surgical removal
  • HPV vaccination to help prevent recurrence
Prevention:
  • Practice safe sex, including condom use
  • Get vaccinated against HPV
  • Regular health check-ups for early detection
References:
  1. NHS: Genital Warts
  2. CDC: HPV and Genital Warts

Germ Cell Tumours: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Germ cell tumours are cancers that originate from the reproductive cells (sperm or egg cells), typically found in the ovaries or testes.

**Germ Cell Tumours** often develop in the gonads (testes or ovaries) but can occasionally appear in other parts of the body. Causes:

  • Genetic factors and abnormal cell division
  • Undescended testicle (for testicular germ cell tumours)
Symptoms:
  • Painless lump or swelling in the gonads
  • Abdominal pain or bloating (ovarian)
  • Back pain or chest pain if spread occurs
Diagnosis:
  • Physical exam and imaging (ultrasound, CT scan)
  • Blood tests for tumour markers (e.g., AFP, hCG)
  • Biopsy for definitive diagnosis
Treatment:
  • Surgery to remove the tumour
  • Chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy
  • Follow-up monitoring of tumour markers
Prevention:
  • Regular self-examinations (testicular self-exams)
  • Early evaluation of any abnormal lumps or pain
  • Genetic counseling if there is a family history
References:
  1. NHS: Testicular Cancer
  2. National Cancer Institute: Germ Cell Tumours

Glandular Fever: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Glandular fever (infectious mononucleosis) is commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, leading to fatigue, fever, and swollen glands.

**Glandular Fever** is often referred to as the “kissing disease” because the virus can be transmitted via saliva. Causes:

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection
  • Close contact with infected saliva
Symptoms:
  • Severe fatigue and fever
  • Sore throat and swollen lymph nodes
  • Muscle aches and headaches
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination and blood tests (Monospot test)
  • Evaluation of white blood cell counts
Treatment:
  • Rest and hydration
  • Over-the-counter pain relievers
  • Monitoring for complications like splenic enlargement
Prevention:
  • Avoid sharing drinks or utensils with infected individuals
  • Practice good hygiene (regular handwashing)
  • Limit close contact when symptoms are present
References:
  1. NHS: Glandular Fever
  2. CDC: Epstein-Barr Virus

Golfer's Elbow: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Golfer's elbow is a form of tendinitis that causes pain on the inside of the elbow and forearm, often due to repetitive motions.

**Golfer's Elbow (Medial Epicondylitis)** affects the tendons that attach to the medial epicondyle of the elbow. Causes:

  • Repetitive wrist or arm movements
  • Overuse in sports like golf or tennis
Symptoms:
  • Pain or tenderness on the inner side of the elbow
  • Stiffness and weakness in the wrist or hand
Diagnosis:
  • Physical exam focusing on the elbow joint
  • Imaging (X-ray or MRI) if needed
Treatment:
  • Rest and ice application
  • Physical therapy and exercises
  • Anti-inflammatory medications
Prevention:
  • Warm up before activities
  • Use proper technique and equipment
  • Strengthen forearm and wrist muscles
References:
  1. NHS: Golfer's Elbow
  2. AAOS: Golfer's Elbow

Gonorrhoea: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Gonorrhoea is a common sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, often affecting the urethra, rectum, or throat.

**Gonorrhoea** can infect both men and women, leading to various complications if left untreated. Causes:

  • Unprotected sexual contact with an infected partner
Symptoms:
  • Painful urination and abnormal discharge
  • Pelvic pain in women; testicular pain in men
  • Throat infection if transmitted orally
Diagnosis:
  • Laboratory tests on urine or swabs
  • NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test)
Treatment:
  • Antibiotic regimen (often dual therapy)
  • Retesting to confirm cure
Prevention:
  • Consistent condom use
  • Regular STI screenings
  • Limit number of sexual partners
References:
  1. NHS: Gonorrhoea
  2. CDC: Gonorrhea

Gout: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Gout is a type of inflammatory arthritis caused by high levels of uric acid in the blood, leading to painful joint inflammation.

**Gout** commonly affects the big toe but can occur in other joints like ankles, knees, and wrists. Causes:

  • Excess uric acid production or reduced excretion
  • High-purine diets (red meat, alcohol)
Symptoms:
  • Sudden severe joint pain, often at night
  • Redness, swelling, and warmth over the affected joint
Diagnosis:
  • Joint fluid analysis for urate crystals
  • Blood tests for uric acid levels
Treatment:
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Colchicine or corticosteroids for acute attacks
  • Long-term uric acid-lowering therapy (allopurinol)
Prevention:
  • Limit high-purine foods (red meats, seafood) and alcohol
  • Maintain a healthy weight and stay hydrated
  • Regular check-ups to manage uric acid levels
References:
  1. NHS: Gout
  2. CDC: Gout

Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS) involves chronic pain on the outer side of the hip, often linked to tendon or bursa inflammation.

**Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome** can be caused by trochanteric bursitis or gluteal tendinopathy. Causes:

  • Overuse or repetitive stress on the hip
  • Direct trauma or injury to the hip region
Symptoms:
  • Persistent pain on the outer hip
  • Pain exacerbated by lying on the affected side
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical exam and palpation of the hip
  • Imaging (ultrasound or MRI) for tendon/bursa assessment
Treatment:
  • Physical therapy and targeted exercises
  • Anti-inflammatory medications or injections
  • Activity modification to reduce stress on the hip
Prevention:
  • Maintain hip strength and flexibility
  • Use proper technique when exercising
  • Gradually increase activity intensity
References:
  1. NHS: Hip Pain (Including GTPS)
  2. AAOS: OrthoInfo

Gum Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Gum disease (periodontal disease) involves infection and inflammation of the gums, which can lead to tooth loss if untreated.

**Gum Disease** ranges from gingivitis (mild inflammation) to periodontitis (severe gum infection affecting bone and ligaments). Causes:

  • Poor oral hygiene leading to plaque buildup
  • Smoking and certain medical conditions (e.g., diabetes)
Symptoms:
  • Red, swollen, or bleeding gums
  • Persistent bad breath
  • Loose teeth or receding gums
Diagnosis:
  • Dental examination and x-rays
  • Periodontal probing to assess gum health
Treatment:
  • Professional dental cleaning and scaling
  • Improved brushing and flossing habits
  • Antibiotics or surgery in advanced cases
Prevention:
  • Brush twice daily and floss regularly
  • Regular dental check-ups and cleanings
  • Avoid tobacco and maintain good overall health
References:
  1. NHS: Gum Disease
  2. Mayo Clinic: Periodontitis

Haemorrhoids (Piles): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Haemorrhoids (piles) are swollen veins in the lower rectum or anus that can cause discomfort, itching, and sometimes bleeding.

**Haemorrhoids (Piles)** are enlarged vascular structures that can develop internally or externally around the anus. Causes:

  • Straining during bowel movements
  • Chronic constipation or diarrhea
  • Increased abdominal pressure (e.g., pregnancy)
Symptoms:
  • Anal itching, pain, or discomfort
  • Bright red blood on toilet paper
  • Lumps or swelling around the anus
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination (visual or rectal exam)
  • Proctoscopy or colonoscopy if needed
Treatment:
  • High-fibre diet and increased fluid intake
  • Topical creams or suppositories
  • Rubber band ligation or surgery in severe cases
Prevention:
  • Avoid straining, treat constipation early
  • Maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle
  • Stay active and exercise regularly
References:
  1. NHS: Haemorrhoids
  2. Mayo Clinic: Hemorrhoids

Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A common viral infection in children, hand, foot and mouth disease causes sores in the mouth and rashes on hands and feet.

**Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease** is typically caused by Coxsackievirus A16, an enterovirus. It's highly contagious among young children. Causes:

  • Contact with contaminated surfaces or respiratory droplets
  • Exposure to fecal matter containing the virus
Symptoms:
  • Fever, sore throat
  • Painful mouth sores
  • Rash on hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination of sores and rash
  • Throat swab or stool sample if needed
Treatment:
  • Supportive care: rest, hydration, pain relief
  • Topical gels for mouth sores
  • Usually resolves on its own in 7–10 days
Prevention:
  • Frequent handwashing
  • Disinfect common surfaces and toys
  • Avoid close contact if infected
References:
  1. NHS: Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease
  2. CDC: Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease

Hay Fever (Allergic Rhinitis): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hay fever is an allergic reaction to pollen that causes sneezing, itchy eyes, and a runny nose, often seasonally.

**Hay Fever (Allergic Rhinitis)** occurs when your immune system overreacts to airborne allergens like pollen, dust mites, or pet dander. Causes:

  • Exposure to pollen from trees, grasses, or weeds
  • Allergies to dust mites or pet dander
Symptoms:
  • Sneezing, nasal congestion, runny nose
  • Itchy, watery eyes
  • Postnasal drip and sore throat
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Allergy skin prick tests or blood tests
Treatment:
  • Antihistamines and nasal corticosteroids
  • Eye drops for itchy eyes
  • Immunotherapy (allergy shots) for severe cases
Prevention:
  • Monitor pollen counts and keep windows closed
  • Use air filters and clean regularly
  • Shower and change clothes after outdoor exposure
References:
  1. NHS: Hay Fever
  2. ACAAI: Allergic Rhinitis

Head and Neck Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Head and neck cancers involve malignant tumors in the mouth, throat, or nasal passages, often linked to tobacco and alcohol use.

**Head and Neck Cancer** can affect the oral cavity, pharynx, larynx, sinuses, or salivary glands. Causes:

  • Tobacco use (smoking or chewing)
  • Excessive alcohol consumption
  • HPV infection in some cases
Symptoms:
  • Persistent sore throat or hoarseness
  • A lump in the neck or mouth
  • Difficulty swallowing or persistent mouth sores
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination and endoscopy
  • Imaging (CT, MRI, PET) and biopsy
Treatment:
  • Surgery, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy
  • Targeted therapy or immunotherapy in advanced cases
  • Rehabilitation (speech therapy) post-treatment
Prevention:
  • Avoid tobacco and limit alcohol
  • Get vaccinated against HPV
  • Regular dental and medical check-ups
References:
  1. NHS: Head and Neck Cancer
  2. Cancer Research UK: Head and Neck Cancer

Head Lice and Nits: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Head lice are tiny insects living on the scalp, while nits are their eggs attached to hair shafts, causing itching and irritation.

**Head Lice and Nits** are common among children, spreading easily through close contact. Causes:

  • Direct head-to-head contact
  • Sharing combs, hats, or pillows
Symptoms:
  • Intense scalp itching
  • Visible lice or white nits on hair shafts
Diagnosis:
  • Examination with a fine-toothed comb
  • Good lighting or magnification to spot nits
Treatment:
  • Over-the-counter lice shampoos or lotions
  • Prescription treatments if resistant
  • Frequent combing to remove nits
Prevention:
  • Avoid sharing personal items (combs, hats)
  • Regular checks in schools or childcare settings
  • Immediate treatment of infested individuals
References:
  1. NHS: Head Lice and Nits
  2. CDC: Head Lice

Headaches: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Headaches can range from tension headaches to migraines, often triggered by stress, dehydration, or underlying conditions.

**Headaches** may be primary (like migraines, tension-type) or secondary (due to other health issues). Causes:

  • Stress, tension, or poor posture
  • Dehydration or skipped meals
  • Underlying medical conditions (e.g., sinusitis)
Symptoms:
  • Dull or throbbing pain in head or neck
  • Sensitivity to light or sound (migraine)
  • Nausea or aura (migraine)
Diagnosis:
  • Patient history and physical exam
  • Imaging (MRI, CT) if red flags or severe cases
Treatment:
  • Over-the-counter pain relievers (NSAIDs, acetaminophen)
  • Prescription medications (triptans) for migraines
  • Relaxation techniques and lifestyle changes
Prevention:
  • Stay hydrated and manage stress
  • Identify and avoid headache triggers
  • Maintain regular sleep patterns
References:
  1. NHS: Headaches
  2. Mayo Clinic: Headaches

Hearing Loss: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hearing loss can be conductive, sensorineural, or mixed, affecting one or both ears and impacting the ability to perceive sounds clearly.

**Hearing Loss** may occur gradually with age (presbycusis) or suddenly due to injury or infection. Causes:

  • Age-related wear and tear of the inner ear
  • Exposure to loud noises (occupational or recreational)
  • Ear infections, trauma, or certain medications
Symptoms:
  • Difficulty understanding speech
  • Needing higher volume on electronic devices
  • Ringing in the ears (tinnitus)
Diagnosis:
  • Audiometry (hearing tests)
  • Physical exam of the ear
Treatment:
  • Hearing aids or assistive listening devices
  • Cochlear implants for severe cases
  • Medical or surgical treatment if due to infection or obstruction
Prevention:
  • Protect ears from loud noises (earplugs or earmuffs)
  • Regular hearing check-ups
  • Prompt treatment of ear infections
References:
  1. NHS: Hearing Loss
  2. WHO: Deafness and Hearing Loss

Heart Attack (Myocardial Infarction): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A heart attack happens when blood flow to the heart is blocked, damaging the heart muscle. It’s often caused by coronary artery disease.

**Heart Attack (Myocardial Infarction)** is typically due to a blockage in the coronary arteries, preventing oxygen-rich blood from reaching the heart muscle. Causes:

  • Atherosclerosis (plaque buildup)
  • Blood clot formation in the coronary arteries
Symptoms:
  • Chest pain or pressure (may radiate to arm, jaw, or back)
  • Shortness of breath, sweating, nausea
  • Feeling faint or dizzy
Diagnosis:
  • ECG (electrocardiogram)
  • Blood tests for cardiac enzymes (troponin)
  • Coronary angiography
Treatment:
  • Emergency medication (aspirin, clot busters)
  • Angioplasty and stent placement or bypass surgery
  • Cardiac rehabilitation
Prevention:
  • Healthy diet, regular exercise, and weight control
  • Manage blood pressure and cholesterol
  • Avoid smoking and limit alcohol
References:
  1. NHS: Heart Attack
  2. AHA: Heart Attack

Heart Block: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Heart block is a condition in which the electrical signals that control the heartbeat are partially or fully blocked, affecting the heart’s rhythm.

**Heart Block** can be first-degree (mild), second-degree (partial), or third-degree (complete), impacting how signals travel through the heart’s conduction system. Causes:

  • Age-related degeneration of the conduction system
  • Underlying heart disease or medication side effects
  • Congenital heart defects
Symptoms:
  • Slow or irregular heartbeat
  • Dizziness or fainting
  • Fatigue and shortness of breath
Diagnosis:
  • ECG (electrocardiogram)
  • Holter monitor or event recorder
Treatment:
  • Pacemaker implantation for moderate to severe cases
  • Adjusting medications that affect heart rhythm
  • Monitoring mild cases without symptoms
Prevention:
  • Manage heart risk factors (blood pressure, cholesterol)
  • Regular cardiac check-ups
  • Avoid excessive use of medications that affect conduction
References:
  1. NHS: Heart Block
  2. Mayo Clinic: Heart Block

Heart Failure: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Heart failure is a chronic condition where the heart doesn't pump blood effectively, leading to fatigue, fluid buildup, and breathing difficulties.

**Heart Failure** occurs when the heart muscle is weakened or damaged and cannot meet the body’s circulatory demands. Causes:

  • Coronary artery disease and heart attacks
  • High blood pressure (hypertension)
  • Valvular heart disease or cardiomyopathy
Symptoms:
  • Shortness of breath, especially on exertion or lying down
  • Swelling in the ankles, feet, or abdomen
  • Persistent fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance
Diagnosis:
  • Physical exam, medical history, and blood tests
  • Echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart)
  • Chest X-ray and ECG (electrocardiogram)
Treatment:
  • Medications (ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics)
  • Lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, fluid management)
  • In advanced cases, devices or surgery (pacemaker, LVAD)
Prevention:
  • Manage blood pressure, cholesterol, and diabetes
  • Maintain a healthy weight and stay active
  • Avoid smoking and limit alcohol
References:
  1. NHS: Heart Failure
  2. AHA: Heart Failure

Heart Palpitations: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Heart palpitations are sensations of a fast-beating, fluttering, or pounding heart, often related to stress, exercise, or certain health issues.

**Heart Palpitations** can feel like the heart is skipping beats or beating too hard or fast. They are usually harmless but can sometimes indicate underlying heart conditions. Causes:

  • Stress, anxiety, or panic attacks
  • Caffeine, alcohol, or nicotine
  • Arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation) or thyroid disorders
Symptoms:
  • Fluttering or pounding in the chest
  • Feeling faint or lightheaded
  • Shortness of breath or chest discomfort
Diagnosis:
  • Physical exam and patient history
  • ECG, Holter monitor, or event recorder
  • Blood tests (thyroid function, electrolytes)
Treatment:
  • Reducing triggers (stress, caffeine)
  • Medications for arrhythmias if necessary
  • Relaxation techniques and stress management
Prevention:
  • Maintain a healthy lifestyle and manage stress
  • Avoid excessive caffeine, alcohol, and smoking
  • Regular check-ups if you have a heart condition
References:
  1. NHS: Heart Palpitations
  2. Mayo Clinic: Heart Palpitations

Hepatitis A: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hepatitis A is a viral infection that inflames the liver, often spread through contaminated food or water, or close contact with an infected person.

**Hepatitis A** typically causes acute but self-limiting liver inflammation and does not become chronic. Causes:

  • Fecal-oral route (contaminated food or water)
  • Close personal contact with an infected individual
Symptoms:
  • Fatigue, nausea, and vomiting
  • Abdominal pain and jaundice (yellowing of the skin/eyes)
  • Loss of appetite and low-grade fever
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests to detect HAV antibodies
  • Liver function tests
Treatment:
  • Supportive care (rest, hydration, balanced diet)
  • Avoid alcohol and hepatotoxic drugs
  • Most recover fully without long-term liver damage
Prevention:
  • Vaccination against hepatitis A
  • Proper handwashing and safe food practices
  • Avoid contaminated water or ice in high-risk areas
References:
  1. NHS: Hepatitis A
  2. CDC: Hepatitis A

Hepatitis B: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hepatitis B is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV), transmitted through blood and bodily fluids.

**Hepatitis B** can be acute or chronic, potentially leading to serious liver damage if untreated. Causes:

  • Exposure to infected blood (needles, syringes)
  • Sexual contact with an infected partner
  • Mother-to-child transmission during birth
Symptoms:
  • Fatigue, jaundice, and dark urine
  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain
  • Loss of appetite and joint pain
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests (HBsAg, anti-HBc, etc.)
  • Liver function tests and ultrasound
Treatment:
  • Antiviral medications for chronic hepatitis B
  • Liver monitoring for potential cirrhosis or cancer
  • Supportive care for acute infection
Prevention:
  • Hepatitis B vaccination
  • Safe sex and needle-use practices
  • Screening blood donations and pregnant women
References:
  1. NHS: Hepatitis B
  2. CDC: Hepatitis B

Hepatitis C: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hepatitis C is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV), mainly spread through blood-to-blood contact.

**Hepatitis C** can be acute or chronic, and chronic infection may lead to cirrhosis or liver cancer if untreated. Causes:

  • Sharing needles or equipment for injecting drugs
  • Unsanitized medical or tattoo equipment
  • Rarely, sexual transmission or mother-to-child
Symptoms:
  • Fatigue, muscle aches, and loss of appetite
  • Jaundice, dark urine, and pale stools
  • Often asymptomatic until advanced liver damage
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests (anti-HCV antibodies, HCV RNA)
  • Liver function tests and imaging
Treatment:
  • Direct-acting antiviral (DAA) medications
  • Monitoring for liver cirrhosis or cancer
  • Lifestyle changes to support liver health
Prevention:
  • Avoid sharing needles or personal items
  • Use reputable tattoo/piercing services
  • Screening and early treatment
References:
  1. NHS: Hepatitis C
  2. CDC: Hepatitis C

Hiatus Hernia: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A hiatus hernia occurs when part of the stomach pushes up into the chest cavity through the diaphragm, often causing acid reflux.

**Hiatus Hernia** can be sliding (most common) or paraesophageal. Symptoms are often related to gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD). Causes:

  • Weakening of the diaphragm muscles
  • Increased abdominal pressure (obesity, pregnancy)
  • Genetic predisposition or injury
Symptoms:
  • Heartburn and acid reflux
  • Chest or abdominal pain
  • Difficulty swallowing in severe cases
Diagnosis:
  • Barium swallow X-ray
  • Endoscopy (gastroscopy)
  • pH monitoring for reflux
Treatment:
  • Lifestyle changes (weight loss, diet adjustments)
  • Medications (antacids, proton pump inhibitors)
  • Surgical repair in severe or complicated cases
Prevention:
  • Maintain a healthy weight
  • Avoid large meals and lying down after eating
  • Manage chronic coughing or constipation
References:
  1. NHS: Hiatus Hernia
  2. Mayo Clinic: Hiatal Hernia

High Blood Pressure (Hypertension): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hypertension occurs when the force of blood against artery walls is consistently too high, increasing risks of heart disease and stroke.

**High Blood Pressure (Hypertension)** can be primary (essential) or secondary to an underlying condition (kidney, endocrine disorders). Causes:

  • Obesity, poor diet (high sodium), and inactivity
  • Genetic factors and age
  • Underlying conditions (kidney disease, thyroid issues)
Symptoms:
  • Often asymptomatic (silent killer)
  • Severe hypertension may cause headaches or vision changes
  • Chest pain or difficulty breathing in extreme cases
Diagnosis:
  • Repeated blood pressure measurements
  • 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring
  • Lab tests to rule out secondary causes
Treatment:
  • Lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise, weight loss)
  • Medications (ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics)
  • Monitoring blood pressure regularly
Prevention:
  • Limit salt and alcohol intake
  • Engage in regular physical activity
  • Manage stress and maintain a healthy weight
References:
  1. NHS: High Blood Pressure
  2. WHO: Hypertension

High Cholesterol: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

High cholesterol means there’s an excessive amount of fatty substances in your blood, increasing the risk of heart disease and stroke.

**High Cholesterol** typically refers to elevated LDL (“bad” cholesterol) or triglycerides, which can lead to plaque buildup in arteries. Causes:

  • Poor diet (high in saturated or trans fats)
  • Genetic predisposition (familial hypercholesterolemia)
  • Obesity, inactivity, and certain health conditions
Symptoms:
  • No specific symptoms (detected via blood tests)
  • Chest pain or heart attack if arteries are significantly blocked
Diagnosis:
  • Lipid profile blood test (LDL, HDL, triglycerides)
  • Assessment of cardiovascular risk factors
Treatment:
  • Lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise, weight management)
  • Medications (statins, fibrates, bile-acid sequestrants)
  • Regular follow-up to monitor lipid levels
Prevention:
  • Healthy eating (fruits, vegetables, whole grains)
  • Maintain a healthy weight and stay active
  • Avoid smoking and limit alcohol intake
References:
  1. NHS: High Cholesterol
  2. CDC: Cholesterol

HIV: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) attacks the immune system, weakening the body’s ability to fight infections and certain cancers.

**HIV** can progress to AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) if untreated. Modern therapies help many people live long, healthy lives. Causes:

  • Unprotected sexual contact with an infected person
  • Sharing needles or syringes
  • Mother-to-child transmission during pregnancy or breastfeeding
Symptoms:
  • Flu-like illness shortly after infection
  • Asymptomatic period can last for years
  • Opportunistic infections in advanced stages
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests for HIV antibodies and antigens
  • Confirmatory tests (Western blot, PCR)
Treatment:
  • Antiretroviral therapy (ART) to suppress the virus
  • Regular monitoring of CD4 counts and viral load
  • Early treatment improves outcomes significantly
Prevention:
  • Use condoms and practice safer sex
  • Regular HIV testing and PrEP for high-risk individuals
  • Avoid sharing needles or injection equipment
References:
  1. NHS: HIV and AIDS
  2. CDC: HIV

Hives (Urticaria): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hives (urticaria) are raised, itchy welts on the skin that appear suddenly, often as an allergic reaction or due to stress.

**Hives (Urticaria)** can be acute (short-term) or chronic (long-term), often triggered by allergens or physical factors like heat or pressure. Causes:

  • Allergic reactions (foods, medications, insect stings)
  • Infections or stress
  • Physical triggers (heat, cold, pressure)
Symptoms:
  • Raised, red or skin-colored welts
  • Intense itching or burning sensation
  • Welts that vary in size and may merge together
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and medical history
  • Allergy tests (skin prick or blood tests) if needed
Treatment:
  • Antihistamines to reduce itching and swelling
  • Identify and avoid triggers (allergens, stressors)
  • Corticosteroids or immunosuppressants for severe cases
Prevention:
  • Keep a diary to identify possible triggers
  • Manage stress and maintain healthy lifestyle habits
  • Use protective measures against known allergens
References:
  1. NHS: Hives (Urticaria)
  2. ACAAI: Hives

Hodgkin Lymphoma: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hodgkin lymphoma is a cancer of the lymphatic system, characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

**Hodgkin Lymphoma** often affects lymph nodes in the neck, chest, or underarms, and can spread throughout the lymphatic system. Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition
  • Viral infections (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus)
  • Weakened immune system
Symptoms:
  • Painless swelling of lymph nodes
  • Night sweats, fever, and unexplained weight loss
  • Persistent fatigue and itching
Diagnosis:
  • Biopsy of an enlarged lymph node
  • Imaging tests (CT, PET) to stage the disease
  • Blood tests to assess overall health
Treatment:
  • Chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy
  • Immunotherapy for advanced cases
  • Stem cell transplant if necessary
Prevention:
  • Early detection through regular check-ups
  • Maintain a healthy immune system
  • Awareness of family history
References:
  1. NHS: Hodgkin Lymphoma
  2. Cancer Research UK: Hodgkin Lymphoma

Hodgkin Lymphoma in Children: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hodgkin lymphoma in children is a rare but treatable cancer affecting the lymphatic system, often presenting with swollen lymph nodes.

**Hodgkin Lymphoma in Children** may have similar symptoms to adult Hodgkin lymphoma but often has a higher cure rate when diagnosed early. Causes:

  • Potential genetic factors
  • Prior Epstein-Barr virus infection
  • Immune system issues
Symptoms:
  • Swollen lymph nodes in the neck, underarm, or groin
  • Fatigue, fever, night sweats
  • Loss of appetite or weight loss
Diagnosis:
  • Physical exam and biopsy of lymph node
  • Blood tests and imaging (CT, PET)
Treatment:
  • Combined chemotherapy and low-dose radiation
  • Supportive care to manage side effects
  • Long-term follow-up for potential late effects
Prevention:
  • Early detection and awareness of symptoms
  • Regular pediatric check-ups
  • Genetic counseling if a strong family history exists
References:
  1. NCI: Childhood Hodgkin Lymphoma
  2. NHS: Hodgkin Lymphoma

Hodgkin Lymphoma in Teenagers & Young Adults

Hodgkin lymphoma is one of the most common cancers in older children and young adults, often presenting with painless lymph node swelling.

**Hodgkin Lymphoma in Teenagers & Young Adults** can have a strong impact on physical, emotional, and social development but is highly treatable. Causes:

  • Family history or genetic predisposition
  • Previous EBV infection
  • Weakened immune system
Symptoms:
  • Swollen, painless lymph nodes
  • Night sweats, unexplained fever
  • Persistent fatigue and weight loss
Diagnosis:
  • Biopsy and imaging studies (PET, CT)
  • Blood tests to check overall health
Treatment:
  • Combination chemotherapy and radiation therapy
  • Psychosocial support and counseling
  • Fertility preservation options if relevant
Prevention:
  • Early recognition of symptoms and timely medical advice
  • Regular health checks, especially with a family history
  • Healthy lifestyle to support the immune system
References:
  1. Teenage Cancer Trust: Hodgkin Lymphoma
  2. Cancer Research UK: Hodgkin Lymphoma

Huntington's Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Huntington's disease is a progressive brain disorder caused by a genetic mutation, affecting movement, cognition, and behavior.

**Huntington's Disease** results from a defective gene on chromosome 4, leading to gradual degeneration of neurons in certain brain areas. Causes:

  • Inherited genetic mutation (autosomal dominant)
Symptoms:
  • Involuntary jerking or writhing movements (chorea)
  • Difficulty with coordination, speech, and swallowing
  • Changes in mood, memory, and judgment
Diagnosis:
  • Genetic testing for the HTT gene mutation
  • Neurological exam and family history
Treatment:
  • Medications to manage movement and psychiatric symptoms
  • Physical, occupational, and speech therapy
  • Supportive care for daily living activities
Prevention:
  • Genetic counseling for at-risk families
  • Pre-symptomatic testing to inform family planning
References:
  1. NHS: Huntington's Disease
  2. Huntington's Disease Association

Hydrocephalus: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hydrocephalus is a buildup of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain, increasing pressure and potentially causing damage to brain tissues.

**Hydrocephalus** can occur at any age but is most common in infants or older adults, often resulting from an imbalance in fluid production and absorption. Causes:

  • Blockage preventing fluid circulation (tumor, cyst)
  • Infections (meningitis), hemorrhage, or injury
  • Congenital defects in brain structure
Symptoms:
  • Head enlargement in infants, bulging fontanelle
  • Headaches, nausea, and vomiting in older children/adults
  • Balance problems, blurred vision, or cognitive changes
Diagnosis:
  • Neurological exam and imaging (MRI, CT scan)
  • Measurement of head circumference in infants
Treatment:
  • Surgical insertion of a shunt system
  • Endoscopic third ventriculostomy in select cases
  • Ongoing monitoring and management of complications
Prevention:
  • Prompt treatment of infections or brain injuries
  • Prenatal care to reduce risk of congenital causes
  • Helmet use to prevent head injuries
References:
  1. NHS: Hydrocephalus
  2. CDC: Hydrocephalus

Hyperglycaemia (High Blood Sugar): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hyperglycaemia occurs when blood glucose levels are too high, often related to diabetes or other endocrine disorders.

**Hyperglycaemia** is a key concern in diabetes management, potentially leading to complications like ketoacidosis or organ damage if persistent. Causes:

  • Inadequate insulin production or action (diabetes)
  • Excessive carbohydrate intake or stress hormones
  • Medications or illness
Symptoms:
  • Frequent urination and increased thirst
  • Fatigue, blurred vision
  • Unexplained weight loss
Diagnosis:
  • Blood glucose tests (fasting, random, HbA1c)
  • Urinalysis for glucose or ketones
Treatment:
  • Insulin therapy or oral medications
  • Dietary adjustments and regular exercise
  • Monitoring blood sugar levels frequently
Prevention:
  • Maintain healthy diet and physical activity
  • Adhere to diabetes management plan if diagnosed
  • Regular check-ups for early detection
References:
  1. NHS: Hyperglycaemia
  2. Diabetes UK

Hyperhidrosis (Excessive Sweating): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hyperhidrosis is characterized by excessive sweating beyond what’s needed to regulate body temperature, affecting daily activities.

**Hyperhidrosis** can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to underlying conditions like hyperthyroidism or infections. Causes:

  • Overactive sweat glands (primary hyperhidrosis)
  • Medical conditions (thyroid issues, diabetes)
  • Certain medications or stress
Symptoms:
  • Excessive sweating in specific areas (hands, feet, armpits)
  • Visible sweating soaking through clothing
  • Emotional distress and social anxiety
Diagnosis:
  • Physical exam and patient history
  • Starch-iodine test or thermoregulatory sweat test
Treatment:
  • Antiperspirants with aluminum chloride
  • Botulinum toxin injections or iontophoresis
  • Surgery (sympathectomy) in severe cases
Prevention:
  • Wear breathable clothing and use antiperspirants
  • Manage stress and anxiety
  • Treat underlying medical conditions
References:
  1. NHS: Hyperhidrosis
  2. International Hyperhidrosis Society

Hypoglycaemia (Low Blood Sugar): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hypoglycaemia occurs when blood sugar levels drop below normal, leading to symptoms like shakiness, sweating, and confusion.

**Hypoglycaemia** is common in people with diabetes who take insulin or certain medications, but it can also occur in non-diabetics under specific conditions. Causes:

  • Excess insulin or diabetes medications
  • Skipping meals or not eating enough carbohydrates
  • Excessive alcohol consumption or prolonged exercise
Symptoms:
  • Shakiness, sweating, palpitations
  • Hunger, irritability, or confusion
  • Severe cases can lead to seizures or unconsciousness
Diagnosis:
  • Blood glucose testing during episodes
  • Medical history and physical exam
Treatment:
  • Consume fast-acting carbohydrates (glucose tablets, juice)
  • Adjust diabetes medications if needed
  • Emergency glucagon injection for severe cases
Prevention:
  • Frequent blood sugar monitoring
  • Regular meals and balanced diet
  • Educate family/friends about warning signs
References:
  1. NHS: Hypoglycaemia
  2. Diabetes UK: Hypoglycaemia

Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A progressive lung disease causing scarring (fibrosis) of lung tissue, leading to irreversible breathing difficulties.

**IPF** is a chronic condition with unknown cause, primarily affecting adults over 50. Prognosis is generally poor with median survival of 3-5 years. Causes:

  • Exact cause unknown (idiopathic)
  • Genetic predisposition in some cases
  • Environmental factors (smoking, dust exposure)
Symptoms:
  • Progressive shortness of breath
  • Dry, hacking cough
  • Fatigue and weight loss
Diagnosis:
  • High-resolution CT scan
  • Lung function tests
  • Sometimes surgical lung biopsy
Treatment:
  • Antifibrotic medications (nintedanib, pirfenidone)
  • Oxygen therapy
  • Lung transplantation in eligible patients
Management:
  • Pulmonary rehabilitation
  • Vaccinations to prevent respiratory infections
  • Symptom management with cough suppressants
References:
  1. NHS: IPF
  2. American Lung Association

Child Cold/Flu Symptoms: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Common viral infections in children characterized by respiratory symptoms, fever, and general discomfort.

**Childhood cold/flu** are typically self-limiting but require careful monitoring for complications. Causes:

  • Rhinovirus (common cold)
  • Influenza viruses
  • Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)
Symptoms:
  • Runny nose/congestion
  • Cough and sore throat
  • Fever (more common in flu)
When to Worry:
  • Difficulty breathing
  • Persistent high fever
  • Dehydration signs
Treatment:
  • Rest and hydration
  • Saline nasal drops
  • Age-appropriate pain/fever relievers
Prevention:
  • Annual flu vaccination
  • Hand hygiene education
  • Avoid sick contacts
References:
  1. NHS: Childhood Illnesses
  2. CDC: Flu in Children

Impetigo: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A highly contagious bacterial skin infection causing honey-colored crusts, common in young children.

**Impetigo** spreads easily through direct contact and typically affects face, hands, and diaper area. Causes:

  • Staphylococcus aureus bacteria
  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Skin breaks from insect bites or eczema
Symptoms:
  • Red sores that burst and crust
  • Itchy fluid-filled blisters
  • Local lymph node swelling
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination
  • Bacterial culture if recurrent
Treatment:
  • Topical antibiotics (mupirocin)
  • Oral antibiotics for severe cases
  • Antiseptic washes
Prevention:
  • Keep skin clean and dry
  • Avoid sharing personal items
  • Isolate until 48hrs after treatment
References:
  1. NHS: Impetigo
  2. Mayo Clinic

Indigestion: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A common digestive issue causing discomfort in the upper abdomen, often related to eating habits or underlying conditions.

**Dyspepsia** affects 20-30% of adults and can be functional (no clear cause) or organic (from specific medical issues). Causes:

  • Overeating or eating too quickly
  • Spicy/fatty foods and alcohol
  • GERD, ulcers, or gallstones
Symptoms:
  • Upper abdominal pain/bloating
  • Heartburn and nausea
  • Early satiety
Diagnosis:
  • Medical history assessment
  • Endoscopy if red flags present
  • H. pylori testing
Treatment:
  • Antacids or PPIs
  • Dietary modifications
  • Stress management techniques
When to Seek Help:
  • Unintentional weight loss
  • Difficulty swallowing
  • Persistent vomiting
References:
  1. NHS: Indigestion
  2. Mayo Clinic

Ingrown Toenail: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A painful condition where the toenail grows into surrounding skin, often affecting the big toe.

**Onychocryptosis** can lead to infection if untreated. Common in adolescents and young adults. Causes:

  • Improper nail trimming
  • Tight-fitting shoes
  • Trauma or foot deformities
Symptoms:
  • Redness and swelling
  • Pain when pressure applied
  • Pus in infected cases
Treatment:
  • Warm water soaks
  • Antibiotics for infection
  • Partial nail avulsion surgery
Prevention:
  • Cut nails straight across
  • Wear properly fitted shoes
  • Keep feet clean and dry
References:
  1. NHS: Ingrown Toenail
  2. AAD Guidelines

Infertility: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Defined as inability to conceive after 12 months of regular unprotected intercourse (6 months if over 35).

**Infertility** affects 1 in 7 couples. Both male and female factors contribute equally. Causes (Female):

  • Ovulation disorders (PCOS)
  • Tubal blockages
  • Endometriosis
Causes (Male):
  • Low sperm count/motility
  • Varicocele
  • Hormonal imbalances
Diagnosis:
  • Semen analysis
  • Ovulation tracking
  • HSG test for fallopian tubes
Treatments:
  • Fertility medications (Clomid)
  • IVF/IUI procedures
  • Surgical interventions
Support:
  • Counseling services
  • Support groups
  • Lifestyle modifications
References:
  1. NHS: Infertility
  2. ASRM Guidelines

Inflammatory Bowel Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

**IBD** is distinct from IBS - it causes visible bowel damage and requires different management. Types:

  • Crohn's disease (any GI location)
  • Ulcerative colitis (colon only)
Symptoms:
  • Bloody diarrhea
  • Abdominal pain and fatigue
  • Weight loss and malnutrition
Diagnosis:
  • Colonoscopy with biopsy
  • Calprotectin stool test
  • MRI/CT enterography
Treatment:
  • 5-ASA drugs (mesalamine)
  • Immunosuppressants
  • Biologic therapies (anti-TNF)
Management:
  • Dietician support
  • Stress reduction
  • Regular cancer surveillance
References:
  1. Crohn's & Colitis Foundation
  2. NHS: IBD

Inherited Heart Conditions: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Genetic disorders affecting heart structure/function, including cardiomyopathies and channelopathies.

**Familial cardiac conditions** account for 25% of sudden cardiac deaths in young people. Common Types:

  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • Long QT syndrome
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia
Symptoms:
  • Palpitations or syncope
  • Chest pain during exercise
  • Family history of early cardiac death
Diagnosis:
  • ECG and echocardiogram
  • Genetic testing
  • Cardiac MRI
Management:
  • Beta-blockers
  • Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD)
  • Lifestyle restrictions
Screening:
  • Family cascade testing
  • Regular cardiac evaluations
  • Genetic counseling
References:
  1. BHF
  2. Mayo Clinic

Insomnia: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Persistent difficulty falling or staying asleep, affecting daily functioning and quality of life.

**Chronic insomnia** affects 10-15% of adults and can be primary or secondary to other conditions. Causes:

  • Stress and anxiety
  • Poor sleep hygiene
  • Medical conditions (chronic pain, asthma)
Symptoms:
  • Daytime fatigue
  • Mood disturbances
  • Difficulty concentrating
Treatment:
  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT-I)
  • Sleep restriction therapy
  • Short-term medication (zolpidem)
Prevention:
  • Consistent sleep schedule
  • Limit screen time before bed
  • Create dark, cool sleep environment
References:
  1. NHS: Insomnia
  2. American Academy of Sleep Medicine

Iron Deficiency Anaemia: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Low red blood cell count due to insufficient iron, affecting oxygen transport throughout the body.

**Most common nutritional deficiency** worldwide, particularly affecting women and children. Causes:

  • Inadequate dietary intake
  • Blood loss (menstruation, GI bleeding)
  • Malabsorption (celiac disease)
Symptoms:
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Pale skin and brittle nails
  • Shortness of breath
Diagnosis:
  • Complete blood count (CBC)
  • Ferritin levels
  • Endoscopy/colonoscopy if GI bleeding suspected
Treatment:
  • Oral iron supplements (ferrous sulfate)
  • Iron-rich diet (red meat, leafy greens)
  • IV iron for severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: IDA
  2. ASH Guidelines

Irritable Bowel Syndrome: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Functional gastrointestinal disorder causing abdominal pain and altered bowel habits.

**IBS affects 10-15%** of adults, with three subtypes: IBS-D (diarrhea), IBS-C (constipation), and IBS-M (mixed). Triggers:

  • Food intolerances (FODMAPs)
  • Stress and anxiety
  • Gut microbiome changes
Symptoms:
  • Abdominal cramping relieved by defecation
  • Bloating and gas
  • Mucus in stool
Management:
  • Low FODMAP diet
  • Probiotics
  • Antispasmodics (hyoscine)
Red Flags:
  • Weight loss
  • Rectal bleeding
  • Onset after age 50
References:
  1. NHS: IBS
  2. IBS Network

Itching: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Unpleasant sensation that provokes scratching, ranging from mild irritation to severe discomfort.

**Pruritus** can be localized or generalized, acute or chronic (>6 weeks duration). Causes:

  • Skin conditions (eczema, urticaria)
  • Systemic diseases (liver/kidney failure)
  • Medication reactions
Evaluation:
  • Complete medical history
  • Skin examination
  • Blood tests for systemic causes
Treatment:
  • Topical corticosteroids
  • Antihistamines
  • Treat underlying condition
Self-care:
  • Cool compresses
  • Moisturize dry skin
  • Avoid hot showers
References:
  1. AAD Itching Guide
  2. NHS: Itchy Skin

Itchy Bottom: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Persistent itching around the anal area, often worse at night.

**Pruritus ani** affects 1-5% of population, more common in men. Causes:

  • Poor hygiene or excessive cleaning
  • Hemorrhoids or anal fissures
  • Pinworm infection (children)
Management:
  • Gentle cleansing after bowel movements
  • Zinc oxide ointment
  • Treat underlying infections
When to Investigate:
  • Persistent >4 weeks
  • Bleeding or discharge
  • Perianal skin changes
References:
  1. NHS: Itchy Bottom
  2. Patient.info Guide

Itchy Skin: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Widespread itching without visible rash, often indicating systemic involvement.

**Generalized pruritus** requires investigation when persistent (>2 weeks). Systemic Causes:

  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Cholestatic liver disease
  • Thyroid disorders
Diagnostic Approach:
  • Liver/kidney function tests
  • Thyroid screening
  • Iron studies
Treatment:
  • Gabapentin for uremic pruritus
  • Cholestyramine for liver-related itching
  • Phototherapy
References:
  1. AAFP Guidelines
  2. DermNet NZ

Joint Hypermobility: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Increased joint flexibility beyond normal range, often benign but sometimes associated with pain syndromes.

**Hypermobility spectrum disorders** affect 10-25% of population, more common in young females. Characteristics:

  • Beighton score ≥4/9
  • Stretchy skin
  • Easy bruising
Complications:
  • Chronic joint pain
  • Frequent dislocations
  • Fatigue (similar to CFS)
Management:
  • Physiotherapy for stability
  • Pain management
  • Genetic testing for EDS
References:
  1. Hypermobility Syndromes Association
  2. NHS Guide

Kaposi’s Sarcoma: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Cancer caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), often appearing as purple skin lesions.

**Four Types:**

  • Classic (elderly Mediterranean men)
  • Endemic (African populations)
  • HIV-associated
  • Iatrogenic (transplant patients)
Symptoms:
  • Cutaneous purple plaques
  • Mucosal/organ involvement
  • Lymphedema
Treatment:
  • Antiretroviral therapy (HIV+ patients)
  • Local radiotherapy
  • Chemotherapy (liposomal doxorubicin)
References:
  1. NCI Guidelines
  2. AAD Overview

Kidney Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Renal cell carcinoma accounts for 90% of kidney cancers, often discovered incidentally.

**Risk Factors:**

  • Smoking and obesity
  • Hypertension
  • Genetic syndromes (VHL disease)
Symptoms:
  • Hematuria
  • Flank pain
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes
Diagnosis:
  • CT urogram
  • Biopsy (selected cases)
  • Metastatic workup
Treatment:
  • Partial/radical nephrectomy
  • Targeted therapies (sunitinib)
  • Immunotherapy (nivolumab)
References:
  1. American Cancer Society
  2. NHS Guide

Kidney Infection: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Pyelonephritis - bacterial infection of kidneys, usually ascending from urinary tract.

**Clinical Features:**

  • Fever >38°C
  • Flank pain/CVA tenderness
  • Nausea/vomiting
Diagnosis:
  • Urinalysis (leukocyte esterase+)
  • Urine culture
  • Blood cultures if septic
Treatment:
  • IV antibiotics (ceftriaxone)
  • Switch to oral (co-amoxiclav)
  • 7-14 day course
Prevention:
  • Hydration
  • Prompt UTI treatment
  • Avoid urinary catheters
References:
  1. NICE Guidelines
  2. National Kidney Foundation

Kidney Stones: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Hard mineral deposits forming in urinary tract, causing severe pain (renal colic).

**Types:**

  • Calcium oxalate (80%)
  • Uric acid
  • Struvite (infection stones)
Symptoms:
  • Colicky flank pain
  • Hematuria
  • Dysuria
Management:
  • Analgesia (NSAIDs)
  • Medical expulsive therapy
  • ESWL or ureteroscopy
Prevention:
  • Hydration (>2.5L/day)
  • Dietary modifications
  • Thiazides for calcium stones
References:
  1. Urology Care Foundation
  2. NHS Guide

Labyrinthitis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Inner ear inflammation affecting both vestibular and cochlear systems, often post-viral.

**Pathophysiology:** Inflammation of membranous labyrinth → disrupts balance/auditory signals Differential Diagnosis:

  • Meniere's disease
  • Acoustic neuroma
  • BPPV
Clinical Course:
  • Acute phase: 1-3 days severe vertigo
  • Subacute: 1-2 weeks gradual improvement
  • Chronic: Residual imbalance (weeks)
Emergency Signs:
  • Focal neurological deficits
  • Severe headache
  • Bilateral symptoms
References:
  1. NICE Clinical Knowledge Summaries
  2. Journal of Vestibular Research 2023

Lactose Intolerance: Comprehensive Guide

Enzymatic deficiency causing carbohydrate malabsorption with global prevalence variations.

**Genetic Epidemiology:**

  • 95% prevalence in East Asia
  • 15% Northern Europeans
  • Age-related decline in lactase
Diagnostic Tests:
TestSensitivitySpecificity
Hydrogen Breath78%95%
Genetic Test94%100%
Nutrition Management:
  • Fermented dairy better tolerated
  • Calcium requirements: 1000-1300mg/day
  • Vitamin D co-supplementation
References:
  1. World Gastroenterology Organisation Guidelines
  2. NIH Lactose Intolerance Consensus

Laryngeal Cancer: Oncological Management

Squamous cell carcinoma (95%) with TNM staging determining therapeutic approach.

**Molecular Markers:**

  • EGFR overexpression (60-90%)
  • TP53 mutations
  • HPV+ (15-25% cases)
Treatment Protocol:
StageTreatment5-Yr Survival
IRadiation85%
IIIChemoradiation55%
IVSurgery + Adjuvant35%
Rehabilitation Needs:
  • Speech therapy post-laryngectomy
  • Swallowing retraining
  • Psychosocial support
References:
  1. NCCN Guidelines v3.2023
  2. European Laryngological Society

Laryngitis: Advanced Clinical Perspectives

Inflammation of laryngeal mucosa with acute/chronic differentiation and voice rehabilitation needs.

**Pathophysiological Changes:**

  • Vocal fold edema (Reinke's space)
  • Increased mucosal blood flow
  • Impaired vibratory pattern (stroboscopy findings)
Diagnostic Protocol:
ToolAcuteChronic
LaryngoscopyRarely neededEssential
pH Monitoring-For GERD evaluation
Novel Therapies (2023):
  • Pulsed dye laser treatment
  • In-office steroid injections
  • Voice biofeedback therapy
References:
  1. American Speech-Language-Hearing Association (ASHA) Guidelines
  2. Laryngoscope 2023;133:123-135

Late Miscarriage: Multidisciplinary Management

Second trimester fetal loss requiring comprehensive obstetric and psychological care.

**Etiological Framework:**

Category% CasesExamples
Anatomical25%Cervical insufficiency
Infectious15%Chorioamnionitis
Genetic12%Triploidy
Prevention Strategies:
  • Transvaginal cerclage (McDonald vs Shirodkar)
  • 17-OH progesterone supplementation
  • Antiphospholipid syndrome management
Psychological Intervention Protocol:
  • Perinatal loss counseling
  • Support group referrals
  • Subsequent pregnancy planning
References:
  1. RCOG Green-top Guideline No. 17
  2. Lancet 2023 Pregnancy Loss Series

Leg Cramps: Neuromuscular Mechanisms

Sudden involuntary muscle contractions with complex electrolyte and neurological etiology.

**Pathophysiological Model:**

  • Abnormal α-motoneuron excitability
  • Sarcolemmal hyperexcitability
  • Altered chloride channel function
Evidence-Based Management:
InterventionEfficacyDose
MagnesiumRR 0.86300mg nocte
QuinineRR 0.53200-300mg HS
Red Flag Evaluation:
  • ALS (fasciculations)
  • Peripheral artery disease
  • Metabolic myopathies
References:
  1. BMJ 2023;380:e073362
  2. Neuromuscular Disorders 2022 Compendium

Lichen Planus: Immunodermatological Insights

T-cell mediated autoimmune disorder targeting basal keratinocytes.

**Molecular Pathways:**

  • CD8+ T-cell infiltration
  • CXCR3/CXCL10 axis activation
  • Fas-FasL mediated apoptosis
Therapeutic Ladder:
SeverityTreatmentResponse Rate
MildTopical calcineurin inhibitors65%
ModerateNB-UVB phototherapy80%
SevereJAK inhibitors92% (trial data)
Malignant Potential:**
  • Oral LP: 1-5% transformation risk
  • Esophageal LP: SCC monitoring
  • Annual cancer surveillance protocol
References:
  1. British Journal of Dermatology 2023 Guidelines
  2. NEJM 2022;387:1603-1616

Lipoedema: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Lipoedema is a chronic condition characterized by abnormal fat distribution, primarily affecting the legs and sometimes the arms.

**Lipoedema** is a progressive adipose tissue disorder that predominantly affects women. It typically presents with symmetrical enlargement of the legs, pain, tenderness, and easy bruising. Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition and hormonal factors
  • Abnormal fat deposition and inflammatory processes
Symptoms:
  • Disproportionate fat accumulation in the lower body
  • Painful, tender legs with easy bruising
  • Swelling and a feeling of heaviness
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Imaging techniques (ultrasound or MRI) to assess tissue changes
Treatment:
  • Conservative management: compression garments, manual lymphatic drainage
  • In selected cases, liposuction may be considered
References:
  1. NHS: Lipoedema
  2. International Lipoedema Foundation

Liver Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Liver cancer is a malignant tumor arising from liver cells, often linked to chronic liver conditions such as cirrhosis.

**Liver Cancer** most commonly refers to hepatocellular carcinoma, a primary malignancy of the liver frequently associated with chronic hepatitis infections, alcohol abuse, and cirrhosis. Causes:

  • Chronic hepatitis B and C infections
  • Cirrhosis due to alcohol abuse or non‑alcoholic fatty liver disease
Symptoms:
  • Abdominal pain and swelling
  • Unexplained weight loss and jaundice
  • Fatigue and loss of appetite
Diagnosis:
  • Imaging studies (ultrasound, CT, MRI)
  • Biopsy for histopathological confirmation
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection or liver transplant in early stages
  • Chemotherapy and targeted therapies for advanced disease
References:
  1. NHS: Liver Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society: Liver Cancer

Liver Disease: Overview, Causes & Management

Liver disease encompasses a range of conditions that impair the liver's ability to function properly, including hepatitis and cirrhosis.

**Liver Disease** refers to any condition that damages the liver, affecting its crucial functions such as detoxification, metabolism, and protein synthesis. It includes hepatitis, cirrhosis, and non‑alcoholic fatty liver disease. Causes:

  • Viral infections (hepatitis B and C)
  • Excessive alcohol consumption
  • Metabolic conditions like NAFLD
Symptoms:
  • Jaundice, fatigue, and abdominal swelling
  • Nausea and loss of appetite
  • Bruising and bleeding abnormalities
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests to assess liver function
  • Imaging studies and sometimes liver biopsy
Treatment:
  • Lifestyle changes, medications, and management of underlying causes
  • In advanced cases, liver transplantation may be considered
References:
  1. NHS: Liver Disease
  2. Mayo Clinic: Liver Disease

Liver Tumours: Types, Causes & Treatment

Liver tumours can be benign or malignant, with hepatocellular carcinoma being the most common malignant tumour.

**Liver Tumours** include a range of lesions from benign growths (such as hemangiomas) to malignant cancers like hepatocellular carcinoma. Risk factors include chronic liver disease and cirrhosis. Causes:

  • Cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis, and exposure to toxins
Symptoms:
  • Abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice
  • Fatigue and loss of appetite
Diagnosis:
  • Imaging studies (ultrasound, CT, MRI)
  • Biopsy for definitive diagnosis
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection, ablation, or liver transplant depending on severity
  • Chemotherapy and targeted therapies for advanced cases
References:
  1. NHS: Liver Cancer/Tumours
  2. American Cancer Society: Liver Cancer

Long-term Effects of COVID-19: Overview & Management

Long-term effects of COVID-19, often known as Long COVID, refer to persistent symptoms that continue after the acute infection has resolved.

**Long-term Effects of COVID-19 (Long COVID)** encompass a range of symptoms—such as fatigue, breathlessness, and cognitive impairment—that persist for weeks or months following the initial infection. Causes:

  • Prolonged inflammatory response and organ damage
  • Immune system dysregulation following infection
Symptoms:
  • Chronic fatigue, breathlessness, and brain fog
  • Muscle pain and intermittent fever
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and patient history
  • Exclusion of other underlying conditions
Management:
  • Multidisciplinary rehabilitation and supportive care
  • Symptom-targeted treatments and regular follow-up
References:
  1. NHS: Long COVID
  2. CDC: Long-term Effects of COVID-19

Loss of Libido: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Loss of libido refers to a decrease in sexual desire, which may result from hormonal, psychological, or medical factors.

**Loss of Libido** is a reduction in sexual desire that can affect both men and women. It may be influenced by hormonal imbalances, stress, medications, and underlying health conditions. Causes:

  • Hormonal imbalances (e.g., low testosterone, menopause)
  • Psychological factors such as stress, anxiety, or depression
  • Medications and chronic health conditions
Symptoms:
  • Decreased interest in sexual activity
  • Reduced sexual arousal and satisfaction
  • Emotional distress and relationship challenges
Diagnosis:
  • Medical and sexual history evaluation
  • Hormonal testing and psychological assessment
Treatment:
  • Counseling and therapy for psychological causes
  • Hormonal treatments or medication adjustments as needed
  • Lifestyle modifications and stress management
References:
  1. NHS: Sexual Dysfunction
  2. Mayo Clinic: Low Sex Drive

Malaria: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Malaria is a parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes, causing fever, chills, and flu-like symptoms.
