**Malaria** is caused by Plasmodium parasites transmitted via the bite of an infected Anopheles mosquito. Causes:

  • Infection with Plasmodium species (e.g., P. falciparum, P. vivax)
  • Transmission through mosquito bites
Symptoms:
  • Fever, chills, and sweating
  • Headache, muscle aches, and fatigue
  • Nausea and vomiting
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests to detect parasites
Treatment:
  • Antimalarial medications (e.g., chloroquine, artemisinin-based therapies)
Prevention:
  • Use of insecticide-treated bed nets and repellents
  • Prophylactic antimalarials when traveling to endemic areas
References:
  1. WHO: Malaria
  2. CDC: Malaria

Malignant Brain Tumour: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Malignant brain tumours are aggressive cancers that affect brain tissue and can disrupt neurological function.

**Malignant Brain Tumour** refers to cancerous growths within the brain. They are often aggressive and can cause neurological deficits. Causes:

  • Genetic mutations and chromosomal abnormalities
  • Rare environmental factors such as radiation exposure
Symptoms:
  • Headaches and seizures
  • Changes in behavior, memory, and cognitive function
  • Nausea and visual disturbances
Diagnosis:
  • Neuroimaging (MRI, CT scans) and biopsy for confirmation
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy
  • Targeted therapies for specific tumour types
References:
  1. American Cancer Society: Brain Cancer
  2. NHS: Brain Cancer

Malnutrition: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Malnutrition occurs when the body lacks adequate nutrients, affecting growth, immunity, and overall health.

**Malnutrition** is a condition caused by an inadequate or unbalanced intake of nutrients, which can lead to significant health problems. Causes:

  • Insufficient dietary intake or poor absorption of nutrients
  • Chronic illnesses and food insecurity
Symptoms:
  • Weight loss, fatigue, and stunted growth
  • Muscle wasting and weakened immune response
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and nutritional assessment
  • Blood tests to check nutrient levels
Treatment:
  • Dietary supplementation and nutritional rehabilitation
  • Treatment of underlying conditions
Prevention:
  • Access to balanced diets and public health nutrition programs
References:
  1. WHO: Malnutrition
  2. NHS: Malnutrition

Managing Genital Symptoms: Overview & Guidance

Learn strategies for managing genital symptoms which may indicate infections or other conditions, ensuring proper care and treatment.

**Managing Genital Symptoms** involves understanding the signs of potential infections or dermatological issues in the genital area and taking appropriate action. Causes:

  • Sexually transmitted infections, allergic reactions, and irritants
Common Symptoms:
  • Itching, pain, unusual discharge, or lesions
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and laboratory testing (swabs, blood tests)
Management:
  • Targeted treatments based on diagnosis
  • Maintaining good hygiene and regular check-ups
References:
  1. NHS: STIs & Genital Infections
  2. CDC: Sexually Transmitted Diseases

Measles: Causes, Symptoms & Prevention

Measles is a highly contagious viral infection marked by fever, cough, and a characteristic red rash.

**Measles** is a viral illness spread through respiratory droplets, which can lead to severe complications if not prevented by vaccination. Causes:

  • Infection with the measles virus
  • Transmission via respiratory droplets
Symptoms:
  • High fever, cough, runny nose, and conjunctivitis
  • A characteristic red, blotchy rash
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and serological tests
Treatment:
  • Supportive care including hydration and fever management
Prevention:
  • Measles vaccination (MMR vaccine)
References:
  1. NHS: Measles
  2. CDC: Measles

Meningitis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, often due to infections.

**Meningitis** is an inflammation of the meninges, usually caused by viral, bacterial, or fungal infections. Causes:

  • Viral, bacterial, or fungal infections
  • In some cases, non-infectious causes like autoimmune conditions
Symptoms:
  • Severe headache, fever, and neck stiffness
  • Nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation, lumbar puncture, and imaging tests
Treatment:
  • Antibiotics for bacterial meningitis
  • Antivirals or antifungals for other types, along with supportive care
References:
  1. NHS: Meningitis
  2. CDC: Meningitis

Meniere’s Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Meniere’s disease is a disorder of the inner ear characterized by episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss.

**Meniere’s Disease** involves abnormal fluid accumulation in the inner ear, leading to symptoms such as vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss. Causes:

  • Abnormal fluid dynamics in the inner ear
  • Genetic and environmental factors
Symptoms:
  • Recurrent vertigo attacks and imbalance
  • Tinnitus and hearing loss
  • Sensation of fullness in the ear
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation, audiometric tests, and vestibular assessments
Treatment:
  • Medications to control vertigo and nausea
  • Dietary changes and lifestyle adjustments
  • In some cases, surgical interventions
References:
  1. NHS: Meniere’s Disease
  2. Mayo Clinic: Meniere’s Disease

Menopause: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Menopause is a natural transition marking the end of menstruation in women, accompanied by various hormonal changes.

**Menopause** is the stage in a woman's life when menstrual cycles cease due to a decline in ovarian function and hormone production. Causes:

  • Natural aging and decline in estrogen production
Symptoms:
  • Hot flashes, night sweats, and mood swings
  • Irregular periods and vaginal dryness
  • Sleep disturbances and fatigue
Diagnosis:
  • Based on clinical symptoms and menstrual history
Management:
  • Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and non-hormonal alternatives
  • Lifestyle modifications and supportive counseling
References:
  1. NHS: Menopause
  2. Mayo Clinic: Menopause

Mesothelioma: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Mesothelioma is a rare, aggressive cancer most often affecting the lining of the lungs due to asbestos exposure.

**Mesothelioma** is a cancer that develops in the mesothelial cells lining the lungs, abdomen, or heart, typically linked to asbestos exposure. Causes:

  • Prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers
  • Occupational hazards in construction, shipbuilding, or manufacturing
Symptoms:
  • Chest pain and shortness of breath
  • Persistent cough and fatigue
  • Unexplained weight loss
Diagnosis:
  • Imaging tests (CT scan, X-ray, MRI)
  • Biopsy for histopathological confirmation
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy
  • Palliative care for symptom management
References:
  1. NHS: Mesothelioma
  2. American Cancer Society: Mesothelioma

Metacarpal Fracture: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A metacarpal fracture is a break in one of the hand bones, commonly caused by trauma or falls.

**Metacarpal Fracture** refers to a break in one of the five bones of the hand (metacarpals), often resulting from a direct impact or fall. Causes:

  • Direct trauma or impact (e.g., sports injuries, falls)
  • Accidents or heavy object impact on the hand
Symptoms:
  • Severe pain and swelling in the hand
  • Bruising and difficulty in grasping objects
  • Visible deformity or tenderness along the hand
Diagnosis:
  • X-rays and physical examination
Treatment:
  • Immobilization with a splint or cast
  • Surgical repair for displaced fractures
  • Physical therapy during recovery
References:
  1. NHS: Fractures
  2. AAOS: Metacarpal Fractures

Middle Ear Infection (Otitis Media): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Otitis media is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear, common in children but also affecting adults.

**Otitis Media** is an infection of the middle ear that causes pain, fever, and sometimes hearing loss. Causes:

  • Viral or bacterial infections, often following a cold
  • Eustachian tube dysfunction
Symptoms:
  • Ear pain and a feeling of fullness
  • Fever and irritability
  • Temporary hearing difficulties
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination with an otoscope
  • Assessment of symptoms
Treatment:
  • Antibiotics for bacterial infections
  • Pain relievers and warm compresses
References:
  1. NHS: Ear Infections
  2. Mayo Clinic: Otitis Media

Migraine: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Migraine is a neurological condition characterized by severe, recurring headaches often accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light.

**Migraine** is a common, chronic neurological disorder marked by intense headache episodes, often with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition and environmental triggers
  • Hormonal changes, stress, and certain foods
Symptoms:
  • Throbbing headache, often on one side of the head
  • Nausea, vomiting, and visual disturbances (aura)
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and headache history
  • Exclusion of other causes through imaging if necessary
Treatment:
  • Medications such as triptans, analgesics, and preventive therapies
  • Lifestyle modifications and trigger avoidance
References:
  1. NHS: Migraine
  2. Mayo Clinic: Migraine

Minor Head Injury: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Minor head injuries, such as concussions, are common and usually resolve with rest, though they require proper evaluation.

**Minor Head Injury** typically refers to a concussion or mild traumatic brain injury resulting from a blow to the head. Causes:

  • Falls, sports injuries, or minor accidents
  • Occasional impact during daily activities
Symptoms:
  • Headache, dizziness, and confusion
  • Brief loss of consciousness or memory gaps
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and neurological assessment
  • Imaging tests (CT/MRI) if symptoms persist
Treatment:
  • Rest and gradual return to activities
  • Pain relief and monitoring for worsening symptoms
References:
  1. NHS: Concussion
  2. Mayo Clinic: Concussion

Miscarriage: Causes, Symptoms & Management

A miscarriage is the loss of a pregnancy before 20 weeks, often due to chromosomal abnormalities or other factors.

**Miscarriage** refers to the spontaneous loss of a pregnancy before 20 weeks gestation, commonly due to chromosomal abnormalities. Causes:

  • Genetic or chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus
  • Hormonal imbalances and uterine abnormalities
Symptoms:
  • Vaginal bleeding and abdominal cramping
  • Passage of tissue
Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound and blood tests (hCG levels)
Treatment:
  • Expectant management or medical/surgical intervention if incomplete
  • Counseling and supportive care
References:
  1. NHS: Miscarriage
  2. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists

Molar Pregnancy: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Molar pregnancy is a rare complication where abnormal tissue grows in the uterus instead of a viable embryo.

**Molar Pregnancy** is a gestational trophoblastic disease caused by abnormal fertilization, resulting in a non-viable pregnancy characterized by excessive trophoblastic tissue. Causes:

  • Abnormal fertilization leading to a hydatidiform mole
  • Risk factors include advanced maternal age
Symptoms:
  • Vaginal bleeding and rapid uterine growth
  • Excessively high hCG levels
  • Nausea and early preeclampsia
Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound imaging and hCG blood tests
  • Histopathological examination following tissue removal
Treatment:
  • Dilation and curettage (D&C) to remove abnormal tissue
  • Follow-up monitoring of hCG levels
References:
  1. NHS: Molar Pregnancy
  2. Mayo Clinic: Molar Pregnancy

Motor Neurone Disease (MND): Causes, Symptoms & Management

MND is a progressive neurological disorder affecting motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and disability.

**Motor Neurone Disease (MND)** is a group of disorders characterized by the gradual degeneration of motor neurons, which control voluntary muscles. Causes:

  • Genetic mutations and environmental influences
  • Abnormal protein accumulation in neurons
Symptoms:
  • Progressive muscle weakness and twitching
  • Difficulty speaking, swallowing, and breathing
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and electromyography (EMG)
  • Exclusion of other neurological conditions
Management:
  • Multidisciplinary supportive care and symptom relief (e.g., riluzole)
  • Physical and occupational therapy
References:
  1. NHS: Motor Neurone Disease
  2. Motor Neurone Disease Association

Mouth Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Mouth cancer develops in the oral cavity, often linked to tobacco, alcohol, and HPV infection.

**Mouth Cancer** refers to malignant growths in the mouth, including the lips, tongue, and gums. Major risk factors include tobacco use, alcohol consumption, and HPV. Causes:

  • Tobacco and alcohol use
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection
  • Excessive sun exposure (for lip cancer)
Symptoms:
  • Pain, lumps, or ulcers in the mouth
  • Difficulty swallowing or speaking
  • Unexplained weight loss and persistent sore throat
Diagnosis:
  • Biopsy and imaging (CT, MRI)
  • Clinical examination by an oral surgeon
Treatment:
  • Surgical removal, radiation, and chemotherapy
  • Reconstructive surgery if needed
References:
  1. NHS: Mouth Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society: Mouth Cancer

Mouth Ulcer: Causes, Symptoms & Home Remedies

Mouth ulcers are small, painful sores inside the mouth that can result from stress, injury, or nutritional deficiencies.

**Mouth Ulcer** is a common condition characterized by a small, shallow sore in the mouth. It is usually benign and self-limiting. Causes:

  • Minor trauma from dental work or biting
  • Stress and hormonal fluctuations
  • Nutritional deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12, folate)
Symptoms:
  • Painful, red lesions inside the mouth
  • Difficulty eating or speaking if severe
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination by a healthcare provider
Treatment:
  • Topical treatments and over‑the‑counter pain relievers
  • Avoiding irritant foods
  • Improved nutrition and stress management
References:
  1. NHS: Mouth Ulcers
  2. Mayo Clinic: Aphthous Ulcers

Multiple Myeloma: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells that disrupts normal blood cell production and causes bone pain.

**Multiple Myeloma** is a type of blood cancer that affects plasma cells in the bone marrow, leading to bone lesions, anemia, and immune dysfunction. Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition and abnormal plasma cell proliferation
Symptoms:
  • Bone pain, especially in the back and ribs
  • Fatigue, frequent infections, and weight loss
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests (e.g., serum protein electrophoresis)
  • Bone marrow biopsy and imaging studies
Treatment:
  • Chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and stem cell transplant
  • Supportive care for bone health
References:
  1. NHS: Multiple Myeloma
  2. American Cancer Society: Multiple Myeloma

Multiple Sclerosis (MS): Causes, Symptoms & Management

MS is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, leading to neurological impairments.

**Multiple Sclerosis (MS)** is a chronic autoimmune condition where the immune system attacks the myelin sheath in the central nervous system. Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition and environmental triggers
  • Immune-mediated demyelination
Symptoms:
  • Muscle weakness, coordination issues, and visual disturbances
  • Fatigue and sensory changes
Diagnosis:
  • MRI, lumbar puncture, and evoked potentials
Treatment:
  • Disease-modifying therapies, steroids for relapses, and symptom management
References:
  1. NHS: Multiple Sclerosis
  2. National MS Society

Multiple System Atrophy (MSA): Causes, Symptoms & Management

MSA is a rare neurodegenerative disorder affecting autonomic and motor functions, leading to complex symptoms.

**Multiple System Atrophy (MSA)** is a progressive neurological disorder characterized by autonomic dysfunction, parkinsonism, and cerebellar ataxia. Causes:

  • Abnormal accumulation of alpha-synuclein protein in the brain
  • Primarily sporadic with no clear genetic link
Symptoms:
  • Autonomic failure (e.g., blood pressure fluctuations)
  • Motor impairments similar to Parkinson’s disease
  • Balance and coordination difficulties
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation, MRI, and autonomic testing
Treatment:
  • Symptomatic treatment and supportive care
  • Multidisciplinary approach to improve quality of life
References:
  1. NHS: Multiple System Atrophy
  2. Atkinson Institute for MSA

Mumps: Causes, Symptoms & Prevention

Mumps is a viral infection that primarily affects the salivary glands, causing swelling and pain.

**Mumps** is a contagious viral illness characterized by swelling of the parotid glands, often accompanied by fever and muscle aches. Causes:

  • Infection with the mumps virus, spread through respiratory droplets
Symptoms:
  • Swelling and pain in the cheeks and jaw
  • Fever, headache, and muscle aches
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and serological tests
Treatment:
  • Supportive care including pain relief and hydration
Prevention:
  • MMR vaccination to prevent mumps
References:
  1. NHS: Mumps
  2. CDC: Mumps

Munchausen’s Syndrome: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Munchausen’s syndrome is a factitious disorder where individuals deliberately produce or exaggerate symptoms for attention.

**Munchausen’s Syndrome** is a psychiatric disorder in which a person repeatedly acts as if they have a physical or mental illness, often seeking treatment and sympathy. Causes:

  • Psychological factors such as a need for attention or care
  • Underlying personality disorders
Symptoms:
  • Frequent hospital visits and invasive procedures
  • Inconsistent medical history
Diagnosis:
  • Thorough psychiatric evaluation
  • Review of medical records
Treatment:
  • Psychotherapy and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
  • Long-term psychiatric care
References:
  1. NHS: Factitious Disorder
  2. APA: Factitious Disorders

Muscular Dystrophy: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Muscular dystrophy is a group of genetic disorders characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness.

**Muscular Dystrophy** refers to a collection of inherited disorders that cause progressive weakness and loss of muscle mass. Causes:

  • Genetic mutations affecting muscle proteins
  • Inherited patterns of transmission
Symptoms:
  • Progressive muscle weakness and wasting
  • Difficulty walking and performing daily tasks
Diagnosis:
  • Genetic testing and muscle biopsy
  • Electromyography (EMG)
Management:
  • Physical therapy and assistive devices
  • Medications to slow progression and manage symptoms
References:
  1. NHS: Muscular Dystrophy
  2. Muscular Dystrophy Association

ME/CFS: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME) or chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) is a complex disorder characterized by profound, persistent fatigue.

**Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (ME) / Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)** is a debilitating condition marked by extreme fatigue that is not improved by rest, along with cognitive and physical symptoms. Causes:

  • Unknown; possible triggers include viral infections and immune dysfunction
Symptoms:
  • Persistent fatigue and post-exertional malaise
  • Cognitive difficulties and unrefreshing sleep
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and exclusion of other conditions
Management:
  • Graded exercise therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)
  • Medications for symptom relief
References:
  1. NHS: CFS/ME
  2. CDC: ME/CFS

Myasthenia Gravis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder causing weakness in voluntary muscles, often impacting eye and facial muscles.

**Myasthenia Gravis** is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder in which antibodies disrupt the communication between nerves and muscles. Causes:

  • Autoimmune attack on acetylcholine receptors
  • Genetic and environmental factors
Symptoms:
  • Muscle weakness, especially in the eyes, face, and throat
  • Fatigability with repeated use
Diagnosis:
  • Antibody blood tests and electrodiagnostic studies (EMG)
Treatment:
  • Medications such as anticholinesterases and immunosuppressants
  • Plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) in severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Myasthenia Gravis
  2. Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of America

Nasal & Sinus Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Nasal and sinus cancer are rare malignancies often linked to occupational exposures and environmental factors.

**Nasal and Sinus Cancer** refers to malignant tumors developing in the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses, often associated with chemical exposures. Causes:

  • Exposure to industrial chemicals like wood dust or leather dust
  • Smoking and environmental pollutants
Symptoms:
  • Nasal obstruction, pain, or bleeding
  • Facial swelling and sinus pressure
Diagnosis:
  • Imaging (CT, MRI) and biopsy
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection and radiation therapy
  • Chemotherapy in advanced cases
References:
  1. NHS: Nasal Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society

Nasopharyngeal Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Nasopharyngeal cancer is a malignant tumor arising in the nasopharynx, with higher prevalence in certain regions.

**Nasopharyngeal Cancer** is a type of head and neck cancer that develops in the upper part of the throat behind the nose. Causes:

  • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection
  • Genetic and environmental factors
Symptoms:
  • Neck mass, nasal obstruction, and ear problems
  • Frequent nosebleeds and headaches
Diagnosis:
  • Imaging studies and biopsy
Treatment:
  • Radiation therapy and chemotherapy
  • Surgical interventions in select cases
References:
  1. NHS: Nasopharyngeal Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society

Neck Injury: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Neck injuries can occur from trauma or overuse, leading to pain and restricted mobility.

**Neck Injury** refers to trauma to the cervical spine or surrounding soft tissues, which may result from accidents, falls, or sports injuries. Causes:

  • Trauma such as whiplash from car accidents
  • Overuse or repetitive strain
Symptoms:
  • Neck pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion
  • Headaches and sometimes numbness in the arms
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination and imaging (X-ray, MRI)
Treatment:
  • Rest, pain management, and physical therapy
  • Surgical intervention for severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Neck Pain
  2. AAOS: Neck Injuries

Neck Problems: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Neck problems encompass a range of conditions from muscle strain to degenerative disc disease, affecting mobility and comfort.

**Neck Problems** can include muscle strain, cervical spondylosis, or herniated discs, leading to pain and reduced mobility. Causes:

  • Poor posture and repetitive strain
  • Degenerative changes in the cervical spine
Symptoms:
  • Chronic neck pain and stiffness
  • Headaches and radiating arm pain
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination and imaging studies (X-ray, MRI)
Management:
  • Physical therapy, pain relievers, and ergonomic adjustments
References:
  1. NHS: Neck Pain
  2. Mayo Clinic: Neck Pain

Neuroblastoma in Children: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Neuroblastoma is a childhood cancer that develops in the sympathetic nervous system, often presenting as an abdominal mass.

**Neuroblastoma** is a cancer that forms in nerve tissue, most commonly affecting children under the age of 5. It typically originates in the adrenal glands or along the sympathetic chain. Causes:

  • Genetic mutations and developmental abnormalities
  • Mostly sporadic, with a small percentage having a familial link
Symptoms:
  • Abdominal pain and a palpable mass
  • Weight loss, fever, and bone pain in advanced cases
Diagnosis:
  • Imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI) and biopsy
  • Urine and blood tests for catecholamines
Treatment:
  • Chemotherapy, surgery, and radiation therapy
  • Stem cell transplant in high-risk cases
References:
  1. NHS: Neuroblastoma
  2. American Cancer Society: Neuroblastoma

Neuroendocrine Tumours: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Neuroendocrine tumours (NETs) are cancers arising from hormone-producing cells that can occur in various organs.

**Neuroendocrine Tumours (NETs)** are a diverse group of malignancies originating from neuroendocrine cells found throughout the body, including the gastrointestinal tract, lungs, and pancreas. Causes:

  • Genetic mutations and sporadic errors in cell division
  • Possible environmental triggers
Symptoms:
  • Abdominal pain, flushing, and diarrhea (when functional)
  • Often asymptomatic until advanced
Diagnosis:
  • Imaging (CT, MRI, PET scans) and biopsy
  • Blood and urine tests for hormonal markers
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection when possible
  • Targeted therapies, chemotherapy, and somatostatin analogues
References:
  1. NHS: Neuroendocrine Tumours
  2. American Cancer Society: NETs

Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD): Causes, Symptoms & Management

NAFLD is the buildup of excess fat in the liver not caused by alcohol, often linked to obesity and metabolic syndrome.

**Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD)** is characterized by excess fat deposition in the liver, which can progress to inflammation (NASH) and eventually cirrhosis. Causes:

  • Obesity, insulin resistance, and metabolic syndrome
  • High-fat diets and sedentary lifestyles
Symptoms:
  • Often asymptomatic in early stages
  • Fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and elevated liver enzymes
Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound imaging and blood tests
  • Liver biopsy in uncertain cases
Management:
  • Weight loss, dietary changes, and exercise
  • Managing diabetes and cholesterol levels
References:
  1. NHS: NAFLD
  2. Mayo Clinic: NAFLD

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is a diverse group of blood cancers affecting the lymphatic system, with various subtypes and treatment options.

**Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL)** is a type of cancer that originates in lymphocytes. Its presentation varies from indolent to aggressive forms. Causes:

  • Genetic factors and immune system dysregulation
  • Exposure to chemicals or certain viruses
Symptoms:
  • Painless swelling of lymph nodes
  • Fever, night sweats, and weight loss
Diagnosis:
  • Biopsy and imaging studies (CT, PET scans)
Treatment:
  • Chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and sometimes radiation
  • Stem cell transplant in advanced cases
References:
  1. NHS: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
  2. American Cancer Society: NHL

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma in Children: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Pediatric non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a rare cancer affecting children’s lymphatic systems with specialized treatment protocols.

**Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma in Children** is a cancer of the lymphatic system that occurs in pediatric patients. Its presentation may differ from adult forms, requiring tailored treatment. Causes:

  • Genetic and developmental factors
  • Immune system differences in children
Symptoms:
  • Rapidly enlarging lymph nodes
  • Fever, fatigue, and weight loss
Diagnosis:
  • Biopsy, imaging, and blood tests
Treatment:
  • Pediatric chemotherapy protocols and sometimes radiation therapy
References:
  1. NHS: Childhood Lymphoma
  2. American Cancer Society: Childhood Lymphoma

Norovirus: Causes, Symptoms & Prevention

Norovirus is a highly contagious virus that causes gastroenteritis, leading to vomiting and diarrhea.

**Norovirus** is a leading cause of acute gastroenteritis, transmitted through contaminated food, water, or contact with infected individuals. Causes:

  • Infection with the norovirus
  • Close contact in communal settings
Symptoms:
  • Vomiting, watery diarrhea, and abdominal cramps
  • Fever and headache
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and laboratory tests during outbreaks
Treatment:
  • Supportive care with hydration and rest
  • No specific antiviral treatment available
Prevention:
  • Frequent handwashing and proper food hygiene
  • Avoidance of contaminated water and close contact during outbreaks
References:
  1. NHS: Norovirus
  2. CDC: Norovirus

Nosebleed: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Nosebleeds (epistaxis) are common and can result from dry air, injury, or underlying health issues.

**Nosebleed** is the spontaneous rupture of blood vessels in the nasal cavity, often causing bleeding from one or both nostrils. Causes:

  • Dry air and environmental irritants
  • Nasal injury or frequent nose picking
  • Underlying bleeding disorders or high blood pressure
Symptoms:
  • Bleeding from one or both nostrils
  • Nasal congestion or a sensation of fullness
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination by a healthcare provider
  • Nasal endoscopy if recurrent or severe
Management:
  • Pinching the nostrils and applying cold compresses
  • Cauterization or nasal packing in persistent cases
References:
  1. NHS: Nosebleeds
  2. Mayo Clinic: Nosebleeds

Obesity: Causes, Health Risks & Management

Obesity is a complex condition characterized by excessive body fat that increases the risk of numerous health issues.

**Obesity** is defined by an excessive accumulation of body fat, often determined by a high body mass index (BMI). It is associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes, heart disease, and joint problems. Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition, poor diet, and lack of physical activity
  • Environmental and psychological factors
Symptoms:
  • Excess weight, fatigue, and breathlessness during exertion
  • Increased risk of metabolic and cardiovascular disorders
Diagnosis:
  • Body mass index (BMI) calculation and clinical evaluation
Management:
  • Dietary modifications, regular exercise, and behavioral therapy
  • Medications or surgical interventions in selected cases
References:
  1. NHS: Obesity
  2. CDC: Obesity

Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

OCD is a mental health disorder characterized by intrusive thoughts and repetitive behaviors that interfere with daily life.

**Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD)** is marked by persistent, unwanted obsessions and compulsions. These can significantly impact an individual's functioning and quality of life. Causes:

  • Genetic, neurological, and environmental factors
  • Abnormalities in brain circuits related to anxiety
Symptoms:
  • Intrusive, repetitive thoughts and behaviors performed to alleviate anxiety
  • Time-consuming rituals that disrupt daily activities
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and standardized psychological assessments
Treatment:
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and exposure-response prevention (ERP)
  • Antidepressant medications such as SSRIs
References:
  1. NHS: OCD
  2. Mayo Clinic: OCD

Obstructive Sleep Apnoea: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Obstructive sleep apnoea is a sleep disorder characterized by repeated breathing interruptions during sleep due to airway obstruction.

**Obstructive Sleep Apnoea (OSA)** occurs when the muscles in the throat relax excessively during sleep, causing temporary airway blockage. This leads to disrupted sleep and reduced oxygen levels. Causes:

  • Obesity, enlarged tonsils, or anatomical differences in the airway
  • Age-related muscle relaxation
Symptoms:
  • Loud snoring and pauses in breathing during sleep
  • Daytime fatigue, morning headaches, and irritability
Diagnosis:
  • Sleep studies (polysomnography) and clinical evaluation
Management:
  • Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) therapy
  • Lifestyle modifications, weight loss, and sometimes surgery
References:
  1. NHS: Sleep Apnoea
  2. Sleep Foundation: Sleep Apnoea

Oesophageal Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Oesophageal cancer is a malignancy affecting the oesophagus, often linked to risk factors such as smoking, alcohol, and chronic acid reflux.

**Oesophageal Cancer** affects the tube that carries food from the throat to the stomach. It is often associated with long-term acid reflux, smoking, and heavy alcohol use. Causes:

  • Chronic gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and Barrett’s oesophagus
  • Tobacco use and excessive alcohol consumption
Symptoms:
  • Difficulty swallowing and unintentional weight loss
  • Persistent heartburn and chest pain
Diagnosis:
  • Endoscopy with biopsy and imaging studies
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy
References:
  1. NHS: Oesophageal Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society: Oesophageal Cancer

Oral Thrush in Adults: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Oral thrush is a fungal infection of the mouth, often occurring in immunocompromised individuals or those using inhaled steroids.

**Oral Thrush** is a fungal infection caused by Candida species. It typically presents as white patches inside the mouth and may be associated with soreness and difficulty swallowing. Causes:

  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids, antibiotic use, or immunosuppression
Symptoms:
  • White, cottage cheese-like lesions on the tongue and inner cheeks
  • Redness and soreness in the mouth
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and sometimes swab tests
Treatment:
  • Antifungal medications and improved oral hygiene
References:
  1. NHS: Oral Thrush
  2. Mayo Clinic: Oral Thrush

Osteoarthritis: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease marked by the breakdown of cartilage, leading to pain and reduced mobility.

**Osteoarthritis** is a chronic condition where the protective cartilage cushioning the joints deteriorates over time, resulting in joint pain, stiffness, and reduced flexibility. Causes:

  • Age-related wear and tear, obesity, and joint injuries
Symptoms:
  • Joint pain and stiffness, especially after periods of inactivity
  • Swelling and reduced range of motion
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and imaging (X-ray, MRI)
Management:
  • Physical therapy, exercise, and pain relievers
  • Weight management and sometimes joint replacement surgery
References:
  1. NHS: Osteoarthritis
  2. Mayo Clinic: Osteoarthritis

Osteoarthritis of the Hip: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Osteoarthritis of the hip is a degenerative joint disease causing pain, stiffness, and reduced mobility in the hip joint.

**Osteoarthritis of the Hip** is a chronic condition where the cartilage in the hip joint deteriorates, leading to pain and limited movement. Causes:

  • Age-related degeneration, obesity, and prior hip injuries
Symptoms:
  • Hip pain, stiffness, and difficulty walking
  • Reduced range of motion and joint swelling
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical assessment and imaging studies (X-ray, MRI)
Treatment:
  • Conservative management including physical therapy and pain relief
  • Surgical options such as hip replacement in severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Hip Osteoarthritis
  2. Mayo Clinic: Hip Osteoarthritis

Osteoarthritis of the Knee: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Osteoarthritis of the knee is a degenerative joint disease causing pain, stiffness, and limited mobility.

**Osteoarthritis of the Knee** is a chronic condition where the cartilage in the knee gradually wears away.

Causes:

  • Age-related wear and tear
  • Previous knee injuries and obesity
Symptoms:
  • Knee pain and stiffness, especially after rest
  • Swelling and reduced range of motion
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and X-rays
Management:
  • Physical therapy, pain relievers, and weight management
  • Surgical options for severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Osteoarthritis
  2. Mayo Clinic: Osteoarthritis

Osteoarthritis of the Thumb: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Osteoarthritis of the thumb affects the base joint, causing pain, reduced grip strength, and difficulty with pinching.

**Osteoarthritis of the Thumb** (trapeziometacarpal arthritis) is a degenerative joint condition at the base of the thumb.

Causes:

  • Age-related wear and repetitive use
  • Previous injuries to the thumb
Symptoms:
  • Thumb pain, especially when grasping or pinching
  • Swelling and reduced hand function
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination and X-rays
Management:
  • Splinting, anti-inflammatory medications, and sometimes surgery
References:
  1. NHS: Osteoarthritis
  2. Mayo Clinic: Osteoarthritis

Osteoporosis: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by low bone density and increased fracture risk, often affecting older adults.

**Osteoporosis** is a systemic skeletal disorder marked by diminished bone density and strength, increasing the risk of fractures.

Causes:

  • Aging, hormonal changes, and nutritional deficiencies
Symptoms:
  • Often asymptomatic until a fracture occurs
  • Bone pain and fractures with minimal trauma
Diagnosis:
  • Bone mineral density test (DEXA scan)
Management:
  • Calcium and vitamin D supplementation, exercise, and medications
References:
  1. NHS: Osteoporosis
  2. National Osteoporosis Foundation

Osteosarcoma: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Osteosarcoma is an aggressive bone cancer most commonly affecting teenagers and young adults, usually involving long bones.

**Osteosarcoma** is a primary malignant bone tumor typically arising in the metaphysis of long bones in adolescents and young adults.

Causes:

  • Genetic mutations and rapid bone growth during adolescence
Symptoms:
  • Localized bone pain and swelling
  • Risk of pathological fractures
Diagnosis:
  • Imaging (X-ray, MRI, CT) and biopsy for confirmation
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection and chemotherapy, sometimes radiation therapy
References:
  1. NHS: Bone Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society: Osteosarcoma

Outer Ear Infection (Otitis Externa): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Otitis externa is an infection of the external ear canal, commonly seen in swimmers, causing pain and swelling.

**Otitis Externa** is an infection of the outer ear canal, often referred to as "swimmer's ear."

Causes:

  • Moist environments promoting bacterial growth
  • Trauma or insertion of objects into the ear
Symptoms:
  • Ear pain, itching, and discharge
  • Redness and swelling of the ear canal
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination using an otoscope
Treatment:
  • Topical antibiotic and steroid drops
  • Ear cleaning and keeping the ear dry
References:
  1. NHS: Ear Infections
  2. Mayo Clinic: Otitis Externa

Ovarian Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Ovarian cancer is a malignancy of the ovary, often diagnosed at a later stage due to vague early symptoms.

**Ovarian Cancer** is a cancer that forms in ovarian tissues. It is often asymptomatic until advanced, with symptoms like abdominal pain, bloating, and menstrual irregularities.

Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition and hormonal factors
Symptoms:
  • Abdominal bloating, pelvic pain, and urinary changes
Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound, CA-125 blood test, and biopsy
Treatment:
  • Surgery, chemotherapy, and targeted therapy
References:
  1. NHS: Ovarian Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society: Ovarian Cancer

Ovarian Cancer in Teenagers & Young Adults: Overview & Management

Ovarian cancer in younger women is rare and may have distinct clinical features, requiring specialized treatment.

**Ovarian Cancer in Teenagers & Young Adults** is uncommon and often presents with non-specific symptoms. Early detection is crucial for effective management.

Causes:

  • Genetic predispositions and developmental factors
Symptoms:
  • Abdominal pain, bloating, and menstrual irregularities
Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound and blood tests, followed by biopsy if needed
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection and chemotherapy tailored for younger patients
References:
  1. NHS: Ovarian Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society

Overactive Thyroid: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

An overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism) results in excessive hormone production, leading to symptoms such as weight loss, anxiety, and palpitations.

**Overactive Thyroid (Hyperthyroidism)** is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone.

Causes:

  • Graves’ disease, thyroid nodules, or thyroiditis
Symptoms:
  • Weight loss, rapid heartbeat, tremors, and heat intolerance
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests for TSH and thyroid hormone levels
Treatment:
  • Antithyroid medications, radioactive iodine, or surgery
References:
  1. NHS: Hyperthyroidism
  2. Mayo Clinic: Hyperthyroidism

Pain in the Ball of the Foot: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Discomfort in the ball of the foot can result from overuse, injury, or underlying foot conditions.

**Pain in the Ball of the Foot** often refers to pain in the metatarsal area, sometimes known as metatarsalgia. It may arise from excessive pressure, injury, or biomechanical imbalances.

Causes:

  • Overuse from high-impact activities
  • Improper footwear or foot biomechanics
  • Stress fractures or nerve compression
Symptoms:
  • Sharp or aching pain in the ball of the foot
  • Bloating or swelling in the forefoot
  • Difficulty walking or standing for long periods
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and foot examination
  • Imaging studies such as X-rays if needed
Treatment:
  • Rest, ice, and proper footwear
  • Physical therapy and orthotics
  • Medication for pain relief
References:
  1. NHS: Foot Pain
  2. Mayo Clinic: Foot Pain

Paget’s Disease of the Nipple: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

A rare form of breast cancer affecting the nipple, often presenting with eczema-like changes.

**Paget’s Disease of the Nipple** is a rare condition often associated with underlying breast cancer. It typically presents as persistent redness, scaling, and itching of the nipple and areola.

Causes:

  • Abnormal cell changes associated with breast cancer
  • Hormonal and genetic factors
Symptoms:
  • Eczematous changes and scaling of the nipple
  • Pain, burning, and discharge
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and biopsy
Treatment:
  • Surgical removal of affected tissue and possible adjunct therapy
References:
  1. NHS: Breast Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society: Breast Cancer

Pancreatic Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Pancreatic cancer is an aggressive malignancy of the pancreas with often vague early symptoms.

**Pancreatic Cancer** is a malignant tumour of the pancreas, often diagnosed at an advanced stage due to subtle early symptoms.

Causes:

  • Smoking, obesity, and chronic pancreatitis
  • Genetic predispositions and environmental factors
Symptoms:
  • Abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice
  • Loss of appetite and fatigue
Diagnosis:
  • Imaging (CT, MRI) and biopsy
Treatment:
  • Surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy
References:
  1. NHS: Pancreatic Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society: Pancreatic Cancer

Panic Disorder: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Panic disorder is an anxiety condition marked by sudden, intense episodes of fear and physical symptoms.

**Panic Disorder** is an anxiety disorder characterized by recurrent panic attacks and persistent worry about future attacks.

Causes:

  • Genetic, biological, and environmental factors
  • Abnormalities in brain function related to anxiety
Symptoms:
  • Sudden episodes of intense fear, heart palpitations, and sweating
  • Shortness of breath, dizziness, and chest pain
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and psychological assessments
Treatment:
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and exposure therapy
  • Antidepressant medications (SSRIs)
References:
  1. NHS: Panic Disorder
  2. Mayo Clinic: Panic Disorder

Parkinson’s Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by tremors, stiffness, and bradykinesia.

**Parkinson’s Disease** is a progressive neurological disorder marked by motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and slowed movement, along with non-motor symptoms.

Causes:

  • Loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the brain
  • Genetic and environmental factors
Symptoms:
  • Tremor, muscle stiffness, and slow movement
  • Postural instability and cognitive changes
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and neurological examination
  • Imaging and response to dopaminergic therapy
Management:
  • Medications such as levodopa and dopamine agonists
  • Physical therapy and supportive care
References:
  1. NHS: Parkinson’s Disease
  2. Parkinson’s Foundation

Patau’s Syndrome: Causes, Characteristics & Prognosis

Patau’s syndrome (trisomy 13) is a severe chromosomal disorder associated with multiple congenital anomalies and a poor prognosis.

**Patau’s Syndrome** is a chromosomal abnormality resulting from an extra copy of chromosome 13, leading to severe intellectual and physical disabilities.

Causes:

  • Non-disjunction during cell division resulting in trisomy 13
  • Advanced maternal age can be a risk factor
Characteristics:
  • Multiple congenital anomalies, including heart defects and brain abnormalities
  • Severe developmental delays
Prognosis:
  • High infant mortality with limited life expectancy
References:
  1. NHS: Trisomy 13 (Patau’s Syndrome)
  2. CDC: Trisomy 13

Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Patellofemoral pain syndrome causes anterior knee pain, often due to malalignment or overuse.

**Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome** is a common knee condition characterized by pain around the kneecap, frequently exacerbated by activities like climbing stairs or squatting.

Causes:

  • Overuse, malalignment, or muscle imbalances
  • Repetitive stress on the knee joint
Symptoms:
  • Anterolateral knee pain and discomfort
  • Worsening pain with activity or prolonged sitting
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and physical examination
  • Imaging studies if needed
Treatment:
  • Physical therapy and strengthening exercises
  • Rest, ice, and pain relievers
References:
  1. NHS: Knee Pain
  2. Mayo Clinic: Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an infection of the female reproductive organs, typically caused by sexually transmitted bacteria.

**Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)** is an infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, and other reproductive organs, often resulting from untreated sexually transmitted infections.

Causes:

  • Infections such as chlamydia and gonorrhea
Symptoms:
  • Lower abdominal pain, fever, and unusual vaginal discharge
  • Pain during intercourse
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination, pelvic ultrasound, and laboratory tests
Treatment:
  • Antibiotics and supportive care
References:
  1. NHS: PID
  2. CDC: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Pelvic Organ Prolapse: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Pelvic organ prolapse occurs when pelvic muscles weaken, allowing organs like the uterus or bladder to descend.

**Pelvic Organ Prolapse** is a condition in which the pelvic organs, such as the bladder, uterus, or rectum, descend due to weakened pelvic floor muscles.

Causes:

  • Childbirth, aging, and hormonal changes
  • Chronic straining and obesity
Symptoms:
  • Sensation of heaviness or bulging in the pelvic area
  • Urinary or bowel dysfunction
Diagnosis:
  • Pelvic examination and imaging if needed
Management:
  • Pelvic floor exercises, pessaries, or surgery in severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Pelvic Organ Prolapse
  2. Mayo Clinic: Pelvic Organ Prolapse

Penile Cancer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Penile cancer is a rare malignancy affecting the skin and tissues of the penis, often linked to HPV infection.

**Penile Cancer** is a rare type of cancer that typically affects the glans or foreskin. It is often associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, poor hygiene, and smoking.

Causes:

  • HPV infection
  • Smoking and poor hygiene
Symptoms:
  • Redness, lumps, or ulcers on the penis
  • Bleeding or foul-smelling discharge
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and biopsy
  • Imaging studies for staging
Treatment:
  • Surgical removal and possibly radiation or chemotherapy
References:
  1. NHS: Penile Cancer
  2. American Cancer Society: Penile Cancer

Peripheral Neuropathy: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Peripheral neuropathy involves damage to nerves, often causing pain, tingling, and numbness in the extremities.

**Peripheral Neuropathy** is a condition resulting from damage to the peripheral nerves. It is most commonly seen in patients with diabetes, but can also result from infections, toxins, or autoimmune disorders.

Causes:

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Alcohol abuse and exposure to toxins
  • Vitamin deficiencies or autoimmune disorders
Symptoms:
  • Tingling, numbness, and burning sensations in hands and feet
  • Muscle weakness and pain
Diagnosis:
  • Nerve conduction studies and blood tests
Treatment:
  • Pain management, physical therapy, and treating underlying causes
References:
  1. NHS: Peripheral Neuropathy
  2. Mayo Clinic: Peripheral Neuropathy

Personality Disorder: Overview, Symptoms & Treatment

Personality disorders are enduring patterns of behavior and inner experiences that deviate from cultural expectations.

**Personality Disorder** refers to a group of mental health conditions characterized by long-term, inflexible patterns of behavior and inner experiences that differ markedly from cultural norms.

Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition and environmental factors
  • Early childhood experiences and trauma
Symptoms:
  • Inflexible thinking, unstable interpersonal relationships, and emotional dysregulation
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical assessment and psychological evaluation
Treatment:
  • Psychotherapy (e.g., dialectical behavior therapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy)
  • Medications for associated symptoms
References:
  1. NHS: Personality Disorders
  2. APA: Personality Disorders

PIMS: Pediatric Inflammatory Multisystem Syndrome

PIMS, also known as MIS-C, is a rare but serious inflammatory condition affecting children following COVID-19 infection.

**PIMS (Pediatric Inflammatory Multisystem Syndrome)**, also called MIS-C, is an inflammatory condition seen in children after COVID-19. It involves persistent fever and inflammation affecting multiple organs.

Causes:

  • Post-infectious immune dysregulation following COVID-19
Symptoms:
  • High fever, abdominal pain, rash, and fatigue
  • Cardiac involvement in some cases
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation, blood tests, and imaging studies
Treatment:
  • Immunomodulatory therapies and supportive care
References:
  1. NHS: Long COVID (including PIMS)
  2. CDC: MIS-C

Plantar Heel Pain: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Plantar heel pain, often related to plantar fasciitis, causes discomfort in the heel, especially during the first steps of the day.

**Plantar Heel Pain** is typically a result of inflammation or degeneration of the plantar fascia—the thick band of tissue supporting the arch of the foot.

Causes:

  • Overuse, obesity, or improper footwear
  • Repetitive strain and foot biomechanics issues
Symptoms:
  • Sharp heel pain, especially in the morning or after prolonged sitting
  • Swelling and tenderness along the heel
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical examination and patient history
  • Imaging if necessary
Management:
  • Rest, ice, stretching exercises, and orthotics
  • Physical therapy and, in some cases, corticosteroid injections
References:
  1. NHS: Plantar Fasciitis
  2. Mayo Clinic: Plantar Fasciitis

Pleurisy: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Pleurisy is the inflammation of the pleural lining of the lungs, causing sharp chest pain during breathing.

**Pleurisy** is an inflammation of the pleura, the membrane surrounding the lungs, often causing sharp chest pain that worsens with breathing.

Causes:

  • Infections (viral, bacterial, or fungal)
  • Autoimmune conditions and pulmonary embolism
Symptoms:
  • Sharp chest pain, especially with deep breaths
  • Coughing and fever
Diagnosis:
  • Chest X-rays, ultrasound, and CT scans
Treatment:
  • Pain management and treating the underlying cause
References:
  1. NHS: Pleurisy
  2. Mayo Clinic: Pleurisy

Pneumonia: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Pneumonia is an infection of the lungs that can be caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi, leading to cough and fever.

**Pneumonia** is a lung infection that results in inflammation of the air sacs, which may fill with fluid. It can be caused by various pathogens.

Causes:

  • Bacterial, viral, or fungal infections
  • Underlying health conditions or immunosuppression
Symptoms:
  • Cough, fever, and difficulty breathing
  • Chest pain and fatigue
Diagnosis:
  • Chest X-ray and blood tests
Treatment:
  • Antibiotics (for bacterial pneumonia) and supportive care
References:
  1. NHS: Pneumonia
  2. CDC: Pneumonia

Polio: Causes, Symptoms & Prevention

Polio is a viral disease that can cause paralysis. It is preventable through vaccination.

**Polio (Poliomyelitis)** is an infectious disease caused by the poliovirus, which can lead to paralysis. Thanks to effective vaccination programs, polio has been nearly eradicated.

Causes:

  • Infection with the poliovirus
Symptoms:
  • Fever, sore throat, and fatigue
  • Paralysis in severe cases
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and laboratory tests (stool, blood tests)
Prevention:
  • Polio vaccination is key to prevention
References:
  1. NHS: Polio
  2. WHO: Polio

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Causes, Symptoms & Management

PCOS is a hormonal disorder affecting reproductive-age women, often causing irregular periods, excess androgen levels, and ovarian cysts.

**Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)** is an endocrine disorder marked by irregular menstrual cycles, high levels of androgens, and polycystic ovaries.

Causes:

  • Genetic predisposition and insulin resistance
  • Hormonal imbalances
Symptoms:
  • Irregular periods, weight gain, and acne
  • Hirsutism (excess hair growth)
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests and pelvic ultrasound
Management:
  • Lifestyle modifications, hormonal therapy, and insulin-sensitizing drugs
References:
  1. NHS: PCOS
  2. Mayo Clinic: PCOS

Polymyalgia Rheumatica: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Polymyalgia rheumatica is an inflammatory disorder causing muscle pain and stiffness, especially in the shoulders and hips.

**Polymyalgia Rheumatica** is an inflammatory condition, predominantly affecting older adults, marked by widespread muscle pain and morning stiffness.

Causes:

  • Exact cause unknown; likely immune-mediated
Symptoms:
  • Severe stiffness and pain in shoulders and hips
  • Difficulty rising in the morning
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and elevated inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP)
Treatment:
  • Corticosteroids and gradual tapering of doses
References:
  1. NHS: Polymyalgia Rheumatica
  2. Mayo Clinic: Polymyalgia Rheumatica

Post-Concussion Syndrome: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Post-concussion syndrome is characterized by persistent symptoms following a concussion, including headaches and cognitive difficulties.

**Post-Concussion Syndrome** occurs when concussion symptoms such as headache, dizziness, and cognitive impairments persist beyond the usual recovery period.

Causes:

  • Traumatic brain injury from impacts or blows to the head
Symptoms:
  • Headaches, dizziness, and memory problems
  • Fatigue and difficulty concentrating
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and neurological examination
Management:
  • Rest, gradual activity resumption, and cognitive rehabilitation
References:
  1. NHS: Concussion
  2. Mayo Clinic: Concussion

Post-Polio Syndrome: Causes, Symptoms & Management

Post-polio syndrome affects survivors of polio, leading to new muscle weakness, pain, and fatigue years after recovery.

**Post-Polio Syndrome** is a condition that can develop decades after a person has recovered from polio, characterized by renewed muscle weakness, fatigue, and pain.

Causes:

  • Degeneration of previously damaged motor neurons
Symptoms:
  • Muscle weakness, pain, and fatigue
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical history and neurological examination
Management:
  • Physical therapy, pain management, and assistive devices
References:
  1. NHS: Post-Polio Syndrome
  2. CDC: Polio

Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

PTSD is a mental health condition triggered by exposure to traumatic events, resulting in flashbacks, anxiety, and emotional distress.

**Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)** develops after exposure to a traumatic event. It is characterized by recurring flashbacks, nightmares, and severe anxiety.

Causes:

  • Exposure to traumatic events such as combat, abuse, or accidents
Symptoms:
  • Flashbacks, nightmares, and hyperarousal
  • Avoidance of trauma reminders and emotional numbness
Diagnosis:
  • Psychological evaluation and screening tools
Treatment:
  • Psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive-behavioral therapy) and medication
References:
  1. NHS: PTSD
  2. APA: PTSD

Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (PoTS): Causes, Symptoms & Management

PoTS is an autonomic disorder characterized by a rapid increase in heart rate upon standing, along with dizziness and fatigue.

**Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (PoTS)** is a disorder of the autonomic nervous system marked by an excessive heart rate increase upon standing.

Causes:

  • Autonomic dysfunction and possible genetic predisposition
Symptoms:
  • Dizziness, lightheadedness, and rapid heartbeat on standing
  • Fatigue and exercise intolerance
Diagnosis:
  • Tilt table test and clinical evaluation
Management:
  • Lifestyle modifications, increased fluid/salt intake, and medications
References:
  1. NHS: PoTS
  2. Mayo Clinic: PoTS

Postnatal Depression: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Postnatal depression is a mood disorder affecting new mothers, characterized by persistent sadness, anxiety, and fatigue.

**Postnatal Depression** is a type of depression that can occur after childbirth, affecting the mother's emotional and physical well-being.

Causes:

  • Hormonal changes and stress related to childbirth
  • Psychological and social factors
Symptoms:
  • Persistent sadness, anxiety, and irritability
  • Fatigue and changes in appetite
Diagnosis:
  • Clinical evaluation and screening questionnaires
Treatment:
  • Psychotherapy, medication, and support groups
References:
  1. NHS: Postnatal Depression
  2. Mind: Postnatal Depression

Pregnancy and Baby: Essential Health Tips & Expert Guidance

Comprehensive guidance for mothers-to-be, covering prenatal health, pregnancy wellness, delivery preparation, and newborn care.

**Pregnancy and Baby Care** is a holistic approach that ensures both the mother’s and baby’s health throughout pregnancy, childbirth, and the early months of life. From diet and exercise to emotional well-being and medical screenings, each phase plays a vital role.

Key Areas of Focus:

  • Nutrition and balanced diet during pregnancy
  • Routine antenatal check-ups and ultrasounds
  • Physical activity and safe exercises for pregnant women
  • Common symptoms management (morning sickness, fatigue, etc.)
Management Tips:
  • Follow medical advice for supplements (folic acid, iron, calcium)
  • Stay hydrated and eat small frequent meals
  • Attend prenatal education classes if possible
  • Ensure skin-to-skin contact after birth to promote bonding
Postpartum Care for Mothers:
  • Monitor for postpartum bleeding and infections
  • Rest and gradually resume physical activity
  • Seek help for emotional changes or signs of depression
Trusted References:
  1. NHS: Pregnancy and Baby
  2. American Pregnancy Association
  3. WHO: Pregnancy Care Guidance

Pressure Ulcers: Prevention and Treatment

Also known as bedsores, these are injuries to the skin and underlying tissue resulting from prolonged pressure.

Causes:

  • Prolonged pressure on the skin (e.g., from immobility)
  • Friction or shear forces
  • Poor nutrition and hydration
Symptoms:
  • Redness or discoloration of the skin
  • Pain or tenderness in the affected area
  • Open wounds or blisters in severe cases
Stages of Pressure Ulcers:
StageDescription
1Redness without broken skin
4Deep tissue damage with exposed bone or muscle
Treatment Options:
  • Wound care and dressings
  • Debridement of dead tissue
  • Surgery for severe cases
Prevention Strategies:
  • Regular repositioning (every 2 hours)
  • Use of pressure-relieving mattresses
  • Maintaining skin hygiene and moisture
References:
  1. NHS Guide
  2. Wounds International

Progressive Supranuclear Palsy: Symptoms and Management

A rare brain disorder causing problems with balance, movement, and vision.

Causes:

  • Abnormal accumulation of tau protein in the brain
  • Genetic mutations (rare)
  • Unknown environmental factors
Symptoms:
  • Loss of balance and frequent falls
  • Difficulty moving eyes (vertical gaze palsy)
  • Speech and swallowing difficulties
Diagnosis:
  • Neurological examination
  • MRI or CT scans
  • Assessment of eye movements
Management Strategies:
  • Physical therapy for mobility
  • Speech therapy for communication
  • Medications (e.g., levodopa for movement)
References:
  1. PSP Association
  2. National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

Prostate Cancer: Diagnosis and Treatment

A common cancer in men, often growing slowly and initially confined to the prostate gland.

Risk Factors:

  • Age (most common in men over 50)
  • Family history of prostate cancer
  • Ethnicity (higher risk in African-American men)
Symptoms:
  • Difficulty urinating
  • Blood in urine or semen
  • Pelvic pain or discomfort
Diagnostic Tools:
  • PSA blood test
  • Digital rectal exam (DRE)
  • Biopsy for confirmation
Treatment Options:
  • Active surveillance for low-risk cases
  • Surgery (prostatectomy)
  • Radiation therapy or hormone therapy
References:
  1. American Cancer Society
  2. NCCN Guidelines

Psoriasis: Causes and Treatment

A chronic autoimmune condition causing rapid skin cell buildup, leading to scaling and inflammation.

Causes:

  • Immune system dysfunction
  • Genetic predisposition
  • Environmental triggers (e.g., stress, infections)
Symptoms:
  • Red, scaly patches of skin
  • Itching or burning sensations
  • Thickened or pitted nails
Treatment Options:
  • Topical treatments (corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs)
  • Phototherapy (UV light treatment)
  • Biologic drugs (e.g., TNF inhibitors)
Lifestyle Management:
  • Moisturize skin regularly
  • Avoid triggers like stress and smoking
  • Follow a balanced diet
References:
  1. National Psoriasis Foundation
  2. American Academy of Dermatology

Psoriatic Arthritis: Symptoms and Management

A form of arthritis affecting some people with psoriasis, causing joint pain and swelling.

Causes:

  • Immune system attacking healthy joints
  • Genetic factors
  • Environmental triggers (e.g., infections)
Symptoms:
  • Joint pain and stiffness
  • Swollen fingers and toes (dactylitis)
  • Nail changes (pitting or separation)
Treatment Options:
  • NSAIDs for pain relief
  • DMARDs (e.g., methotrexate)
  • Biologic therapies (e.g., TNF inhibitors)
Lifestyle Tips:
  • Regular exercise to maintain joint mobility
  • Healthy diet to reduce inflammation
  • Stress management techniques
References:
  1. Arthritis Foundation
  2. NHS Guide

Psychosis: Symptoms, Causes & Treatment

Psychosis affects how your brain processes information, leading to hallucinations and delusions.

Psychosis is a mental health condition where individuals struggle to distinguish reality from imagination. It can be triggered by mental illness, trauma, substance abuse, or medical conditions.

Key Areas:

  • Symptoms: hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking
  • Causes: schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, severe stress, drug misuse
  • Treatment: antipsychotic medications, cognitive therapy, hospitalization (in severe cases)
Management:
  • Early diagnosis and intervention are key
  • Long-term support from mental health professionals
References:
  1. NHS: Psychosis

Pubic Lice (Crabs): Symptoms & Treatment

Pubic lice are small parasitic insects that infest hair in the genital area.

Pubic lice, also known as crabs, are tiny parasitic insects that primarily live in coarse body hair like pubic hair. They spread through close contact, especially sexual contact.

Key Areas:

  • Symptoms: intense itching, visible lice or eggs
  • Causes: direct body contact, sharing infested towels or bedding
  • Treatment: topical insecticides, washing clothes and bedding in hot water
Management:
  • Avoid close contact until fully treated
  • Notify sexual partners for mutual treatment
References:
  1. NHS: Pubic Lice

Pulmonary Hypertension: Causes & Management

A rare type of high blood pressure affecting arteries in the lungs and heart.

Pulmonary hypertension is a serious condition where blood pressure in the lungs' arteries becomes abnormally high, forcing the heart to work harder to pump blood.

Key Areas:

  • Symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness
  • Causes: lung disease, heart disease, genetics, autoimmune disorders
  • Treatment: medications (vasodilators), oxygen therapy, in some cases surgery
Management:
  • Regular medical monitoring and tests
  • Avoid high altitudes and strenuous physical activity
References:
  1. NHS: Pulmonary Hypertension

Phobias: Understanding & Managing Fears

Phobias are irrational, intense fears of specific situations, objects, or activities.

A phobia is a type of anxiety disorder where a person experiences extreme fear triggered by specific things—like flying, spiders, or social situations. Phobias can disrupt everyday life if not managed.

Key Areas:

  • Types: social phobia, specific phobia (heights, animals), agoraphobia
  • Causes: past trauma, learned behaviors, genetics
  • Treatment: cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), exposure therapy, relaxation techniques
Management:
  • Identifying triggers and gradual desensitization
  • Breathing exercises and mindfulness
References:
  1. NHS: Phobias

Rare Conditions: Causes, Symptoms & Care

Uncommon diseases that affect small populations, often needing specialized diagnosis and care.

Rare conditions (orphan diseases) impact fewer than 1 in 2,000 people. They can be genetic, autoimmune, metabolic, or infectious in nature.

Causes:

  • Genetic mutations
  • Environmental triggers
  • Unknown causes in many cases
Symptoms: Varies widely depending on condition but often involves chronic pain, organ dysfunction, or developmental delays.

Management:
  • Multidisciplinary specialist care
  • Supportive therapies
  • Genetic counseling
References:
  1. NIH: Rare Diseases

Rare Tumours: Types & Treatment

Tumours occurring in rare sites or with unusual cell types, needing expert diagnosis.

Rare tumours can occur in almost any organ but are defined by their low frequency, often resulting in delayed diagnosis.

Common Rare Tumours:

  • Thymic cancer
  • Adrenal gland tumours
  • Salivary gland cancers
Symptoms: Location-dependent, but may include pain, swelling, or organ dysfunction.

Management:
  • Specialist oncologist input
  • Tailored chemotherapy, surgery, or radiotherapy
References:
  1. NCI: Rare Cancers

Raynaud’s Phenomenon: Symptoms & Prevention

Vascular disorder triggered by cold or stress, affecting fingers and toes.

Raynaud's causes blood vessels to narrow excessively, reducing blood supply to extremities.

Causes:

  • Cold exposure
  • Emotional stress
  • Autoimmune conditions (secondary Raynaud’s)
Symptoms:
  • Colour changes (white, blue, red)
  • Numbness, tingling
  • Pain in affected areas
Prevention & Management:
  • Dress warmly in cold weather
  • Avoid smoking
  • Medications (calcium channel blockers)
References:
  1. NHS: Raynaud’s

Reactive Arthritis: Causes, Symptoms & Care

Inflammation following infections, affecting joints, eyes, and skin.

Reactive arthritis is triggered by bacterial infections, typically affecting the joints within 1-4 weeks after infection.

Causes: Gut, urinary tract, or genital infections.

Symptoms:

  • Joint pain and swelling
  • Red eyes (conjunctivitis)
  • Skin rashes (keratoderma blennorrhagicum)
Management:
  • Antibiotics (for infection)
  • Anti-inflammatory medication
  • Physical therapy
References:
  1. NHS: Reactive Arthritis

Retinoblastoma in Children: Early Signs & Treatment

A rare eye cancer affecting children, often detected through abnormal reflections in the pupil.

Retinoblastoma is a rare cancer developing in the retina, mostly in children under 5.

Causes:

  • Genetic mutations (RB1 gene)
  • Inherited in some cases
Symptoms:
  • White pupil reflex (leukocoria)
  • Strabismus (crossed eyes)
  • Redness or swelling in the eye
Management:
  • Chemotherapy
  • Laser therapy
  • Surgery in severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Retinoblastoma

Rhabdomyosarcoma: Symptoms & Treatment

A rare soft tissue cancer that develops in muscles, mostly affecting children.

Rhabdomyosarcoma forms in skeletal muscle cells and can occur almost anywhere in the body.

Causes: Exact cause is unclear, but genetic factors are likely involved.

Symptoms:

  • Swelling or lump (painless or painful)
  • Blocked nose, blood in urine, or vision problems (depending on location)
Management:
  • Surgery
  • Chemotherapy
  • Radiotherapy
References:
  1. NHS: Rhabdomyosarcoma

Rheumatoid Arthritis: Symptoms & Management

An autoimmune disorder that causes joint inflammation and pain.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) causes the immune system to attack healthy joint tissues, leading to chronic inflammation.

Causes:

  • Immune system malfunction
  • Genetic predisposition
  • Environmental triggers (infections, smoking)
Symptoms:
  • Joint pain, swelling, and stiffness
  • Fatigue and fever
  • Joint deformity over time
Management:
  • Anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs, DMARDs)
  • Physical therapy
  • In severe cases, surgery
References:
  1. NHS: Rheumatoid Arthritis

Ringworm & Fungal Infections: Causes & Treatment

Common skin infections caused by fungi, affecting skin, nails, and scalp.

Fungal infections like ringworm are highly contagious and affect the skin, nails, and scalp.

Causes:

  • Direct skin contact with infected person/animal
  • Contaminated surfaces (gym equipment, towels)
Symptoms:
  • Itchy, red, circular rash (ringworm)
  • Cracked or discolored nails
  • Scaly scalp patches (in scalp infections)
Management:
  • Antifungal creams, powders, or oral medications
  • Keep affected area clean and dry
  • Avoid sharing personal items
References:
  1. NHS: Ringworm

Rosacea: Triggers, Symptoms & Care

A chronic skin condition causing facial redness and visible blood vessels.

Rosacea is a long-term skin condition affecting the face, sometimes involving eye irritation (ocular rosacea).

Causes & Triggers:

  • Genetics
  • Hot drinks, spicy foods, alcohol
  • Sun exposure and stress
Symptoms:
  • Facial redness and flushing
  • Visible blood vessels
  • Small red bumps or pus-filled pimples
Management:
  • Avoid known triggers
  • Topical medications (metronidazole, azelaic acid)
  • Laser therapy for visible vessels
References:
  1. NHS: Rosacea

Scabies: Symptoms, Causes & Treatment

A contagious skin condition caused by mites burrowing under the skin.

Scabies is an itchy skin infestation caused by tiny mites called *Sarcoptes scabiei*.

Causes:

  • Direct skin-to-skin contact with an infected person
  • Shared bedding, towels, or clothes
Symptoms:
  • Intense itching (worse at night)
  • Red rash with small blisters
  • Thin, irregular burrow tracks on the skin
Management:
  • Prescription creams (permethrin or malathion)
  • Wash bedding and clothes in hot water
  • Treat all household members simultaneously
References:
  1. NHS: Scabies

Scarlet Fever: Causes, Symptoms & Care

A bacterial infection causing a distinctive red rash and high fever.

Scarlet fever is caused by *Group A Streptococcus* bacteria, often following strep throat.

Causes:

  • Bacterial infection (Streptococcus pyogenes)
  • Spread via coughing, sneezing, or touching contaminated surfaces
Symptoms:
  • Bright red rash (feels like sandpaper)
  • Sore throat and high fever
  • Red tongue ("strawberry tongue")
Management:
  • Antibiotic treatment (usually penicillin)
  • Rest and hydration
  • Avoid contact with others until 24 hours after antibiotics start
References:
  1. NHS: Scarlet Fever

Schizophrenia: Understanding Symptoms & Treatment

A severe mental health disorder affecting thinking, emotions, and behavior.

Schizophrenia is a long-term mental health condition causing distorted thoughts and perceptions.

Causes:

  • Combination of genetics and environmental factors
  • Brain chemistry imbalances
Symptoms:
  • Hallucinations (hearing/seeing things that aren't real)
  • Delusions (strong beliefs not based on reality)
  • Disorganized speech and behavior
Management:
  • Antipsychotic medications
  • Psychotherapy (CBT, family therapy)
  • Social support and rehabilitation programs
References:
  1. NHS: Schizophrenia

Sciatica: Causes, Symptoms & Relief

Pain caused by irritation or compression of the sciatic nerve.

Sciatica refers to pain along the sciatic nerve, which runs from the lower back down each leg.

Causes:

  • Herniated disc or spinal stenosis
  • Muscle spasm or injury
Symptoms:
  • Sharp pain radiating from lower back to leg
  • Numbness or tingling in leg or foot
  • Worsens when sitting or coughing
Management:
  • Pain relief medications (NSAIDs)
  • Physical therapy and gentle exercise
  • Severe cases may require steroid injections or surgery
References:
  1. NHS: Sciatica

Scoliosis: Types, Causes & Treatment

A condition where the spine curves abnormally sideways.

Scoliosis causes an abnormal sideways curvature of the spine, often developing in childhood.

Causes:

  • Idiopathic (unknown cause in most cases)
  • Congenital (present at birth)
  • Neuromuscular (due to other conditions like cerebral palsy)
Symptoms:
  • Uneven shoulders or hips
  • Leaning to one side
  • Back pain (in adults)
Management:
  • Observation (mild cases)
  • Bracing (in growing children)
  • Surgery (severe cases)
References:
  1. NHS: Scoliosis

Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)

A type of depression triggered by seasonal changes, often in winter.

SAD is a form of depression linked to seasonal changes, especially in fall and winter.

Causes:

  • Lack of sunlight affecting serotonin and melatonin levels
  • Disruption of body clock (circadian rhythm)
Symptoms:
  • Low mood, fatigue, and irritability
  • Sleep disturbances
  • Craving for carbs and weight gain
Management:
  • Light therapy (using a light box)
  • Counseling (CBT)
  • Medication if necessary (antidepressants)
References:
  1. NHS: SAD

Sepsis: Causes, Symptoms & Urgent Care

A life-threatening reaction to an infection spreading through the body.

Sepsis is the body's extreme response to an infection, potentially leading to organ failure.

Causes:

  • Bacterial, viral, or fungal infections
  • Complications from pneumonia, UTIs, or surgery
Symptoms:
  • High or low body temperature
  • Confusion, rapid heart rate, or breathing difficulty
  • Clammy skin or rash
Management:
  • Immediate hospital treatment with antibiotics
  • IV fluids and oxygen
  • Critical care for severe cases
References:
  1. NHS: Sepsis

Septic Shock: Critical Care & Treatment

A severe form of sepsis causing dangerously low blood pressure.

Septic shock is a life-threatening progression of sepsis, causing vital organ failure.

Causes:

  • Severe infections leading to systemic inflammation
  • Inadequate blood supply to organs
Symptoms:
  • Extremely low blood pressure
  • Severe confusion or unconsciousness
  • Cold, clammy skin and weak pulse
Management:
  • Intensive care with fluids, antibiotics, and vasopressors
  • Organ support (ventilation, dialysis if needed)
References:
  1. NHS: Sepsis

Severe Head Injury: First Aid & Recovery

A serious trauma to the head that may affect brain function.

Severe head injuries can lead to brain damage, bleeding, or swelling.

Causes:

  • Falls, car accidents, or assaults
  • Sports injuries
Symptoms:
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Seizures, vomiting, or confusion
  • Bleeding from ears/nose
Management:
  • Immediate medical evaluation
  • CT scans and neurological exams
  • Surgery for brain bleeding or swelling
References:
  1. NHS: Severe Head Injury

Shingles: Symptoms & Prevention

A painful skin rash caused by the varicella-zoster virus.

Shingles is caused by the reactivation of the chickenpox virus.

Causes:

  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV)
Symptoms:
  • Painful rash on one side of body
  • Blisters that scab over
  • Fever and fatigue
Management:
  • Antiviral medications
  • Pain relief and calamine lotion
  • Vaccination for prevention
References:
  1. NHS: Shingles

Sickle Cell Disease: Causes, Symptoms & Care

A serious inherited blood disorder affecting red blood cells.

Sickle cell disease is a genetic condition where red blood cells develop an abnormal, crescent shape. These misshapen cells can block blood flow, causing pain, infections, and organ damage.

Causes:

  • Genetic mutation affecting hemoglobin production.
  • Passed from parents to children (both parents must carry the faulty gene).
Symptoms:
  • Severe pain episodes ("sickle cell crisis").
  • Fatigue due to anemia.
  • Swelling in hands and feet.
  • Increased risk of infections.
Management:
  • Regular health checks and blood tests.
  • Pain relief with medication during crises.
  • Prevent infections through vaccinations and antibiotics.
  • Blood transfusions in severe cases.
  • Bone marrow transplant (in selected cases).
Living with Sickle Cell:
  • Stay hydrated and avoid extreme temperatures.
  • Balanced diet rich in vitamins and minerals.
  • Avoid overexertion and manage stress.
References:
  1. NHS: Sickle Cell Disease
  2. CDC: Sickle Cell

Sinusitis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

Inflammation of sinuses causing congestion and discomfort.

Sinusitis occurs when the lining of the sinuses becomes swollen due to infection, allergies, or irritation.

Types:

  • Acute Sinusitis (short-term, <4 weeks).
  • Chronic Sinusitis (lasting >12 weeks).
Symptoms:
  • Facial pain and pressure.
  • Blocked nose and thick mucus discharge.
  • Headache and reduced sense of smell.
  • Bad breath (halitosis).
Causes:
  • Viral infections (like colds).
  • Bacterial infections (less common).
  • Allergies (like hay fever).
  • Nasal polyps or deviated septum.
Treatment:
  • Over-the-counter painkillers (paracetamol, ibuprofen).
  • Saline nasal sprays or rinses.
  • Steam inhalation to ease congestion.
  • Antibiotics (if bacterial cause is confirmed).
Prevention:
  • Good hand hygiene to avoid infections.
  • Treat allergies promptly.
  • Avoid smoking and smoky environments.
References:
  1. NHS: Sinusitis

Sjogren’s Syndrome: Symptoms & Care

Autoimmune disease that attacks moisture-producing glands.

Sjogren’s syndrome is a long-term autoimmune condition where the body’s immune system attacks glands that produce fluids, like tears and saliva.

Primary vs Secondary:

  • Primary: Occurs alone.
  • Secondary: Linked to other autoimmune diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis).
Symptoms:
  • Dry eyes and dry mouth.
  • Difficulty swallowing and speaking.
  • Joint pain and swelling.
  • Dry skin and vaginal dryness.
  • Fatigue.
Causes:
  • Exact cause unknown - linked to genetic, environmental, and immune factors.
Diagnosis:
  • Blood tests (antibodies).
  • Eye tests for dryness.
  • Lip biopsy (if needed).
Treatment:
  • Artificial tears and saliva substitutes.
  • Medications like pilocarpine to increase moisture production.
  • Immune-suppressing drugs in severe cases.
References:
  1. NHS: Sjogren’s Syndrome
  2. Mayo Clinic: Sjogren’s Syndrome

Melanoma: Symptoms, Risks & Prevention

A serious type of skin cancer that can spread if untreated.

Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that starts in pigment-producing cells (melanocytes). It can spread to other parts of the body if not caught early.

Symptoms:

  • New mole or change in an existing mole.
