  • Irregular shape, uneven border, multiple colors.
  • Itchy, bleeding, or crusty moles.
Causes & Risk Factors:
  • UV exposure from sun and tanning beds.
  • Fair skin, light hair, and blue eyes.
  • Family history of melanoma.
  • Weakened immune system.
Prevention:
  • Use SPF 30+ sunscreen regularly.
  • Wear protective clothing and avoid midday sun.
  • Self-check skin monthly and report changes to a doctor.
Treatment:
  • Surgical removal of melanoma.
  • Immunotherapy, targeted therapy, and chemotherapy (for advanced cases).
References:
  1. NHS: Melanoma

Non-Melanoma Skin Cancer: Symptoms & Care

A more common, less aggressive form of skin cancer.

Non-melanoma skin cancer usually affects the outer layers of skin, often caused by sun exposure.

Types:

  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC).
  • Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).
Symptoms:
  • Persistent scab or sore that doesn't heal.
  • Waxy, shiny lumps or red, scaly patches.
  • Bleeding or crusting skin growths.
Risk Factors:
  • Excessive sun exposure.
  • Fair skin or light hair.
  • History of sunburns.
Prevention:
  • Use sunscreen, cover skin, and avoid tanning beds.
Treatment:
  • Surgical removal (excision, Mohs surgery).
  • Cryotherapy (freezing the cancer).
  • Topical treatments (creams for superficial cases).
References:
  1. NHS: Non-melanoma Skin Cancer

Photosensitivity: Causes & Prevention

Increased sensitivity to sunlight, causing skin reactions.

Photosensitivity refers to heightened skin reaction to sunlight, triggered by medications, medical conditions, or genetic factors.

Causes:

  • Certain medications (antibiotics, diuretics, retinoids).
  • Autoimmune conditions (lupus).
  • Genetic disorders (porphyria).
Symptoms:
  • Redness, rash, or blistering after sun exposure.
  • Itching and burning sensation.
Management:
  • Avoid direct sunlight (especially midday).
  • Wear protective clothing and sunglasses.
  • Use broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 50+).
References:
  1. NHS: Sunlight Allergy

Rashes in Children: Identification & Care

Common childhood rashes explained for parents.

Children's skin rashes can have many causes—viral infections, allergies, or skin conditions.

Common Types:

  • Chickenpox.
  • Measles.
  • Heat rash.
  • Allergic rash (hives).
When to Seek Help:
  • Rash with fever.
  • Rapidly spreading rash.
  • Rash with difficulty breathing.
Treatment:
  • Antihistamines for allergic rashes.
  • Calamine lotion for soothing.
  • Moisturizers for dry skin.
  • Antibiotics for bacterial infections (if needed).
References:
  1. NHS: Rashes in Children

Slapped Cheek Syndrome: Causes & Symptoms

A common viral infection causing a bright red rash on the cheeks.

Slapped cheek syndrome (also called Fifth Disease) is caused by **parvovirus B19**. It mostly affects children but can occur in adults too.

Symptoms:

  • Bright red rash on both cheeks (resembles a slap).
  • Mild fever, headache, sore throat before rash.
  • Occasional body rash after face rash fades.
Transmission:
  • Spread through coughing and sneezing.
  • Infectious before rash appears.
Treatment:
  • Usually resolves without treatment.
  • Painkillers for fever or discomfort.
  • Plenty of fluids and rest.
References:
  1. NHS: Slapped Cheek Syndrome

Soft Tissue Sarcomas: Symptoms & Treatment

A rare type of cancer developing in soft tissues like muscles or fat.

Soft tissue sarcomas can develop anywhere in the body, often in the arms, legs, or abdomen.

Symptoms:

  • Painless lump that grows over time.
  • Pressure effects if tumor presses on nerves or organs.
Causes & Risks:
  • Previous radiation exposure.
  • Genetic syndromes (like Li-Fraumeni syndrome).
Treatment:
  • Surgery to remove tumor.
  • Radiotherapy and chemotherapy for larger or advanced tumors.
References:
  1. NHS: Soft Tissue Sarcomas

Soft Tissue Sarcomas in Teens & Young Adults

Rare cancers affecting soft tissues like muscles, fat, and blood vessels, occurring in younger age groups.

Soft tissue sarcomas are rare cancers that develop in the **soft tissues** of the body, including **muscles, fat, nerves, and blood vessels**. Though uncommon, they can affect **teenagers and young adults** and may behave differently in younger people compared to adults.

Common Types in Teens & Young Adults:

  • Rhabdomyosarcoma: Affects muscle tissue and is the most common type in this age group.
  • Synovial Sarcoma: Often develops near **joints**, such as knees or elbows.
  • Fibrosarcoma and Liposarcoma: Affect fibrous tissue or fat cells, though rarer in teens.
Symptoms:
  • A painless lump that gradually grows larger.
  • Swelling, discomfort, or restricted movement if near a joint.
  • In some cases, the lump can press on nearby nerves, causing tingling or numbness.
Diagnosis:
  • Physical examination and imaging (MRI, CT scan).
  • Biopsy to confirm diagnosis and type of sarcoma.
Treatment:
  • Managed by a **specialist sarcoma team** (often called an MDT - multidisciplinary team).
  • Surgery to remove the tumor where possible.
  • Radiotherapy to target any remaining cancer cells.
  • Chemotherapy, especially for certain aggressive types like rhabdomyosarcoma.
References:
  1. NHS: Soft Tissue Sarcomas - Teens
  2. Sarcoma UK

Sore Throat: Causes & Remedies

A sore throat is a common condition caused by viral or bacterial infections, allergies, or environmental irritants.

**Sore throat** refers to pain, irritation, or scratchiness in the throat, often worsened when swallowing. It can be caused by:

Causes:

  • Viral infections (cold, flu).
  • Bacterial infections (strep throat).
  • Allergies, smoking, dry air, pollution.
Symptoms:
  • Throat pain or scratchiness.
  • Difficulty swallowing.
  • Swollen glands in neck or jaw.
  • Hoarseness, fever (in some cases).
Treatment:
  • Rest, warm fluids, throat lozenges.
  • Pain relief (paracetamol, ibuprofen).
  • Antibiotics (only if bacterial infection confirmed).
Prevention:
  • Good hand hygiene.
  • Avoid smoking and exposure to irritants.
  • Stay hydrated, especially in dry environments.
References:
  1. NHS: Sore Throat

Spina Bifida: Types, Causes & Care

A birth defect affecting the spine's development, often detected during pregnancy.

**Spina bifida** is a condition where a baby’s spine and spinal cord do not form properly in the womb. The severity depends on the type.

Types:

  • Spina bifida occulta: Mildest form, often no symptoms.
  • Meningocele: Sac of fluid pushes through spine opening.
  • Myelomeningocele: Most severe, spinal cord exposed.
Causes & Risks:
  • Lack of folic acid during pregnancy.
  • Genetic factors.
  • Environmental influences.
Diagnosis:
  • Ultrasound scan during pregnancy.
  • Sometimes detected after birth.
Treatment & Care:
  • Early surgery to close spine if needed.
  • Physiotherapy and mobility aids.
  • Support for bowel and bladder issues.
Prevention:
  • Folic acid supplements before and during pregnancy.
References:
  1. NHS: Spina Bifida

Spinal Stenosis: Causes & Treatments

Spinal stenosis happens when the spaces in the spine narrow, putting pressure on the nerves.

Spinal stenosis usually affects the lower back or neck, leading to pain, weakness, or numbness.

Causes:

  • Age-related wear and tear (common).
  • Arthritis, herniated discs, or spinal injuries.
Symptoms:
  • Back pain and stiffness.
  • Numbness, tingling, or weakness in legs/arms.
  • Walking difficulties in severe cases.
Treatment:
  • Pain relief medication.
  • Physiotherapy for strengthening.
  • Surgery if severe nerve compression occurs.
References:
  1. NHS: Spinal Stenosis

Spleen Problems & Removal

The spleen helps fight infection and filters blood, but problems may require removal.

The spleen plays a key role in immunity and filtering damaged blood cells. Issues like **enlargement, injury, or disease** may need medical attention or removal.

Common Conditions:

  • Enlarged spleen (splenomegaly).
  • Spleen rupture due to injury.
  • Infections like mononucleosis.
Treatment:
  • Monitoring for mild cases.
  • Surgical removal (splenectomy) if needed.
Life After Spleen Removal:
  • Increased infection risk.
  • Vaccinations and preventive antibiotics recommended.
References:
  1. NHS: Spleen Problems

Stillbirth: Causes & Support

Stillbirth is the loss of a baby after 24 weeks of pregnancy, requiring emotional and medical support.

Stillbirth can happen due to complications during pregnancy, birth, or underlying health issues.

Causes:

  • Placental problems.
  • Pre-eclampsia.
  • Infections, birth defects, or umbilical cord issues.
Support:
  • Counselling and emotional support for parents.
  • Medical investigations to understand the cause.
  • Planning future pregnancies with specialist advice.
Prevention:
  • Regular antenatal care.
  • Monitoring baby’s movements.
  • Managing risk factors like diabetes or high blood pressure.
References:
  1. NHS: Stillbirth

Stomach Ache & Abdominal Pain

Common symptom caused by digestive issues, infections, or other conditions.

Abdominal pain ranges from mild to severe and can be caused by:

Common Causes:

  • Indigestion, constipation, or food poisoning.
  • Infections (gastroenteritis).
  • Appendicitis, gallstones, or ulcers.
Treatment:
  • Rest and hydration.
  • Pain relief medications.
  • Treat underlying cause if identified.
When to Seek Help:
  • Severe or persistent pain.
  • Vomiting blood, high fever, or significant bloating.
References:
  1. NHS: Stomach Ache

Stomach Cancer: Symptoms & Treatment

Cancer that starts in the stomach lining, affecting digestion and overall health.

Stomach cancer can develop in any part of the stomach and may spread if not detected early.

Symptoms:

  • Persistent indigestion.
  • Unintentional weight loss.
  • Blood in vomit or stools.
  • Loss of appetite or unexplained weight loss
  • Pain or a lump in the upper abdomen
  • Feeling full after eating a small amount
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Black stool or blood in vomit
  • Heartburn and indigestion
  • Fatigue or weakness
Treatment:
  • Surgery to remove part or all of the stomach.
  • Chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
References:
  • NHS: Stomach Cancer

    • Stomach Ulcer: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

    An open sore in the stomach lining that causes pain and digestive discomfort.

    Stomach ulcers, also known as peptic ulcers, form when the stomach lining is eroded by stomach acid.

    Causes:

    • Infection with Helicobacter pylori.
    • Long-term use of NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, aspirin).
    • Excess stomach acid production.
    Symptoms:
    • Burning stomach pain, especially between meals or at night.
    • Bloating, nausea, and indigestion.
    • In severe cases, vomiting or bleeding.
    Treatment:
    • Antibiotics to clear H. pylori infections.
    • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) to reduce acid production.
    • Lifestyle and dietary changes.
    References:
    1. NHS: Stomach Ulcer

    Streptococcus A (Strep A): Infections & Management

    A bacterium responsible for infections ranging from mild throat infections to more serious conditions.

    Streptococcus A causes a variety of infections, including strep throat, impetigo, and scarlet fever.

    Common Infections:

    • Strep throat.
    • Impetigo (skin infection).
    • Scarlet fever (when toxins are produced).
    Symptoms:
    • Sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.
    • Red rash or skin sores in impetigo.
    Treatment:
    • Antibiotics (usually penicillin or amoxicillin).
    • Good hygiene to prevent spread.
    Prevention:
    • Regular hand washing and avoiding close contact with infected individuals.
    References:
    1. NHS: Strep Throat

    Streptococcus A (Strep A): Infections & Management

    A bacterium responsible for infections ranging from mild throat infections to more serious conditions.

    Streptococcus A causes a variety of infections, including strep throat, impetigo, and scarlet fever.

    Common Infections:

    • Strep throat.
    • Impetigo (skin infection).
    • Scarlet fever (when toxins are produced).
    Symptoms:
    • Sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.
    • Red rash or skin sores in impetigo.
    Treatment:
    • Antibiotics (usually penicillin or amoxicillin).
    • Good hygiene to prevent spread.
    Prevention:
    • Regular hand washing and avoiding close contact with infected individuals.
    References:
    1. NHS: Strep Throat

    Stress, Anxiety & Low Mood: Coping Strategies

    Common mental health challenges that can affect everyday life.

    Stress, anxiety, and low mood are emotional responses that can be triggered by personal, work, or environmental factors. These conditions may overlap and impact daily functioning.

    Causes:

    • Life stressors and traumatic events.
    • Genetic and environmental factors.
    • Chronic health conditions.
    Symptoms:
    • Feelings of nervousness or sadness.
    • Sleep disturbances and changes in appetite.
    • Difficulty concentrating and low energy.
    Treatment & Support:
    • Counselling and cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT).
    • Stress management techniques (mindfulness, exercise).
    • Medication when necessary.
    References:
    1. NHS: Stress, Anxiety & Depression

    Stroke: Warning Signs & Emergency Care

    A medical emergency where the blood supply to the brain is interrupted.

    A stroke occurs when blood flow to a part of the brain is cut off, leading to brain cell damage. It is crucial to recognize the signs and act fast.

    Warning Signs (FAST):

    • Face: Uneven smile or drooping.
    • Arms: Weakness or numbness.
    • Speech: Slurred or confused speech.
    • Time: Call emergency services immediately.
    Causes:
    • Ischemic stroke (blood clot).
    • Hemorrhagic stroke (bleeding in the brain).
    Treatment:
    • Immediate emergency care.
    • Thrombolytic therapy for ischemic strokes.
    • Surgery or intervention for hemorrhagic strokes.
    Prevention:
    • Control high blood pressure, diabetes, and cholesterol.
    • Healthy lifestyle and regular exercise.
    References:
    1. NHS: Stroke

    Subacromial Pain Syndrome: Shoulder Impingement

    A common shoulder condition where tendons are compressed, causing pain and restricted movement.

    Subacromial pain syndrome is characterized by the impingement of tendons and bursa in the shoulder joint, often due to repetitive motion or injury.

    Causes:

    • Repetitive overhead activities.
    • Injury or inflammation in the shoulder.
    Symptoms:
    • Shoulder pain, especially when lifting the arm.
    • Weakness and reduced range of motion.
    Treatment:
    • Rest, ice, and anti-inflammatory medications.
    • Physical therapy and strengthening exercises.
    • In severe cases, corticosteroid injections or surgery.
    References:
    1. NHS: Subacromial Pain Syndrome

    Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS)

    The sudden, unexpected death of an infant during sleep, with no immediately identifiable cause.

    SIDS refers to the unexplained death of an otherwise healthy baby, typically during sleep. While the exact cause is unknown, several risk factors have been identified.

    Risk Factors:

    • Unsafe sleep environments (prone sleeping, loose bedding).
    • Overheating during sleep.
    • Exposure to cigarette smoke.
    Prevention:
    • Always place infants on their back to sleep.
    • Use a firm mattress with a fitted sheet.
    • Avoid loose bedding and soft toys in the crib.
    • Keep the baby’s sleep area smoke-free.
    References:
    1. NHS: SIDS

    Suicide: Prevention & Support

    Suicide is a major public health concern related to severe mental distress.

    Suicide refers to the act of taking one’s own life and is often linked to mental illnesses such as depression, anxiety, or bipolar disorder. It can also be triggered by overwhelming stress, trauma, or social isolation.

    Risk Factors:

    • Mental health disorders (e.g., depression, bipolar disorder).
    • Traumatic or stressful life events.
    • Substance abuse and social isolation.
    Warning Signs:
    • Expressing feelings of hopelessness or worthlessness.
    • Withdrawal from friends, family, and activities.
    • Talking about or hinting at suicide.
    Prevention & Support:
    • Immediate access to crisis support and mental health services.
    • Counselling and therapy (e.g., cognitive behavioural therapy).
    • Community support and professional intervention.
    References:
    1. NHS: Mental Health

    Supraventricular Tachycardia: Heart Rhythm Issues

    SVT is a rapid heart rate originating above the ventricles, leading to palpitations and discomfort.

    Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is characterized by episodes of rapid heartbeats due to abnormal electrical signals in the heart's upper chambers. It can cause symptoms like dizziness, chest pain, and shortness of breath.

    Symptoms:

    • Sudden, rapid heart rate.
    • Palpitations and chest discomfort.
    • Dizziness or lightheadedness.
    Causes & Risk Factors:
    • Underlying heart conditions.
    • Triggers such as stress, caffeine, or alcohol.
    Treatment:
    • Vagal maneuvers (e.g., coughing, bearing down) to slow the heart rate.
    • Medications to control heart rhythm.
    • Catheter ablation for recurrent or severe cases.
    References:
    1. NHS: Supraventricular Tachycardia

    Swollen Glands: Causes & When to Seek Help

    Swollen glands are often a sign of infection or inflammation in the body.

    Swollen glands, or lymphadenopathy, typically indicate that your body is fighting an infection. They are most commonly seen in the neck, armpits, or groin.

    Causes:

    • Viral infections (e.g., common cold, mononucleosis).
    • Bacterial infections (e.g., strep throat).
    • Other inflammatory conditions.
    Symptoms:
    • Tender, enlarged lymph nodes.
    • Often accompanied by fever or fatigue.
    Treatment:
    • Often resolves on its own with rest and hydration.
    • Antibiotics if a bacterial infection is diagnosed.
    References:
    1. NHS: Swollen Glands

    Syphilis: Stages, Symptoms & Treatment

    Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum.

    Syphilis progresses through several stages if untreated—from an initial sore (chancre) to widespread rash and serious complications affecting the heart and nervous system.

    Stages & Symptoms:

    • Primary: A painless sore at the infection site.
    • Secondary: Skin rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.
    • Tertiary: Severe complications in organs if left untreated.
    Treatment:
    • Antibiotics (typically penicillin) are highly effective.
    Prevention:
    • Safe sexual practices and regular testing.
    References:
    1. NHS: Syphilis

    Self-harm: Understanding & Seeking Help

    Self-harm is the act of deliberately injuring oneself as a way to cope with emotional distress.

    Self-harm can take many forms such as cutting, burning, or hitting oneself. It is often a symptom of underlying mental health issues such as depression, anxiety, or trauma.

    Reasons & Triggers:

    • Emotional distress and overwhelming feelings.
    • Mental health disorders like depression or anxiety.
    • Trauma or stress.
    Warning Signs:
    • Frequent cuts, burns, or other injuries.
    • Secrecy or withdrawal from social interactions.
    Support & Treatment:
    • Therapy and counselling (e.g., cognitive behavioural therapy).
    • Support groups and crisis intervention.
    • Developing healthier coping strategies.
    References:
    1. NHS: Self-harm

    Tennis Elbow: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

    Tennis elbow is an overuse injury causing pain on the outer elbow.

    Tennis elbow, medically known as lateral epicondylitis, is typically caused by repetitive strain or overuse of the forearm muscles, which leads to small tears in the tendon. This condition often affects those involved in activities like tennis, painting, or repetitive manual work.

    Causes:

    • Repetitive motions and overuse of the forearm muscles.
    • Improper technique during sports or work activities.
    Symptoms:
    • Pain and tenderness on the outer elbow.
    • Weak grip and difficulty in lifting objects.
    • Stiffness and discomfort during movement.
    Treatment:
    • Rest and modification of activities.
    • Ice packs, anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs), and physical therapy.
    • Use of braces or counterforce straps; injections or surgery in severe cases.
    References:
    1. NHS: Tennis Elbow

    Testicular Cancer: Early Signs, Diagnosis & Treatment

    A rare cancer affecting the testicles, most common in younger men.

    Testicular cancer occurs when abnormal cells form in the tissues of one or both testicles. It is most commonly seen in men aged 15-35. Early detection is key to effective treatment.

    Symptoms:

    • A lump or swelling in the testicle.
    • Pain or discomfort in the scrotum.
    • A feeling of heaviness in the scrotum.
    Diagnosis & Treatment:
    • Ultrasound scanning and blood tests for diagnosis.
    • Surgical removal (orchiectomy) is common, with radiotherapy or chemotherapy used as needed.
    References:
    1. NHS: Testicular Cancer

    Testicular Cancer in Teens & Young Adults: Awareness & Treatment

    Focusing on testicular cancer in younger men with emphasis on early detection.

    Although testicular cancer is relatively rare, it most commonly affects teenagers and young adults. Early detection greatly improves treatment outcomes. Young men should be aware of any changes in their testicles.

    Symptoms:

    • A painless lump or swelling in the testicle.
    • Discomfort or a dull ache in the scrotum.
    Treatment:
    • Surgical removal of the affected testicle.
    • Follow-up radiotherapy or chemotherapy may be required depending on the stage.
    References:
    1. NHS: Testicular Cancer

    Testicular Lumps & Swellings: When to Seek Help

    Lumps or swelling in the testicles can signal various conditions, including infections or cancer.

    Any unusual lump or swelling in the testicles should be evaluated by a healthcare professional. While some causes are benign—such as cysts or epididymitis—others, like testicular cancer, require prompt attention.

    Possible Causes:

    • Infections such as epididymitis or orchitis.
    • Benign cysts or varicoceles.
    • Testicular cancer.
    What to Do:
    • Seek medical advice for any persistent changes.
    • Diagnosis typically involves a physical exam and ultrasound.
    References:
    1. NHS: Testicular Cancer

    Thirst: Understanding Excessive Thirst & Its Causes

    Persistent thirst can be a sign of dehydration or an underlying health condition.

    Thirst is your body’s way of signaling that it needs more fluids. While it’s normal to feel thirsty after exercise or in hot weather, excessive thirst may be a symptom of dehydration, diabetes, or other metabolic disorders.

    Common Causes:

    • Inadequate fluid intake.
    • High temperatures or intense physical activity.
    • Medical conditions like diabetes.
    When to Seek Help:
    • If thirst is accompanied by frequent urination, unexplained weight loss, or fatigue.
    Management:
    • Increase water intake and monitor hydration.
    • Consult a healthcare provider if symptoms persist.
    References:
    1. NHS: Dehydration

    Threadworms: Symptoms, Treatment & Prevention

    Threadworms, also known as pinworms, are common intestinal parasites that primarily affect children.

    Threadworms are tiny, white parasitic worms that infect the intestines, causing intense anal itching—especially at night. They are spread through contaminated hands, food, or surfaces.

    Symptoms:

    • Intense anal itching, particularly at night.
    • Irritability and disturbed sleep.
    • Occasionally, abdominal discomfort or nausea.
    Treatment:
    • Prescription anthelmintic medications to eliminate the worms.
    • Strict hygiene practices to prevent reinfection.
    Prevention:
    • Regular hand washing and proper cleaning of bed linens and clothes.
    References:
    1. NHS: Threadworms

    Thrush: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

    Thrush is a fungal infection caused by Candida, affecting the mouth and other areas.

    Thrush is a common fungal infection, typically affecting the mouth (oral thrush) but it can also occur in other moist areas of the body. It results from an overgrowth of the Candida fungus.

    Causes:

    • Weakened immune system or imbalance in oral flora.
    • Use of antibiotics, steroids, or inhaled corticosteroids.
    • Underlying conditions such as diabetes.
    Symptoms:
    • White, creamy patches on the tongue, inner cheeks, or throat.
    • Redness and soreness in the affected areas.
    • Difficulty swallowing or a cotton-like feeling in the mouth.
    Treatment:
    • Antifungal medications (lozenges, gels, or tablets).
    • Improved oral hygiene.
    • Management of underlying conditions.
    References:
    1. NHS: Thrush

    Thumb Fracture: Causes, Symptoms & Management

    A thumb fracture is a break in one of the thumb bones, often resulting from trauma.

    A thumb fracture can occur from falls, sports injuries, or accidents. It results in pain, swelling, and sometimes a visible deformity. Prompt treatment is essential to restore function.

    Causes:

    • Direct trauma or impact.
    • Falls or accidents during sports.
    Symptoms:
    • Severe pain and tenderness in the thumb.
    • Swelling and bruising.
    • Difficulty moving the thumb or gripping objects.
    Treatment:
    • Immobilization with a cast or splint.
    • Rest, ice, and elevation.
    • Surgery in complex or displaced fractures.
    References:
    1. NHS: Fractures

    Thyroid Cancer: Symptoms, Diagnosis & Treatment

    Thyroid cancer occurs in the thyroid gland and can affect hormone regulation.

    Thyroid cancer develops in the thyroid gland, located in the neck, and is usually detected through a combination of physical examination, ultrasound, and biopsy. Early diagnosis is crucial for effective treatment.

    Symptoms:

    • Lump or swelling in the neck.
    • Hoarseness or voice changes.
    • Difficulty swallowing.
    Treatment:
    • Surgical removal of the thyroid gland (thyroidectomy).
    • Radioactive iodine treatment and hormone therapy post-surgery.
    References:
    1. NHS: Thyroid Cancer

    Thyroid Cancer in Teens & Young Adults: Awareness & Treatment

    Although rare, thyroid cancer can affect younger individuals, making early detection essential.

    Thyroid cancer in teenagers and young adults is less common but requires prompt attention. Early detection leads to better treatment outcomes, which often involve surgery followed by hormone therapy.

    Symptoms:

    • Swelling or a lump in the neck.
    • Hoarseness and changes in voice.
    • Difficulty swallowing.
    Treatment:
    • Surgical removal of the affected thyroid tissue.
    • Radioactive iodine therapy as needed.
    References:
    1. NHS: Thyroid Cancer

    Tick Bites: Prevention & Management

    Tick bites can transmit infections like Lyme disease if not promptly treated.

    Tick bites occur when ticks attach to the skin, typically during outdoor activities in wooded or grassy areas. Prompt and proper tick removal is essential to prevent infection.

    Prevention:

    • Avoid tick-infested areas; wear long sleeves and trousers when outdoors.
    • Use insect repellent containing DEET.
    Management:
    • Carefully remove ticks with fine-tipped tweezers.
    • Clean the bite area thoroughly and monitor for signs of infection.
    • Seek medical advice if symptoms of Lyme disease develop.
    References:
    1. NHS: Lyme Disease

    Tinnitus: Causes, Symptoms & Management

    Tinnitus is characterized by persistent ringing or buzzing in the ears without an external sound source.

    Tinnitus is a condition where you experience a constant noise—such as ringing, buzzing, or hissing—in one or both ears. It can be caused by prolonged exposure to loud noises, ear infections, or other underlying health issues.

    Causes:

    • Noise-induced hearing loss.
    • Ear infections or earwax buildup.
    • Stress and aging.
    Symptoms:
    • Persistent ringing, buzzing, or hissing sounds.
    • Difficulty concentrating or sleeping due to the noise.
    Management:
    • Hearing aids or sound therapy.
    • Stress management and counselling.
    • Medications in some cases.
    References:
    1. NHS: Tinnitus

    Tonsillitis: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

    Tonsillitis is the inflammation of the tonsils, commonly caused by viral or bacterial infections.

    Tonsillitis involves swelling and inflammation of the tonsils, leading to a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and sometimes fever. It is most common in children but can affect people of all ages.

    Causes:

    • Viral infections (such as the common cold or flu).
    • Bacterial infections (e.g., streptococcus causing strep throat).
    Symptoms:
    • Sore throat and painful swallowing.
    • Red, swollen tonsils with white patches.
    • Fever, swollen lymph nodes, and general malaise.
    Treatment:
    • Rest, hydration, and pain relief medications.
    • Antibiotics if a bacterial infection is confirmed.
    • Gargling with warm salt water to ease throat pain.
    References:
    1. NHS: Tonsillitis

    Tooth Decay: Causes, Symptoms & Prevention

    Tooth decay, also known as dental caries, is a common dental issue caused by bacteria that break down sugars.

    Tooth decay occurs when bacteria in your mouth produce acids that gradually erode tooth enamel, leading to cavities and pain. Factors such as diet, poor oral hygiene, and genetics all play a role.

    Causes:

    • Poor brushing and flossing habits.
    • Frequent consumption of sugary or acidic foods and drinks.
    Symptoms:
    • Tooth sensitivity and pain.
    • Visible holes or discoloration on the tooth.
    • Bad breath.
    Prevention & Treatment:
    • Regular brushing with fluoride toothpaste and flossing.
    • Professional dental cleanings and fluoride treatments.
    • Fillings or crowns for advanced decay.
    References:
    1. NHS: Tooth Decay

    Toothache: Causes, Relief & Treatment

    Toothache is pain arising from the teeth or surrounding tissues, often signaling underlying dental problems.

    Toothache can result from cavities, gum disease, or injury. The pain may range from mild to severe, and early dental intervention is important for treatment.

    Causes:

    • Dental decay and cavities.
    • Gum infections or abscesses.
    • Cracked or broken teeth.
    Symptoms:
    • Persistent or intermittent pain in or around a tooth.
    • Sensitivity to hot, cold, or sweet foods.
    Treatment:
    • Pain relief with medications like paracetamol or ibuprofen.
    • Dental procedures such as fillings, root canals, or extractions.
    References:
    1. NHS: Toothache

    Tourette’s Syndrome: Symptoms & Management

    Tourette’s syndrome is a neurological disorder marked by involuntary motor and vocal tics.

    Tourette’s syndrome typically begins in childhood and is characterized by repeated, involuntary movements and sounds. Although the condition can vary in severity, many individuals learn to manage their symptoms with support.

    Symptoms:

    • Motor tics, such as blinking or facial grimacing.
    • Vocal tics, including throat clearing or grunting.
    Management:
    • Behavioral therapies and support groups.
    • Medications in more severe cases.
    References:
    1. NHS: Tourette’s Syndrome

    Transient Ischaemic Attack (TIA): Warning Signs & Prevention

    A TIA, often called a mini-stroke, is a temporary interruption of blood flow to the brain.

    A transient ischaemic attack (TIA) produces stroke-like symptoms that resolve within a short period. It serves as a warning sign for potential future strokes and requires prompt medical evaluation.

    Symptoms:

    • Sudden weakness or numbness on one side of the body.
    • Difficulty speaking or understanding speech.
    • Dizziness or loss of balance.
    Prevention & Management:
    • Immediate medical assessment to manage risk factors.
    • Lifestyle changes and medications to control blood pressure and cholesterol.
    References:
    1. NHS: TIA

    Transverse Myelitis: Inflammation & Neurological Impact

    A rare condition causing inflammation of the spinal cord that can lead to pain and sensory changes.

    Transverse myelitis is characterized by inflammation across a segment of the spinal cord, which can result in pain, weakness, and sensory disturbances below the level of inflammation. Its causes include infections, autoimmune reactions, or unknown factors.

    Symptoms:

    • Back pain and stiffness.
    • Numbness or tingling in the limbs.
    • Muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.
    Treatment:
    • Corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
    • Plasma exchange therapy and supportive care.
    • Rehabilitation to regain function.
    References:
    1. NHS: Transverse Myelitis

    Trichomonas Infection: Symptoms, Diagnosis & Treatment

    Trichomonas infection is a common sexually transmitted infection caused by a parasite.

    Trichomonas infection, caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, affects both men and women but is more common in women. It can cause irritation and discomfort in the genital area.

    Symptoms:

    • Itching, burning, or irritation in the genital area.
    • Unusual vaginal discharge or odor (in women).
    • Discomfort during urination or sexual intercourse.
    Treatment:
    • Antiprotozoal medications (usually metronidazole).
    • Treatment of sexual partners to prevent reinfection.
    References:
    1. NHS: Trichomonas Infection

    Trigeminal Neuralgia: Facial Pain & Management

    Trigeminal neuralgia is a chronic pain condition affecting the facial nerves, leading to severe, shock-like pain.

    Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by sudden, intense facial pain along the distribution of the trigeminal nerve. The pain is often triggered by everyday activities such as speaking, chewing, or touching the face.

    Symptoms:

    • Sharp, stabbing pain on one side of the face.
    • Episodic attacks that can last seconds to minutes.
    Treatment & Management:
    • Medications, such as anticonvulsants, to manage pain.
    • Surgical options for patients who do not respond to medication.
    • Pain management and supportive therapies.
    References:
    1. NHS: Trigeminal Neuralgia

    Tuberculosis (TB): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

    TB is a contagious infection primarily affecting the lungs, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

    Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can also impact other organs. It spreads through airborne droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes.

    Symptoms:

    • Persistent cough (often with blood-tinged sputum).
    • Fever, night sweats, and weight loss.
    • Fatigue and loss of appetite.
    Treatment:
    • A long-term course (6–9 months) of multiple antibiotics (e.g., isoniazid, rifampicin).
    • Strict adherence to the treatment plan with regular follow-ups.
    References:
    1. NHS: Tuberculosis

    Type 1 Diabetes: Causes, Symptoms & Management

    An autoimmune condition where the pancreas produces little or no insulin.

    Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease that usually appears in childhood or adolescence. In this condition, the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys the insulin-producing cells in the pancreas, leading to little or no insulin production.

    Symptoms:

    • Excessive thirst and frequent urination.
    • Unexplained weight loss and fatigue.
    • Blurred vision.
    Management:
    • Insulin injections or pump therapy.
    • Regular blood sugar monitoring.
    • Balanced diet and regular physical activity.
    References:
    1. NHS: Type 1 Diabetes

    Type 2 Diabetes: Causes, Symptoms & Management

    A metabolic disorder where the body becomes resistant to insulin or doesn’t produce enough.

    Type 2 diabetes is a chronic condition that affects how your body processes blood sugar (glucose). It is typically associated with insulin resistance and is often linked to factors such as obesity, sedentary lifestyle, and genetics.

    Symptoms:

    • Increased thirst and frequent urination.
    • Fatigue and blurred vision.
    • Slow healing of wounds.
    Management:
    • Lifestyle changes: healthy diet, weight management, and exercise.
    • Oral medications and/or insulin therapy as required.
    • Regular monitoring of blood sugar levels.
    References:
    1. NHS: Type 2 Diabetes

    Ulcerative Colitis: Symptoms, Causes & Treatment

    A chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting the colon and rectum.

    Ulcerative colitis is a chronic condition that causes inflammation and ulcers along the lining of the colon and rectum. Its exact cause is unknown, but it likely involves a combination of genetic, immune, and environmental factors.

    Symptoms:

    • Abdominal pain and cramping.
    • Diarrhea, often with blood or pus.
    • Urgency to have bowel movements and fatigue.
    Treatment:
    • Anti-inflammatory medications and immunosuppressants.
    • Dietary changes and, in severe cases, surgical intervention.
    References:
    1. NHS: Ulcerative Colitis

    Underactive Thyroid: Symptoms, Causes & Treatment

    Also known as hypothyroidism, it occurs when the thyroid gland doesn’t produce enough hormones.

    Underactive thyroid, or hypothyroidism, is a condition where the thyroid gland fails to produce sufficient thyroid hormones, resulting in a slowdown of the body's metabolism.

    Symptoms:

    • Fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance.
    • Dry skin, constipation, and depression.
    Treatment:
    • Thyroid hormone replacement therapy (e.g., Levothyroxine).
    • Regular monitoring of thyroid levels.
    References:
    1. NHS: Underactive Thyroid

    Urinary Incontinence: Causes, Symptoms & Management

    A condition involving involuntary leakage of urine, affecting daily life.

    Urinary incontinence is the unintentional loss of urine. It can result from a range of factors such as weakened pelvic muscles, nerve damage, or age-related changes.

    Types & Causes:

    • Stress incontinence: Leakage during physical activity or coughing.
    • Urge incontinence: Sudden, intense urge to urinate.
    • Overflow incontinence: Incomplete bladder emptying.
    Management:
    • Pelvic floor exercises and bladder training.
    • Medications or surgical options in severe cases.
    References:
    1. NHS: Urinary Incontinence

    Urinary Incontinence in Women: Causes, Symptoms & Management

    Involuntary leakage of urine that commonly affects women, especially after childbirth or during menopause.

    Urinary incontinence in women is a common condition that may occur due to weakened pelvic floor muscles, hormonal changes during menopause, or after childbirth. It can range from occasional leaks to more frequent, disruptive symptoms.

    Causes & Risk Factors:

    • Childbirth and pelvic floor trauma.
    • Menopausal hormonal changes.
    • Obesity and chronic coughing.
    Symptoms:
    • Involuntary urine leakage during physical activity or when sneezing.
    • A sudden, strong urge to urinate.
    • Frequent bathroom visits.
    Management:
    • Pelvic floor muscle training (Kegel exercises).
    • Lifestyle modifications and bladder training.
    • Medications or, in severe cases, surgical interventions.
    References:
    1. NHS: Urinary Incontinence

    Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

    A common infection that affects the urinary system, often causing burning and frequent urination.

    Urinary tract infections (UTIs) occur when bacteria, most commonly E. coli, enter the urinary tract. UTIs can affect the bladder (cystitis), urethra (urethritis), or kidneys (pyelonephritis).

    Causes:

    • Bacterial entry through the urethra.
    • Poor hygiene, sexual activity, and blockages in the urinary tract.
    Symptoms:
    • Burning sensation when urinating.
    • Frequent urge to urinate.
    • Lower abdominal pain and cloudy or strong-smelling urine.
    Treatment:
    • Antibiotics to clear the infection.
    • Increased fluid intake and pain relief medications.
    References:
    1. NHS: Urinary Tract Infection

    UTI in Children: Warning Signs & Treatment

    UTIs in children can cause fever, irritability, and discomfort, and require prompt treatment.

    Urinary tract infections in children are relatively common, particularly in girls. They may present with fever, irritability, and sometimes abdominal pain. Early diagnosis and treatment are important to prevent kidney damage.

    Common Signs in Children:

    • Fever and irritability.
    • Abdominal or back pain.
    • Changes in urination (burning, frequency, or strong smell).
    Treatment:
    • Antibiotics prescribed by a pediatrician.
    • Encouraging regular fluid intake and proper hygiene.
    References:
    1. NHS: UTI in Children

    Urticaria (Hives): Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

    Urticaria, commonly known as hives, causes red, itchy welts on the skin and can be triggered by allergens or stress.

    Urticaria is a skin reaction characterized by raised, red, itchy welts that can vary in size. It is often triggered by allergens such as foods, medications, or insect stings, though stress and infections can also cause hives. Hives may be acute or chronic.

    Causes & Triggers:

    • Allergic reactions (foods, medications, insect bites).
    • Infections or stress.
    Symptoms:
    • Red, raised, itchy welts on the skin.
    • Swelling and discomfort.
    Treatment:
    • Antihistamines to reduce symptoms.
    • Avoiding known triggers.
    • In severe cases, corticosteroids may be prescribed.
    References:
    1. NHS: Urticaria (Hives)

    Vaginal Cancer: Symptoms, Causes & Treatment

    A rare type of cancer that develops in the vagina, often linked to HPV infection.

    Causes:

    • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.
    • Smoking and weakened immune system.
    • Exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) in pregnancy.
    Symptoms:
    • Abnormal vaginal bleeding.
    • Pain during intercourse.
    • A lump or mass in the vagina.
    Diagnosis:
    • Pelvic examination and Pap smear.
    • Biopsy and imaging tests like MRI or CT scan.
    Treatment:
    • Surgery to remove cancerous tissue.
    • Radiotherapy and chemotherapy.
    Prevention:
    • HPV vaccination.
    • Avoiding smoking and practicing safe sex.
    References:
    1. NHS: Vaginal Cancer

    Vaginal Discharge: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

    Vaginal discharge is a normal body function, but changes may indicate an infection.

    Causes:

    • Normal hormonal fluctuations.
    • Infections such as bacterial vaginosis or yeast infections.
    Symptoms:
    • Clear or white discharge (normal).
    • Yellow, green, or foul-smelling discharge (infection).
    Diagnosis:
    • Pelvic examination and lab tests.
    Treatment:
    • Antibiotics for bacterial infections.
    • Antifungal treatments for yeast infections.
    Prevention:
    • Good hygiene and avoiding scented products.
    • Safe sexual practices.
    References:
    1. NHS: Vaginal Discharge

    Varicose Eczema: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

    A skin condition affecting the lower legs, often caused by poor blood circulation.

    Causes:

    • Chronic venous insufficiency.
    • Blood pooling in leg veins.
    Symptoms:
    • Dry, itchy, and red skin.
    • Swelling and flaking skin.
    Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination.
    Treatment:
    • Moisturizers and corticosteroid creams.
    • Compression stockings to improve circulation.
    Prevention:
    • Regular movement and leg elevation.
    References:
    1. NHS: Varicose Eczema

    Vertigo: Causes, Symptoms & Treatment

    A sensation of spinning or dizziness, often caused by inner ear issues.

    Causes:

    • Inner ear disorders (e.g., BPPV, Meniere’s disease).
    • Head injuries and migraines.
    Symptoms:
    • Feeling of spinning or tilting.
    • Nausea and balance issues.
    Diagnosis:
    • Hearing and balance tests.
    Treatment:
    • Vestibular rehabilitation exercises.
    • Medications for nausea and dizziness.
    Prevention:
    • Avoid sudden head movements.
    References:
    1. NHS: Vertigo

    Varicose Veins: Causes, Symptoms, Prevention & Treatment

    Varicose veins are swollen, twisted veins that are visible under the skin, most commonly in the legs.

    Causes:

    • Genetic predisposition and age-related wear.
    • Prolonged standing or sitting and obesity.
    Symptoms:
    • Bulging, bluish veins in the legs.
    • Leg pain, heaviness, and swelling.
    • Itching and cramping.
    Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination and ultrasound scan.
    Prevention:
    • Regular exercise and maintaining a healthy weight.
    • Leg elevation and compression stockings.
    Treatment:
    • Conservative management, sclerotherapy, laser treatments, or surgery if severe.
    References:
    1. NHS: Varicose Veins

    Venous Leg Ulcer: Causes, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    A chronic wound on the leg caused by long-term venous insufficiency.

    Venous leg ulcers form due to poor circulation in the leg veins, which leads to increased pressure and skin breakdown.

    Causes:

    • Chronic venous insufficiency and history of deep vein thrombosis.
    • Prolonged standing and obesity.
    Symptoms:
    • Slow-healing sores typically near the ankles.
    • Swelling, pain, and skin discoloration.
    Diagnosis:
    • Clinical examination and duplex ultrasound.
    Prevention:
    • Compression therapy, leg elevation, and exercise.
    • Maintaining a healthy weight.
    Treatment:
    • Proper wound care, compression dressings, and medications to improve circulation.
    • Surgical interventions in advanced cases.
    References:
    1. NHS: Venous Leg Ulcer

    Vitamin B12/Folate Deficiency Anaemia: Causes, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    Anaemia due to insufficient vitamin B12 or folate leads to fatigue, weakness, and other systemic symptoms.

    When the body lacks enough vitamin B12 or folate, it can result in a reduced production of healthy red blood cells, causing anaemia.

    Causes:

    • Poor dietary intake or malabsorption conditions.
    • Gastrointestinal disorders such as pernicious anaemia.
    Symptoms:
    • Fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
    • Pale skin and heart palpitations.
    • Neurological issues (more common in B12 deficiency).
    Diagnosis:
    • Blood tests to measure vitamin B12, folate, and red blood cell count.
    Prevention:
    • A balanced diet rich in vitamin B12 (meat, dairy) and folate (leafy greens, legumes).
    • Supplementation for those at risk.
    Treatment:
    • Vitamin supplements or injections and addressing underlying causes.
    References:
    1. NHS: Vitamin B12 Deficiency

    Vomiting in Adults: Causes, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    Vomiting in adults can arise from a range of causes including infections, gastrointestinal disorders, or systemic illnesses.

    Vomiting is the forceful expulsion of stomach contents and can be acute or recurrent. It may indicate infections, food poisoning, motion sickness, or other underlying conditions.

    Causes:

    • Gastroenteritis, food poisoning, or medication side effects.
    • Migraine, stress, or gastrointestinal obstructions.
    Symptoms:
    • Nausea, retching, and abdominal discomfort.
    • Dehydration and weakness if persistent.
    Diagnosis:
    • Medical history, physical examination, and laboratory tests.
    Prevention:
    • Good hygiene and proper food handling.
    • Avoidance of known triggers and adequate hydration.
    Treatment:
    • Rehydration and antiemetic medications.
    • Treatment of the underlying cause.
    References:
    1. NHS: Vomiting

    Vomiting in Children & Babies: Causes, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    Vomiting in young children is common and can result from infections, allergies, or feeding issues.

    In children and babies, vomiting may be a symptom of viral gastroenteritis, food allergies, or reflux. It is important to monitor for dehydration and other complications.

    Causes:

    • Viral infections (gastroenteritis) or food intolerance.
    • Overfeeding or reflux in babies.
    Symptoms:
    • Nausea, retching, and projectile vomiting.
    • Fever, irritability, and signs of dehydration.
    Diagnosis:
    • Clinical assessment, with tests if dehydration or infection is suspected.
    Prevention:
    • Good hygiene, proper food preparation, and appropriate feeding practices.
    Treatment:
    • Rehydration and electrolyte balance, with medications as prescribed.
    • Medical attention if vomiting is persistent or severe.
    References:
    1. NHS: Vomiting in Children

    Vulval Cancer: Causes, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    Vulval cancer is a rare cancer affecting the external female genitalia, often linked to HPV infection.

    Vulval cancer involves the development of abnormal cells in the vulva, typically in older women. Risk factors include HPV infection, chronic vulvar inflammation, and smoking.

    Causes:

    • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection and chronic inflammation.
    • Smoking and other lifestyle factors.
    Symptoms:
    • Itching, pain, or a lump on the vulva.
    • Changes in the skin’s appearance, such as thickening or discoloration.
    Diagnosis:
    • Pelvic examination, biopsy, and imaging tests.
    Prevention:
    • HPV vaccination and regular gynecological check-ups.
    • Smoking cessation and maintaining good vulvar hygiene.
    Treatment:
    • Surgical removal of cancerous tissue.
    • Radiotherapy and chemotherapy for advanced stages.
    References:
    1. NHS: Vulval Cancer

    Warts & Verrucas: Causes, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    Common skin growths caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), appearing on hands, feet, or other areas.

    Causes:

    • Infection with human papillomavirus (HPV).
    • Direct contact with an infected person or contaminated surfaces.
    Symptoms:
    • Small, rough, raised bumps (warts) or flat, spongy lesions (verrucas).
    • Often painless but can become irritated or painful when on pressure areas.
    Diagnosis:
    • Clinical examination by a healthcare professional.
    • Rarely, a biopsy is performed if diagnosis is uncertain.
    Prevention:
    • Avoid direct skin-to-skin contact in communal areas (e.g., swimming pools, gym showers).
    • Maintain good personal hygiene and use protective footwear.
    Treatment:
    • Topical treatments like salicylic acid, cryotherapy, or laser therapy.
    • In resistant cases, minor surgical removal may be necessary.
    References:
    1. NHS: Warts

    Whiplash: Causes, Symptoms, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    A neck injury caused by a sudden, forceful back-and-forth motion, commonly due to road traffic accidents.

    Causes:

    • Rapid, forceful movement of the head, most often in car accidents or sports injuries.
    Symptoms:
    • Neck pain, stiffness, and headaches.
    • Dizziness, blurred vision, and sometimes numbness in arms.
    Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination and patient history.
    • X-rays, MRI or CT scans to rule out fractures or other injuries.
    Prevention:
    • Use of seat belts and proper head restraints in vehicles.
    • Protective gear in sports and adherence to safety measures.
    Treatment:
    • Rest, ice, and pain relief medications (NSAIDs).
    • Physical therapy and gentle exercises.
    • In severe cases, a short-term neck brace or further interventions.
    References:
    1. NHS: Whiplash

    Whooping Cough: Causes, Symptoms, Prevention & Treatment

    A highly contagious respiratory infection characterized by severe coughing fits and a distinctive "whoop" sound.

    Causes:

    • Infection by the Bordetella pertussis bacterium.
    • Spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
    Symptoms:
    • Severe, uncontrollable coughing fits with a high-pitched "whoop" sound.
    • Vomiting after coughing and difficulty breathing.
    Diagnosis:
    • Clinical examination, patient history, and laboratory tests.
    Prevention:
    • Vaccination (DTP/DTaP) for children and boosters for adults.
    • Good respiratory hygiene and avoiding close contact with infected individuals.
    Treatment:
    • Antibiotics, especially if diagnosed early.
    • Supportive care to manage symptoms and prevent complications.
    References:
    1. NHS: Whooping Cough

    Wilms’ Tumour: Causes, Symptoms, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    A rare kidney cancer that typically affects children, also known as nephroblastoma.

    Causes:

    • Exact cause is often unknown; genetic factors may contribute.
    • Some cases are associated with syndromes like WAGR or Denys-Drash.
    Symptoms:
    • Abdominal swelling or a palpable mass.
    • Abdominal pain and blood in the urine.
    • Fever and loss of appetite.
    Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination, ultrasound, CT scan, and biopsy.
    Prevention:
    • While prevention is not well established, early detection is key.
    Treatment:
    • Surgical removal of the affected kidney.
    • Chemotherapy and sometimes radiotherapy.
    References:
    1. NHS: Wilms’ Tumour

    Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome: Causes, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    A congenital heart condition causing episodes of rapid heart rate due to an extra electrical pathway.

    Causes:

    • A congenital abnormality where an extra electrical pathway (accessory pathway) exists in the heart.
    Symptoms:
    • Sudden episodes of rapid heart rate (palpitations).
    • Dizziness, shortness of breath, or chest discomfort.
    Diagnosis:
    • Electrocardiogram (ECG) and electrophysiological studies.
    Prevention:
    • Early detection and management can prevent complications.
    Treatment:
    • Medications to control heart rate and rhythm.
    • Catheter ablation to remove the accessory pathway if necessary.
    References:
    1. NHS: Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome

    Womb (Uterus) Cancer: Causes, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    A cancer that originates in the uterus, often in the endometrium, and primarily affects postmenopausal women.

    Causes:

    • Excess estrogen exposure, obesity, and genetic predisposition.
    • History of hormone replacement therapy.
    Symptoms:
    • Abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge.
    • Pain or pressure in the pelvic area.
    Diagnosis:
    • Pap smear, ultrasound, and endometrial biopsy.
    Prevention:
    • Maintaining a healthy weight and managing hormone levels.
    • Regular gynecological check-ups.
    Treatment:
    • Surgical removal of the uterus (hysterectomy).
    • Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, or hormone therapy if required.
    References:
    1. NHS: Uterine (Womb) Cancer

    Wrist Fracture: Causes, Diagnosis, Prevention & Treatment

    A break in one or more bones of the wrist, often resulting from a fall or injury.

    Causes:

    • Trauma from falls, sports injuries, or accidents.
    Symptoms:
    • Pain, swelling, and tenderness in the wrist.
    • Bruising and possible deformity.
    Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination and X-rays.
    Prevention:
    • Using protective gear during sports and fall-prevention strategies.
    Treatment:
    • Immobilization with a cast or splint.
    • Surgery in complex or displaced fractures.
    • Physical therapy for rehabilitation.
    References:
    1. NHS: Fractures

    Zika Virus: Causes, Symptoms, Prevention & Treatment

    Zika virus is a mosquito-borne virus that can cause mild symptoms and serious birth defects if contracted during pregnancy.

    Causes:

    • Transmitted primarily by Aedes mosquitoes.
    • Can also be spread through sexual contact and from mother to fetus.
    Symptoms:
    • Mild fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis.
    • Often asymptomatic in many cases.
    Diagnosis:
    • Blood or urine tests to detect viral RNA.
    Prevention:
    • Avoid mosquito bites by using repellents, wearing long sleeves, and staying in air-conditioned or screened areas.
    • Safe sexual practices and travel precautions in affected areas.
    Treatment:
    • No specific antiviral treatment; care is supportive with rest, hydration, and pain relief.
    • Special attention is given to pregnant women to monitor for complications.
    References:
    1. NHS: Zika Virus

    Yellow Fever: Causes, Symptoms, Prevention & Treatment

    Yellow fever is a viral hemorrhagic disease transmitted by mosquitoes, with symptoms ranging from mild fever to severe, life-threatening illness.

    Causes:

    • Caused by the yellow fever virus, spread by infected Aedes mosquitoes.
    • Endemic in certain tropical regions of Africa and South America.
    Symptoms:
    • Fever, chills, headache, backache, and muscle aches.
    • Severe cases may develop jaundice, bleeding, and organ failure.
    Diagnosis:
    • Blood tests and clinical evaluation based on symptoms and travel history.
    Prevention:
    • Vaccination is the most effective method of prevention.
    • Avoiding mosquito bites using repellents and protective clothing.
    Treatment:
    • No specific treatment exists; care is supportive, including hydration and management of complications.
    • Early detection and supportive care are critical.
    References:
    1. NHS: Yellow Fever

    COVID-19 Awareness

    Stay Safe, Stay Healthy

    Protect Yourself and Others

    COVID-19 is a contagious disease caused by the coronavirus. Taking preventive measures can significantly reduce the risk of infection and spread.

    • Wear a mask in crowded places.
    • Maintain social distancing (6 feet).
    • Wash hands regularly with soap and water.
    • Get vaccinated to protect yourself and others.
    • Stay home if you feel unwell or have symptoms.
    Learn More
